dinadaan-daanan ko lang sa quiapo yung mga stall na nasa movie, and most of the time, natatawa ako kasi napapaisip ako if may pumapatos ba talaga sa mga ganitong klase na mga tindahan. watching the film made me realize na totoo nga, madalas nararanasan ito ng mga kababaihan na nasa laylayan. may pumapatos talaga, lalo na kapag gipit at desperada ka na. sobrang galing, sa humigit isang oras na nilaan ng pelikula, natalakay na halos lahat ng mga pinaka-isyu ng pinas patungkol sa usapin ng abortion. nakakalungkot dahil ito ang realidad ng pagiging isang babae sa pinas. napakahirap, literal na women would go through dangerous lengths dahil ayaw ng gobyerno na bigyan tayong mga kababaihan ng right access to health kagaya ng ligtas na abortion.si over naman sa ebasdirek tonet GOAT

I never really gave much attention to Sunshine until it released on Netflix, and I'll be damned, ang ganda talaga! It's worth the 4/5 star average rating and the praise it's getting. Hindi ko pa pinanood ang ibang mga pelikula ni Antionette Jadeone, pero kumbinsido ako na panoorin pa ang mga dinirek niya. Sunshine is such a relatable character that i can't help but praise Maris for giving it her all here. There isn't anything over the top or exaggerated;‚Ä¶

tangina YUNG IYAK KO LORD this is a movie that was needed to be created actually WORD DUMP PLEASE DONT JUDGE MEill be honest, this was an uncomfortable watch. not because im against it but because i empathize with her so much that i could feel her pain and struggles. I CAN PHYSICALLY FEEL IT. DI NAMAN AKO IYAKIN PERO LALA NG HAGULGOL KO. when she was bleeding pucha yung puson ko parang nawawasak din. i really cannot fathom how women have to go through something so heartbreaking just because every being in her life failed her."ang nakabuntis sakanya, tito niya" TANGINA MAMATAY NA LAHAT NG LALAKI.why do women always have to bear the consequences, the pain, the fear, the judgement, the struggle‚Äî everything everytime a man messes up. i hope all pro-life individuals realize that there's nothing more cruel than birthing a baby no one ever wanted. why strip off a living human being off its hopes and dreams for a "baby" that is not even in a specific stage of gestation.Maris really did an amazing job portraying sunshine and what she's going through. i can't think of anyone who would've done better. i will forever be an advocate for woman's rights and reproductive health, and for individuals to acknowledge that that there is nothing wrong in choosing themselves; choosing your own path and chasing your dreams."gets ko na". I hope this movie will actually meet its goal of tackling teenage pregnancy and abortion in the Philippines. sana mamulat tayo.sobrang hirap maging babae sa mundo.ps. i love u papa P pero bwisit ka dito .

i like the concept of the personification of their unborn child as the kids.also, sobrang tapang ng movie na 'to in a pre-dominantly catholic country and i'm so happy na little by little we are finally opening up about this "taboo" topic.i hope in the near future, women will be free and have the right to choose what to do with their own bodies!!!

dream or responsibility?Are you anti- or pro-abortion?As this film is created from a very conservative country‚ÄîChristian‚Äîthis is such a hot take, especially for those religious people that were also shown in the film with the use of the OB-GYN. But as someone who's pro abortion, this is a chef's kiss and an overwhelming approach but a nightmare to those who oppose it. Abortion must be legalized now, as there were too many rape victims that couldn't escape from their nightmare but a ‚Äúblessing in disguise‚Äù to be treated by those who never experienced it. Actually I really have so many words to say, but I couldn't write it all down. And let's characterize the characters one by one. Maris' acting never disappointed me; she always proved why she deserved all the fame and recognition she's getting, and as for her character, she is such a loud, bold, and brave woman‚Äîdeciding all things without further hesitation, though I know it may just seem impulsive, but that's what everyone would do when their only dream is at risk.Jennica's character as a sister was the purest that we all need to have; how I would love to have someone like her by my side for the rest of my life.Elijah and Xyriel's characters were under surveillance by their parents, so they feared whenever they made a single mistake. I fear I somehow saw myself in them back then.And for the overall film, the whole team deserves a well and wide recognition.
GETS MO NA BA? OO GETS KO. ANG GANDA!!!!

here‚Äôs me and my thoughts na hindi organized :pfirst of all, habang pinapanood ko ‚Äòto puro ako ‚Äúshit‚Äù kasi shit, ang ganda t‚Äît gets ko na. every second of this film was worth it huhuhu. ang ganda ng cinematography neto and i don‚Äôt know a lot about color grading yet and other stuff related to that pero totoo at sang-ayon ako sa other reviews na kuhang-kuha neto talaga yung feeling ng nasa manila ka. i‚Äôve been studying there for almost three years na and hay, ito talaga yun. ganiyan na ganiyan yun. amoy mo lahat eh, dama mo lahatsecond, grabe mulat naman na ako pero yk that feeling when u read something o watch something na mas lalong nagpapamulat ng mata mo sa mga bagay-bagay XD i‚Äôm so happy na hindi nag give up si sunshine sa mga pangarap niya. ayaw niya maging nanay kasi ayaw niya maging nanay and this film reminds us na that‚Äôs okay and that should be our choice as women, not someone else‚Äôs. not what the world thinks that is better for us. sa atin yun. next, yung mga characters dito ang totoo rin. like how yung isang doctor doon sa isang hospital, kung makapagsalita akala mo hindi doctor e, sana nagmadre nalang siya. tapos yung lalaking doctor, oh god i hate men and that doctors screentime was like 15 seconds pero i‚Äôm so pissed off kasi mas mahalaga pa talaga sayo yung kalagayan ng licensya mo kesa doon sa buhay ng pasyente mo? like, hindi ba kaya ka nga nag doctor wth. tapos yung si miggy at yung tatay niya (ang pogi mo piolo) tangina mo miggy HAHAHAHAHA i swear this dude, bagay sa pangalan nya kasi alam niyo yon everyone says na yung mga miguel miggy migs are assholes. i don‚Äôt know how else to word this pero yung scene na sinasabi nila na sila na bahala doon sa pagsupport in financial ways tapos nung di tinanggap ni sunshine they made it seem like ungrateful lang siya pero ang hindi kasi nila magets eh ayaw niya nga kasi, kasi ayaw niya. HUHUHU ang ganda talaga. and saludo ako sa mga babae, saludo talaga ako sa mga babae na tumutulong din sa kapwa babae kasi tayo-tayo lang din halos nakakagets ng struggles natin. yung scene sa maternity ward :((((( hay. i also love how yung reaction nung ate nya was js so comforting. normally rin kasi diba sa ibang movies o mapa real life pag buntis yung kapatid mo at an early age, magagalit muna sila bago ka tulungan t‚Äîtand last yung line talaga that broke me pero expected ay yung ‚Äú13 lang siya‚Äù HUHUHU I HATE MEN ‚Äúdi ko naman jowa yun eh, tito ko yun‚Äù ü•πü•πü•πü•π HAYS. and ofc yung bata dito huhuhu hay. di ko na need i-explain yun . ‚Äúpangarap ko yung mga pangarap niya‚Äù ü•πü•πü•π 10/10 movie yesfeeling ko may gusto pa ko sabihin pero balikan ko nlng HAJDJAHAH

sa mundo kung saan pasan ng babae ang bawat pasakit, si sunshine ang ingay‚Äî sa bawat hinaing ng minorya, mga tinig na dapat pakinggan sapagkat si sunshine ay sumisimbolo sa mas mahalagang bagay na hindi dapat hayaang humina at ipagwalang bahala katulad ng patuloy na pagbabalewala sa boses ng mga kababaihan.simple lamang ang mensahe ni sunshine.sana ma-gets niyo at marami pang maka-gets. healthcare is a right. sa bawat daing, sa bawat kirot, nawa'y maalala niyo ang humahagulgol na boses ng kababaihan, na hindi lamang limitadosa isyu ng pagkaka-pantay-pantay, bagkus ang pagkakaroon ng sapat na access-one that is safe, legal, and doesn't put the lives of every woman in danger.we may not like nor be the biggest fan of maris but we cannot deny how deeply moving her perfomance portraying sunshine. ang galing. napaka-husay. hindi man direktang sabihin sa bawat linya, ramdam mo ang nais iparating ng bawat eksena at palitan ng linya ng bawat karakter lalo na ang mga matang punong-puno ng emosyon ni sunshine.boses ng kababaihan, pakinggan! legalize abortion, make healthcare accessible!

"pangarap ko kung anong pangarap niya."this is the perfect ending for mee!! :) mas pipiliin ko makita ang nanay ko maging masaya at matupad ang kanyang mga pangarap. hindi ko rin pipiliin maging ina kung alam ko sa sarili ko na hindi pa ako handa at may pangarap pa akong gustong makamit, at lalo na kung ganon ang magiging tatay ng anak ko. ang hirap maging babae, lalo na kung nasa pilipinas ka. hindi lahat ng tao sa pilipinasa mulat sa isyu na 'to. para sa kanila ang abortion ay isang kasalanan. pero parang mas makasalanan pa kung ipapangak mo 'yung anak mo pero hindi ka handa, wala kang pera at puno ka ng pagsisisi sa nagawa mo. ang masama pa kung sa anak lang din ibubuhos ang galit at poot na nararamdaman.hindi rin lahat ng magulang deserve magkaroon ng anak. katulad nalang ng nanay ni menggay, nasa hospital ang anak mo pero ganon pa rin reaction mo?!? tapos pinagsasamantalahan na nung tito, wala ka pa rin ginagawa?!? ay, tangina mo!hindi ko sila masisisi kung pina-abort nila ang kanilang mga anak. lahat ng mga babae ay may sari-sariling rason kung bakit nila pinapaabort ang kanilang mga anak. wala tayong karapatan para husgahan sila dahil wala naman tayo sa posisyon nila.ang masasabi ko lang talaga, tangina ng mga lalaki! wala kayong mga kwenta! pagtapos mo mabuntis si sunshine, iiwanan mo lang? kase alam niya na 'yung gagawin? ang kapal ng mukha mo! tas 'yung doctor, natatakot kase mawawala 'yung lisensya ampota. yung tito rin na nakabuntis kay menggay, putangina mo! sana mamaga itlog mo, gago ka! buti nga napukpok ka ng red horse!sa lahat ng sunshine sa mundo, hindi mo kailangan magpaliwanag at humigi ng tawad. choice at buhay mo 'yan at wala na silang pakialam don! :) gets na gets ko na, sunshine! :) sana lahat din ng sunshine sa mundo ay merong ate galeen! :)

this movie is such an eye-opener.it's exactly what Filipinos need to see right now. It goes deep into things like healthcare, religion, politics, and women's rights. I liked that it was mostly women helping Sunshine out, because who else really knows how that feels? The film totally calls out the hypocrisy of people who judge your life without knowing the massive problems and choices you had to weigh. For me, Annika was like Sunshine's conscience or her unborn child, and all that guilt. She was the one who helped Sunshine process everything, showing that she wasn't completely alone through all of it. And Rhed's storyline makes it clear that abortion is also about healthcare, especially when the victim is a child who hasn't even figured out the real world yet. The movie shows just how impossibly hard it is to raise a child in the Philippines, starting with the hospitals. So many are just not taken care of properly, and it really exposes the corruption and terrible state of our healthcare system. We should have the final say over our own bodies, but we still need to be responsible and aware of the consequences.Fave line: ‚Äúyung pangarap ko kung ano ang pangarap niya‚Äù ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù

THIS IS ABSOLUTE CINEMA.unang scenario pa lang, makukuha ka na ng pelikulang ito. napaka-realistic, at ramdam mo na agad ang hirap ni sunshine bilang babae. 'yung pagco-commute niya sa jeep, pagse-search niya sa tiktok, reddit, at twitter ng kung anong dapat gawin, danas na danas! wala ka naman kasing aasahan kundi sarili mo lang. kahit ang paghingi niya ng tawad sa Diyos dahil sa gagawin niyang "kasalanan," kuhang-kuha talaga. ganito pala sa maynila. maingay, mausok, at puno ng mga??? chariz lang. kidding aside, i haven't been to that place physically pero ewan ko ba, ang ganda ng cinematography. wala akong masabi.sobrang accurate rin ng portrayal dito ng isang public hospital. when sunshine woke up at may kasama siyang pasyente sa iisang hospital bed, hindi mo talaga maiiwasang hindi magalit sa gobyerno. ang hirap talaga maging mahirap. at mas nakakalungkot na alam nating nangyayari talaga ito sa reyalidad, at nasasaksihan ko ito mismo. sobrang fucked up ng healthcare system sa bansang ito.putangina rin ng isang doktor na nagpu-push ng paniniwala niya sa isang pasyente. hindi ka ba nag-aral ng fundamentals of caring? na dapat irespeto natin ang kung ano mang paniniwala ng pasyente. napaka-hipokrita. talking about how God is forgiving, tapos ikaw ngayon ang aaktong parang tagapaghatol ni sunshine?nakakalungkot na kailangan pang itago ang abortion. na para bang napakabigat na kasalanan kung malaman na ginawa mo ito, o sinusuportahan mo ito. wala ngayong choice ang mga kababaihan kundi gumawa ng mga methods na hindi naman nila sure kung safe, at maaari pa nilang ikamatay, all because of a belief that abortion is murder. sana maging progressive na ang bansa natin sa usaping ito :(grabe!!! walang tapon. lahat ng character, ang gagaling. lalo na si miss jennica garcia. HANDS DOWN TALAGA. putangina rin ng mga lalaki sa pelikulang ito, ang kakapal ng mukha niyo!!!sobrang hanga ako sa 'yo, sunshine. you stood up for yourself. pinili mo kung ano ang tama para sa sarili mo, kahit gaano pa kalaki ang pressure ng lipunan sa 'yo. gets na gets kita.
loved how they nailed at humanizing teen pregnancy, and abortion in general. i hope this can serve as one of the eye-openers for conservative filipinos

gets ko na üí´idc this movie is made for filipinos !!! so tired of philippines pretending to be a conservative country when the system itself can't even be fixed. i really hope marami nang nakaintindi ü•π this film shows the lens of a woman who wants to pursue her own dreams and passion ‚Äî not just raising a child with an emotionally unavailable father and who is still "too young", still has more to experience in life. what about the mother?i feel this movie so deeply because i know what it feels like to be a child of teenage parents; i know how mama struggled in trying to finish college while barely making ends meet, even commuting from fairview/marikina to pup amidst pregnancy ü•≤ she tried to continue even though others looked down on her and every insult pained her. so i love love seeing sunshine happy with her own decision, because she only needs vaidation from herself and that's it.i also liked annika's role, thought it was her alter ego/child self at first but i think she was her child, basing on how ariana disappeared when the girl (rhed) aborted her baby? she really helped in cheering sunshine & making sure she won't be guilty no matter what happens ‚Äî after all, pangarap din niya ang pangarap ni sunshine ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π tbf, kung nagsasalita rin naman mga fetus sa loob ng tiyan, magegets din naman talaga nila !!!!!!! eme lang naman ng mga conservatives na nasasaktan sila sa iniisip at gagawin ng nanay lul, mas masaya nga sana kung in-abort nalang aque edi sana mayaman na c mama tas di nya na-experience lahat ng paghihirap üôèughfhdhf ano pa ba, basta it shows din the other reasons why abortion should be accepted, especially the teenage girl's situation ü•πü•π kahit yon nalang sana intindihin ng mga close minded, simple empathy lang ... tas maganda rin yung scene nina piolo, how others think raising a child is okay basta may financial support naman, like is it really just only about money?i also love the small detail doon sa jeep na sinakyan ni sunshine, "Gift of God" nakalagay HAHAJAHAHAoverall, i love the film üíõ i love sunshine and her impulsive, yet needed decisions ‚òÄÔ∏è

HUHUHUHU ILY SUNSHINE

It took me two weeks to form a comprehensible review after watching such a heavy, gut-wrenching film. Sunshine captures only a fraction of the horrors women endure in society. In a patriarchal, religious, conservative country, you are forced to abide by suffocating norms. Women are expected to embody impossible resilience while being treated with astonishing disregard. Pair that with a failing healthcare system and an absence of political accountability, and you‚Äôre essentially set up for downfall.

sa sobrang effective ni maris, all throughout the film nakahawak ako sa tiyan ko na di makahinga as if buntis din ako na nangangarap mag-olympicspero seryoso, ang perfect ng film na to, gets ba? ang daming bagay na pwede pag-usapan, pero yung pinakanagustuhan ko ay yung representation sa kababaihan. naipakita talaga yung struggle maging babae sa ganitong klaseng society na meron tayo sa Pilipinas. naipakita pa yung iba't ibang klase ng paghihirap gamit yung variety ng female characters. tulad ni thea, na nahihirapan maging mabuting kaibigan dahil sa negatibong pagtingin ng lipunan sa mga babaeng tulad ni Sunshine. sa karakter din ni geleen, na gustong maging mabuting kapatid pero ang kaya lang na paraan ay maging supportive dahil salat din naman sila sa pera. yung character ng batang buntis (yung mas bata kay sunshine), na sobrang saklap pero realidad talaga ng ibang bata, 13 years old pa lang siya? tangina talaga ng mga bobot sa mundo alm ko don't say bad words pero napakagago talaga ng mga ganung tao sana mamatay sila. at syempre yung character ni sunshine, na ipinakita kung gaano kahirap mangarap at gumusto bilang babae. hindi lang pangarap eh, pati yung paghihirap na i-claim yung sariling katawan. na parang sa bawat desisyon niyang gagawin, expected sa kanya na iconsider ang lahat maliban sa sarili. sobrang pinagdadamot talaga ng mundo sa mga kababaihan ang karapatang pumili, bakit kaya? basta sobrang nakakatouch at nakakabahala at nakakawarm at nakakamulat ng mata ang film na to. sobrang dami niyang bagay, at kung hindi mo pa rin naiintindihan, bakit?

nakakagalit. yan lang ang salitang makakapaglarawan ng nararamdaman ko nung pinanood ko ‚Äòto. nakakagalit na maraming kababaihan sa bansa natin ang naghihirap at nagtitiis sa illegal na alternatives dahil walang ginagawa ang gobyerno para ayusin ang sistema; sistemang bulok na puno ng anomalya. kaya tayo nasa cycle of poverty kasi walang ginagawa ang mga nakaupo para baguhin ang sistemang dapat nagbibigay ng karapatan sa mga kababaihan na magkaroon ng safe reproductive health care at safe abortion. nakakalungkot na lahat ng ipinakita sa pelikulang ito ay bunga ng sistema ng gobyerno ng pilipinas. really applauding the writers, director, and production for making this film, it‚Äôs what we need, especially in a country where conservative catholic ideologies are still being followed and reinforced by the state. these disturbing truths are what the government and other filipinos should open their eyes to. yes it‚Äôs real, nangyayari ito sa totoong buhay & it‚Äôs truly upsetting. ok brb lemme wipe my tears muna‚Ä¶

‚ÄúKung babae ka sa Pilipinas, minsan pakiramdam mo wala kang pag-aari‚Äîkahit mismong katawan mo.‚ÄùAntoinette Jadaone really did something here. Hindi siya takot. Hindi niya kinwento si Sunshine bilang ‚Äúbabae na nagkamali‚Äù kundi bilang babae na may katawan, may buhay, at may karapatang magdesisyon kahit ayaw ng mundo. Kung saan ang boses ng babae laging mas mahina kaysa sa bulong ng mga lalaking may kapangyarihan, Sunshine feels like an act of rebellion pero tahimik at marangal.Sunshine is unapologetically feminist. Hindi siya nage-explain, hindi siya humihingi ng sorry. Ipinapakita lang niya na ganito ang katotohanan. Ganito kahirap maging babae dito. Ganito kalakas ang loob na kailangan mo para pumili para sa sarili mo. Kaya ang sakit. Pero ang ganda. Ang daming babae sa Pilipinas na hindi man aminin pero si Sunshine yung kwento nila. She carries the weight of society‚Äôs judgment pero nandun pa rin yung tahimik na desire to choose herself. It forces the viewers to confront something many Filipinos avoid na hindi kasalanan ang magdesisyon para sa sarili mong katawan. Na hindi kabastusan ang pumili ng kinabukasan. Na hindi kababaan ang hindi magpapaalipin sa moralidad na ginawa para kontrolin ang babae.Pero sana dumating ang araw na hindi na kailangan ng tapang para lang maging babae. Hanggang dumating ‚Äôyong araw na ‚Äôyon, kailangan natin ng pelikulang tulad ng Sunshine. A film that doesn‚Äôt just illuminate‚Äîit burns, it challenges, it frees.

PEAK FILIPINO CINEMA. „Äãcharacters: typical religious boomer mindset‚Äîmatandang doctor, miggy & his father; women being fragile and taken advantage of at a young age‚Äîsunshine & menggay; women supporting women‚Äîdr. helena, ate geleen, & thea„Äãcinematography: ingay at gulo ng maynila‚Äîmga batang namamalimos wala akong pera - sungit naman!„Äãbackground music: may pang routine at may pangkanto na luh nalunod ng problema‚Äîang iyak ni ate mo‚Äîseryoso, iba na pag walang pinipiling lugar at oras ang luha e„Äãacting: walang cringe. iiyak si sunshine? ate koh ako rin!!! uungol sa sakit si sunshine??? e2,,,first day of period war with cramps and panghihina flashbacks (not exactly what she felt kasi oo teh iba ang magpalaglag pero tehhh kaming mga babae lang ang makakagets ng nakakaubos lakas na cramps kaseee putangina‚Äîmay 2 major exams in that day, no painkillers, 50 percent of final grade, no excuses, anuna??!!!) galit si sunshine? putangina sige basagin mo ang ulo ng grapist na yan!!! satisfied si sunshine dahil abot kamay niya na yung pangarap niya? sobrang saya ko dahil pinili mo ang pangarap ko‚Äîang makitang piliin mo ang pangarap mo!‚ô° my final take: as much as i hope na sana kahit ito lang sapat na‚Äîmaipanood lang sa mga taong kinain na ng lumang sistema at mabago ang nakasanayan nating pananaw dito sa pilipinas‚Äîimposible. mas may pake sila sa ideyang paghihirap na sasalubungin pa lang sa kabilang buhay kesa sa impyernong nararanasan na ngayon pa lang ng mga kababaihang pinagkaitan ng karapatan sa sariling katawan.

This honestly deserves five stars, no matter what. To the bravery of every woman in the film mula kay Sunshine hanggang kay Direc, saludo talaga.I really liked how the movie focused on Sunshine‚Äôs journey, especially the guilt even when you know you‚Äôre choosing what‚Äôs better for you. The constant hesitation, the konsensya na kahit hindi ka naman talaga attached sa Catholic beliefs, mararamdaman at mararamdaman mo pa rin kahit sabihin pa ng iba na hindi naman ‚Äòyan totoong tao pa (lowk felt validated w this one talaga as someone na nagkakaroon minsan ng contradicting opinions). It showed the cruel, harsh reality of what so many women are still experiencing, hindi lang sa Pilipinas. i also liked na hindi niya niromanticize ang ending. yes, pinili nila ang path na magbibigay sa kanila ng mas malayang future para makapagpatuloy sa mga pangarap nila, and yeah that‚Äôs a factor, but the film never made it the ‚Äúreward.‚Äù It respected the nuance of their decisions, hindi pinilit na gawing moral lesson or success story. Instead, it stayed centered on women‚Äôs choices. It lets the audience truly feel the hardship and struggle behind those decisions. Her success wasn‚Äôt what validated her, and it shouldn‚Äôt be. Even if hindi ipakita yung ‚Äúwould‚Äôve been‚Äù life, or the ‚Äúwould‚Äôve been‚Äù anak, her choice remains valid because we all have our own pacing, our own rights to our own choices in our own lives :)to a better healthcare, esp reproductive health education and to more ph films that boldly challenge toxic filipino cultural norms :<

ive been holding back watching this movie for an extreeeemely long time, so long overdue na yung review na ‚Äòto.i found myself crying at so many different points in the movie; from the start i was moved to a different level. dinamdam ko lahat ng pinagdadaanan ni sunshine. the world she is put into chock-full of side comments, disrespect, and discrimination is sadly the reality of all women in the country. we are put into that kind of position by reckless and stupid men, and somehow we‚Äôre still to blame. and when we want to put ourselves, our aspirations, our dreams before anything else, we are put down by the very women we try to seek refuge in.sunshine is a reminder that before, during, and after a child is placed into a womb, there is still a woman‚Äîa person‚Äîbehind all of that. i really do hope this film isn‚Äôt dismissed or washed away, because no matter how gory and uncomfortable the truth it seeks to spread gets, it‚Äôs still a truth worth revealing. a truth that maybe in the near future pushes our country to become better than the one portrayed in sunshine.

‚ÄúLabag yan sa batas, lalong lalo nang labag na labag yan sa batas ng Diyos. Magpasalamat ka.‚Äù‚ÄúSalamat po‚Ä¶ saan?‚ÄùIt fucking pisses me off, these religious people and their mentality about abortion. Abortion is selfcare, it‚Äôs a choice, it‚Äôs freedom. But most importantly abortion is for someone who have had an unwanted pregnancy, especially most of the times when it‚Äôs teens. Not irresponsible ones but those who‚Äôs been raped, sexually assaulted or abused, and those who are too young to understand the concept of creating a baby. Lalo na kung wala pa silang kapasidad bumuo ng pamilya dahil nga sobrang bata pa nila at nabuntis sila ng kung sino, ang worst is relative pa nila. I‚Äôm glad mulat si Sunshine sa mga ganitong bagay. This is a sensitive topic, and good for Sunshine that she decided early on that she doesn‚Äôt want to be a mother and continue that path, no matter how much some people tried to persuade her and talk about how they can support the baby even if she didn‚Äôt want to raise it or for it to be born at all. She have dreams, dreams that are bigger than her and her having a child. Mas matured pa sya mag isip kesa sa ibang matatandang nakapaligid sa kanya. And to think na mas may sense pa yung pagpapa abort nya kesa sa buhayin yung bata because for me personally I viewed it as a trap for women like her. This is not talked about enough here in our country. Abroad, yes most of the countries had legalized abortion but for some reason our country instilled that we are not ready to have this kind of law or legalization. We are so behind and our fuckass mentality most specifically the older generation‚Äôs thinking is not ready for this kind of topic. That last scene, gets kita Sunshine. Gets na gets. And I hope more women like me and you get the point of this movie. And miraculously, sana ang mga lalaki din. Women like us are bigger than just having a baby, than just being a mother. Maybe some dreamt of it, but women like us have high hopes for our future and it‚Äôs nothing to be ashamed of. Abortion is not bad when women choose themselves and prioritize their own wellbeing. Let that sink in. Papa P jumpscare din pala nagulat ako si Piolo yung tatay ni Miggy hays so gwapo pero I‚Äôm sick and tired of fathers (pastor pa sya dito ha) who act and control women to only have a child just because they are financially capable of providing for them.

"gets ko na. gets ko na." üò≠üò≠üò≠oh my goodness i dont even know where to begin.this film was raw, authentic, and so emotionally moving. i spent the last 30 minutes of this movie with blurry vision because tears wouldn't stop falling!!!!! everything that needed to be said was said. every part carried so much weight and meaning to the message of the film. nothing felt wasted, or empty, or dragged.this perfectly encapsulates what so many women in the philippines have to endure every single day. how can you ask for help when your own family, the government, and even religion become barriers instead of support? why must these things silence us???? why must they must they stop us from wanting a life that is OURS? there are just so many things wrong about the system that you can't help but be enraged for the women who feel hopeless and trappedi hope that we can finally progress as a nation. i hope that women finally get to live on their own terms. i hope that every single woman out there feels the love and support that they need and deserve.i normally struggle put my thoughts into words and would rather make a silly haha funny line to my reviews. but this film was too beautiful, heartbreaking, deep, tender, and incredibly human for me to waste my thoughts. 10/10!!!!! perfection!!!!i will be thinking about this for a while brb....

This short hit me harder than I expected. Ang simple niya, pero ang bigat ng truth underneath ‚Äî yung reality of girls growing up, navigating their bodies, their safety, their choices‚Ä¶ all while pretending everything is ‚Äúnormal.‚ÄùMaybe it‚Äôs because of my SRHR work, but the whole time I was watching, I kept thinking, ‚ÄúGod, ang dami talagang silent battles ng kababaihan.‚Äù The kind people don‚Äôt talk about unless they absolutely have to. The film captures that so well ‚Äî that mix of fear, awkwardness, and quiet resilience you only understand if you‚Äôve seen it up close.Ang galing how something so short can feel so lived-in. Walang arte, walang preachiness, just a slice of life that says, ‚ÄúThis happens. This is real.‚Äù And that‚Äôs what makes it sting a bit more.I finished it and just sat there like, ‚ÄúYeah‚Ä¶ this is exactly why SRHR work matters.‚ÄùSmall stories like this don‚Äôt feel small when you know millions of girls live them.

Drown out the noise Sunshine ‚òÄÔ∏è I really enjoyed the movie. I love how funny, raw, and relatable the script is. It helps you connect more with the film. The plot is so interesting and really hooks you to watch the movie. The whole time I was watching I was so invested. There‚Äôs so many layers to the movie and symbolism that makes you really look at the Philippines in a different lens. This movie really stresses the importance of the legalization of abortion in the Philippines and how sexed should be really promoted among the youth. Apart from that, the side plot of the young child really pulls on ur heartstrings. It‚Äôs crazy that some of the things happening in the film is a reality faced by some people. I really like how the movie is an open ending which will really make you reflect and think. I think the child that sunshine is always with is her unborn child. It was kind of hinted when she had blood all over her when sunshine was rushed in the hospital. Also sunshine performing at the end shows that she did get that abortion so she can reach her dream. Overall I really liked the film.

I believe in God, I also believe in the sayings of the bible. But, I also believe that a woman should have a freedom to decide for her own body and to pursue her own dreams, rather than to own up a boy's mistake or to follow what the society tells her to do with her own body. Here's the thing, there's been a conflict between Biology & Religion. According to biology a fetus is not considered a human until 16 weeks‚Äîwhich is why abortion is legalized in some countries, but it is only allowed if the embryo is not yet 4 months. Now here's the thing with religious people, it's been said in the commandments that "murder is a sin", they believe that fetus are considered human by the time it formed in a woman's body. Which results colliding of each and everyones belief. I believe that they just wanna follow the word of God, but bible is open with variety of interpretations as the books are full of metaphors. It's sad that it came to a point that following a word means controlling womens' body that it came to a point na tinanggalan na nila ng karapatan ang mga kababaihan. This movie was a great eye opener, and to show what most women are going through. It's just not about vocalizing abortion, it's also about vocalizing what women goes through by the hands of terrible men.

WHAT A FILM!!!! truly one of the best newly released locals i've watched for a while.Manila is a character in this film. within every scene, the city is brought to life in all its flaws and edges; you can hear the passing train in Avenida's motel, the market-market behind Quiapo church, the sellers you pass by in Recto, and the noise of vehicles mixed with the shouts of barkers in Taft as if you were actually there. it was Manila in its rawest sense. amoy na amoy pati polusyon, 'yung ihing natuyo sa kalsada, 'yung usok na buga ng mga pribadong sasakyan‚Äîit was the Manila i've come to love and hate at the same time. even upon watching the simple cutscenes of Maris walking along the streets and the hustle and bustle of the city, i realized just how much Manila's gloried failure makes up so much of our identities as Filipinos. the Quiapo scene, however, will be forever etched into my mind. a prayer is a request in hushed tones. see, there will always be a deep-rooted guilt for every Filipino: guilt for knowing what is deemed wrong yet still holding on to it anyway. guilt for the taught sinners. guilt for asking despite being undeserving. guilt for being just feet away from a dark alley filled with frightened women trying to buy black market abortion pills, speaking in small voices to avoid being snitched and arrested. guilt is embedded in the very existence of the people in a country who grew up in God's favor and the Americans' teachings.but fear will always be greater than guilt. and it's what you feel throughout the film from Sunshine, whose greatest fear is letting go of her dream; for Menggay, whose family was the first person who betrayed her; and for all the women who are going through the exact same thing, yet are forced to risk their lives due to underground procedures.what Sunshine portrays is not the twists and turns that are seen within the storyline, nor are there any secrets revealed; rather what it effectively communicates is the complete and utter isolation that young women feel in a society that continually judges them for their decisions and choices, many of which they were forced to make. the weight of cultural expectations, the heavy grip of religious beliefs through the misinterpretation of the Bible, as well as the stigma associated with women who become pregnant, all come together to create an unbearable burden that is carried by the characters in the film. hindi lang 'to tungkol sa babaeng ayaw magkaanak dahil marami pang pangarap. tungkol 'to sa lahat ng babaeng hindi handa, hindi kaya, at ayaw na.

Lantaran pinakita ng pelikula na to kung gaano kahirap maging babae sa lipunan. Anong ibig sabihin na kailangan namin mag dusa sa bagay na hindi namin ginawa mag-isa? Kailangan namin harapin ang repercussion ng tinatawag nilang motherhood? Hindi ako against sa beauty na nakikita ng karamihan sa konsepto ng motherhood pero kung titingnan sa pisikal na aspeto talo ang babae. Mag dudusa ang pisikal appearance nila habang at pagkatapos magbuntis, isama mo pa ang PTSD. Hindi lang natatapos doon, kasama rin ang aspetong pang lipunan. Aminin man o hindi, kadalasang kailangang isuko ng mga babae ang pangarap nila or career para sa konsepto ng motherhood. Nagiging kabawasan ito sa mga babae samantalang sa mga kalalakihan ito ay makakadadag sa konsepto nilang, what does it mean to be a man. Panawagan ito sa safe procedures para sa katulad ni Sunshine at Mary Grace. Our body, our choice. I don't give a damn sa mga kupal na lalaki at mga rehilyoso. Pakshet kayo

‚Äúhow can we judge people based on their decisions when we know nothing about their choices?‚Äù and women, not just in the Philippines, we don‚Äôt have that much choice.the conservatives are angered once again! this film is so timely and relevant. really showed the horror of being a woman in a conservative, third-world country. Mapapa-aral ba ako?exactly. mapapa-aral ba nila? if not, then why bother? a life of a child is indeed precious. but it is only precious if they get to live. honestly, not having access to safe and legalized abortion is a one-way ticket to poverty, high risks of women getting unsafe medications and treatments, and overall normalizing misogyny. this is why the country remains unprogressive. they run back to familiarity and hide behind religion they do not practice at all when confronted with logic and truth. longtermism? no, they perform. they play saint.

BY FAR THE BEST MOVIE I'VE EVER SEEN THIS DECEMBER. Grabe kuhang kuha ng film na to yung reality ng Teenage Pregnancy at yung mga paghihirap na nararamdam nila, ni Sunshine. Like yung feeling palang ng buntis ka pero ayaw mo at lahat ng tao pati ang gobyerno ayaw ang aborsiyon dahil "illegal" daw. Pero hindi nila nakikita yung mga napapagdaanan nila dahil sa isang pagkakamali. I LOVE how they used a character as an unborn child/conscience grabe yung simbolismo at anlaki ng impact ng character ni Annika. THIS LINE STILL HITS ME "ang pangarap ko ay kung ano ang pangarap niya" at yung simplent "naintindihan kita" where sunshine felt accepted is so heartwarming. Grabe kuhang kuha talaga nila yung totoong Manila, yung ingay pati na rin yung kalagayan ng lipunan like doon sa hospital scene at yung financial status ni Sunshine. Gustong gusto ko yung ending kasi napapaisip ka kung pina-abort ni Sunshine or hindi. Pero nung na gets ko na parang it hits me the way na naintindihan ko lalo yung meaning nung movie at ano yung gusto niyang iparating sa mga tao. NO DOUBT 5/5 FOR ME kasi it depicts a reality where not all the people realize and understand, lalo na yung mga kabataan na hindi nakakaranas ng teenage pregnancy. Grabe rin yung acting ni Maris dito na bigay niya ng hustisya yung role niya. Very natural lang talaga kasi grabe kitang kita yung emotion ni Sunshine. Saktong sakto sa Producer/Director na to basta 5/5 talaga siya immediately.

A very daring yet relevant attempt to uncover issues with female body autonomy/consent in a country that still basically gets run by patriarchal beliefs, only beautifully packaged in outdated notions of religious obedience.Time and time again, napakahirap ipatindi sa mga tao (perhaps even more so sa mga lalaki) ang konsepto ng body autonomy ng mga babae. Ang konsepto ng 'choice'. Ang karapatang pumili para sa sarili. Minsan--o madalas kung magiging totoo lang naman tayo, iyung ganitong outdated na pag-iisip ay mapapansin mo sa mga regular na pakikipag-usap. Maliit at 'fleeting' remarks, pero nandoon. May bigat. Kailangan mo lang talagang makinig. Kadalasan siguro sa mga kaibigan mong lalaki na tingin mo mabuti naman talagang tao. O kaya worse, sa ibang mga kakilala mo ring babae. You feel conflicted kung ica-call out mo ba sila at i-risk na masabihang masyado kang 'woke' o hahayaan mo nalang na ganiyan ang way ng pag-iisip na niya habang buhay. Ideally, alam mo iyung tamang gawin. Realistically, maghe-hesitate ka pa rin. Tutal, tao ka lang naman.Naipakita ng pelikula iyung struggle, even iyung kaba. Iyung pagiging high-stakes ng pangyayari. Dinala tayo ng kwento even sa inner monologue ni Shine, sa pamamagitan ng karakter na bata na palaging sumusulpot kapag napapa-isip siya. One thing is for sure, unang-una palang, alam at kita mo na kay Shine kung ano ang desisiyon niya: Ayaw niya. That's it. The only thing na nagpahirap pa sa mahirap na niyang sitwasyon ay ang kawalan ng kakayahang pumili. Therefore resorting to downright dangerous means. Nakita rin natin na lumipas man ang oras, iisa at iisa pa rin ang desisyon niya. Meaning, hindi nagbago. Kung mayroon lang sanang available at safe--recognized na way para matulungan ang mga kababaihan sa mga ganitong sitwasyon hindi ba? Naiyak ako sa ending ng pelikula. Naroon iyung catharsis ni Shine. Iyung pagbitaw niya sa 'guilt'.Ang pagpapatawad sa sarili. Ang pagpili sa sarili. Dahil ang pagiging babae ay hindi dapat isang parusa.
‚Äúayoko maging nanay‚Äù hindi ka nag iisa‚Äö sunshine‚Äö and that is a perfectly valid and respectable life decision. indeed‚Äö it is the ultimate expression of ‚Äútheir body, their choice.‚Äù

Sunshine (2024) Directed by Antoinette JadaoneRating: 10 / 10 | MasterpieceMay kakaibang katotohanan ang obrang ito na bihirang makita sa pelikulang Pilipino. Hindi ito nagsusumikap para maging isang maganda o maging patok sa takilya; sa halip, pinipili nitong maging isang mensaheng magulo, maingay, nakakainis, at hindi nakakakomportable sa ordinaryong manonood. Na tulad na lamang ng buhay ng kababaihang araw-araw na nilalamon ng patriyarka at sistemang pampolitika na matagal nang bulok ngunit nananatiling banal sa mata ng nakararami. Habang nanonood ako, hindi ko naramdaman na gusto akong aliwin ng pelikula; ramdam ko na gusto akong iharap sa katotohanang matagal nating tinatakasan. Propaganda ang tingin ng iilang sarado ang isip sa pinaka-mensahe ng pelikulang ito. At doon sila nagkakamali. Isa lamang itong salamin sa kung paanong sistematikong inaalisan ng kapangyarihan ang mga babae, lalo na ang mahihirap.Sa loob ng sistemang ito, ang reproduktibong karapatan ay hindi itinuturing na karapatan, kundi kasalanan. Tahasang pumapanig ito sa kababaihan, hindi dahil sa moralidad, kundi dahil sa realidad: may mga babaeng nabubuntis hindi dahil pinili nila, kundi dahil pinili sila ng karahasang hindi nila hiningi. At sa bansang tulad ng Pilipinas‚Äîkung saan ang simbahan ay laging mas malakas kaysa sa pagkakaroon ng sentido kumon‚Äîang buntis na biktima ay mas madaling husgahan kaysa sa irresponsableng partner o manggagahasang ama o kapamilya. Sa pelikula, hindi ginawang melodrama ang talakayan ng rape at incest; hindi ito ipinakita para lang sa shock value. Bagkus, ipinakita itong ordinaryong trauma, tila bahagi ng tahimik na kultura ng pamilyang mas pinahahalagahan ang so-called "delikadeza‚Äù kaysa sa hustisya. Mas pinahahalagahan ang pangalan kaysa kaligtasan. Hindi exaggerated ang ganitong representasyon; nakakatakot dahil alam nating totoo.Naging sentro rin sa pelikula ang kabiguan ng sistemang pangkalusugan. Hindi lamang ito inefficient; ito ay moralistic, judgmental, at nakaprograma para parusahan ang mahihirap at mahihina. Ang ospital dito ay hindi naging tahanan ng lunas, kundi naging lungga ng " pagiging moral" na kung saan ang mahihirap ay hindi tinutulungan, kundi hinuhusagan. Sino ang karapat-dapat mabuhay? Sino ang dapat magdusa para masabing matuto? Bilang manonood at kahit isang mg lalake sa bansang ito, nakakagigil ang katotohanang ang pagpunta sa ospital ay hindi palaging pagsalba sa sarili kundi pagpasok sa isang tribunal kung saan ikaw, na biktima, ang dapat magpaliwanag.At dito ko mas naranasan ang kakapalan ng pelikula sa pagrepresenta sa Maynila. Hindi ito glamorized poverty porn; hindi rin romanticized chaos. Ito ang Maynilang nakakapagod kahit tumingin ka lang: ingay ng mga lasinggero sa tabi, tunog ng tren na daraan sa tapat ng bahay mo, sermon ng mga matatanda na ‚Äúmabait ang Diyos, anak, humingi ka ng kapatawaean.‚Äù Ito ang lungsod kung saan ang relihiyon ay sobrang pinapalandakan sa bawat isa, kung saan ang pagiging babae ay isang pampublikong dominyo, at kung saan ang morality policing ay kasing regular ng traffic dito. Para sa marami, nakaka-stress panoorin; para sa iba, nakaka-Filipino. Sa akin, nakaka-trigger dahil ito ang araw-araw na karahasan na hindi natin laging tinatawag na karahasan. Nakakasakit na sa mismong kapwa babae pa nanggagaling ang mga karahasan nito laban sa kanila. Sa gitna ng lahat ng ito, si Maris Racal ang pinakanagbuhat ng pelikula. Totoo, marami na siyang napatunayan bilang artista, pero dito naging malinaw na hindi lang siya artista. Mas higit pa siya roon. Hindi niya ginawang martir o heroine ang karakter niya; inangkin niya ang pagiging imperfect, resentful, selfish kung kinakailangan ng kaniyang Sunshine. At sa kulturang pinapaboran ang babaeng martir na tahimik na lumulunok ng sakit, ang pagganap niya ay isang uri ng pag-aalsa. Hindi siya nagtatangkang humingi ng awa, pinapakita niya na kahit sobrang sakit na, sobrang nakakapagod na, kaya ito. Kaya niya. Kakayanin niya laban sa mga putanginang lalaking nagpapahirap, hindi lang sa kaniya, kundi pati sa kaniyang kapuwa. Kung may direktor na may kakayahang magbitiw ng ganitong pahayag, si Antoinette Jadaone lang iyon. Ang direksyon niya ay hindi preachy, hindi sentimental, hindi deperado para maging tawagin ng ilan na isang woke film. May talim ang mga metapora niya, pero lubog na lubog sa reyalidad. Ito ay pang-araw-araw na simbolismo ng mga babaeng kailangang lumaban ang sarili para mabuhay. Katulad ng mga tauhan ni Jennica Garcia, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, Meryll Soriano, Rhed Bustamante, at Angeli Bayani.Walang mali sa pelikula. Ito ang reyalidad. Sa kung sino ang maaapektuhan at tututol, isa na kayo sa problema. Hindi babae ang problema. Ang problema ay lipunang gumagamit at dumidikta sa kanila.‚Ä¢ Resonance / Impact: ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚Ä¢ Cinematography / Visuals: ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ‚Ä¢ Acting / Performance: ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ‚Ä¢ Direction: ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ‚Ä¢ Soundtrack / Score: ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ‚Ä¢ Plot / Storytelling: ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖFinal Rating: ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ ‚òÖ

"Drown out the noise. You're Sunshine. Olympian. Do this for yourself. Hindi para sa mga judges. Hindi para sa mga nanonood. For yourself."sobrang ganda, sakit, at importante netong pelikula. in a country kung san taboo yung abortion o teenage pregnancy dahil sa shame, moralism, at religious culture ng pinas. hindi na nila ni sugarcoat. pinakita na nila yung mga uncomfortable truths na lagi iniiwasan ng mga tao, especially with how our society treats women at gano ka sira, inaccessible, at judgmental yung healthcare system natenapakaganda ren ng cinematography. direk tonet really captures manila exactly as it is. yung ingay at gulo na pinalilibutan ni sunshine reflects how overwhelming it is to be young, lost, and carrying a burden na di mo ma sabi sa iba. lalo na yung isang motel scene. it really captures how quiet it is to be alone pero all you can hear is yung ingay ng tren sa paligid. It was so raw and sad to watch, seeing her struggling so hard to get rid of it just to make sure she can continue with her dream yung kay mary grace rin, sobrang sakit panoorin. puno ako ng lungkot at galit nun pinapanood ko siya. the fact na nangyayari talaga ito sa mga kababaihan sa pilipinas na walang safe na options, walang legal protection, at walang sistema na naniniwalang deserve nila ng proper care. sobrang nakaka galit. ansakit na di exaggerated yung scene na yon to prove a point kasi it really does happen in real life and reality is really that cruelit pains me that women in our country are pushed into dangerous, improper, and illegal methods para lang may control sila sa kanilang mga katawan. again, sa kanilang katawan, na dapat talagang sila yung may say at control dun. ansaket na kinailangan nilang harapin yung trauma, judgement, physical pain, at emotional isolation dahil di legalized at walang safe abortion sa pinas. no man, no government, no religion, and no stranger should have the right to dictate kung ano dapat gawin ng mga babae sa kanilang mga katawanang galing galing mo direk tonet for having the courage to open eyes of the filipinos, and to maris grabe ang galing mo. thank you for delivering a raw and impactful performanceat gaya ng sinabi ng character ni annika na "gets ko na," sana ma gets na ren ng iba soon

tangina (don‚Äôt say bad words! eme) ang gandahaven‚Äôt watched a pinoy film worthy of a perfect rating for a while now and direk tonet had to do something. where do i even start?beginning to end, i was just sat and hooked. i wasn‚Äôt even able to finish drinking my matcha while watching. pacing is perfect in my opinion. things became more interesting when the girl appeared. but honestly, there‚Äôs a sequence before that which i think is very clever ‚Äî when sunshine rode a jeepney, she was searching for abortion methods and there‚Äôs a warning not to get anything from quiapo and she asked the driver to drop her off ‚Äúkahit saan‚Äù and following up with ‚Äúhanggang sa dulo‚Äù or ‚Äúkung hanggang saan to‚Äù (anywhere along those lines). she was then dropped off at quiapo lmao. ff to the girl‚Äôs appearance, bruh i got goosebumps! the first encounter was so unsettling, that i got a feel of how sunshine felt as she started navigating that conundrum. i realized as well that the kid is the apparition of sunshine‚Äôs ‚Äúwould‚Äôve been‚Äù child, and that concept is nothing less than brilliant. it brings us through the agonizing dilemma of a woman bearing an unwanted pregnancy and having everything on the line. another child was introduced later on, named ariana. ariana, a gay child, appeared after sunshine‚Äôs encounter with mary grace, a 13-year old pregnant girl. ariana mysteriously disappeared when mary grace suffered miscarriage after her attempt to get an abortion from a sketchy lady. that further inferred that these child characters who came out of the blue are symbolisms of the unborn. the penultimate scene where sunshine was practicing her routine, and the girl was watching with a smile on her face, is profoundly beautiful and gut-wrenching at the same time. going a few sequences back to the part when ariana disappeared, the girl was furious at sunshine for enabling mary grace to get an abortion. but in the penultimate scene, she looked at sunshine with pride, clapped for her, and ran to her. when sunshine asked, ‚Äúnaiintindihan mo na ba?‚Äù the girl answered, ‚Äúgets ko na. gets ko na.‚Äù BRUHHHH i swear i ugly cried so much. what a way to conclude the girl‚Äôs mysterious role and sunshine‚Äôs resolution in the story‚Äôs conflict.i could go on and on about the things i liked about the movie but this review would end up as a narration and analysis of the entire thing so i‚Äôll wrap it up here.

"gets ko na"Sunshine is one of the most real and raw Filipino films I‚Äôve seen ‚Äî the kind that doesn‚Äôt dramatize pain but exposes the everyday cruelty wrapped in ‚Äòmorality.‚Äô "Mahirap maging babae, mas lalo na maging babae sa Pilipinas" where judgment comes before empathy and where religion is often used louder than compassion.It‚Äôs not the pregnancy that destroys her, it‚Äôs the world that tells her she should‚Äôve known better while offering her nothing to begin with.Credit must go to the director for trusting a story that refuses neat answers and for letting the silence and pain speak louder than any moral grandstanding. Also hands down to Maris Racal for delivering a performance so quiet, so raw and so human.

Sunshine is a film that sheds light on the harsh realities many women face‚Äîrealities that are often overlooked or silenced. It‚Äôs an eye-opening story that refuses to sugarcoat the truth; instead, it boldly exposes how flawed our system can be. I firmly stand with Sunshine‚Äîrespectfully, no one, no law, and no religion should ever dictate what a woman chooses to do with her own body.One of the most powerful moments is the ending, with her unborn child‚Äôs quiet assurance, ‚ÄúGets ko na.‚Äù That single line hits deeply. It‚Äôs a reminder that sometimes, the smallest gestures carry the heaviest weight. I‚Äôm grateful the film allowed Sunshine to choose herself.Overall, this movie touched every bit of my soul‚ÄîI had goosebumps the entire time. Sunshine isn‚Äôt just a film; it‚Äôs an experience you feel in your chest, something too deep to put into words.Shine, gets na gets kita. ü•∫

Hindi ako magaling sa pag kritiko ng mga bagay-bagay, lalo na sa mga pelikula. Pero sinusubukan ko. Ang pelikulang "Sunshine" idinirekta ni Antoinette Jadaone sobrang danas at isyu sa bansang Pilipinas. Ang ganda ng set sa manila, ang raw, rinig at ramdam mo ang init, sikip, usok, baho, at gulo. Noong tatapatin pa lang niya yung nakabuntis sa kanya itong salita agad ang pumasok sa isip kong sasabihin ng lalaki e,"Sigurado ka bang sa akin 'yan?" Ito talaga ang una mong maririnig sa isang lalaki kapag sinabi ng isang babae na "buntis ako". Walang hiyang linya 'yan imbes na pagsuporta kay Sunshine pagdududa ang ibibigay para ikaila yung responsibilidad, lalaki nga. hahahahaha, sorry kung may pagka discriminate sa parteng ito pero iyan ang reyalidad. Sunod naman yung batang si Anika, noong una hindi ko gets bakit bigla siyang susulpot at mawawala. Para sa akin para siyang inner child ni Sunshine kung susuriin yung pelikula sa bandang dulo nang tinuloy ni Sunshine na gamitin yung nabiling gamot sa Ale sa quiapo, basta fast-forward sa tricycle, makikita na yung legs ni Anika ay may dugo rin which is sign na ganon ang epekto ng nabili niyang gamot o pag abort, hindi ko ma explain pero gets na yan, at kung paano huminga si Sunshine ganoon din siya noong isinusugod na siya sa hospital. Tapos parang noong una hindi pa gets ni Anika yung mga desisyon ni Sunshine sa kagustuhang magpa abort pero yung sa huli nakita niya kung paano mahal at gusto ni Sunshine yung pangrap niya kaya I love the part na sinabi niya na "gets ko na" ika niya nga. Tapos if you think yung pagintindi ay hindi nanggaling sa iba kundi sa sarili niya diba????? So, ito na nga dahil binanggit ko na ang quiapo, gusto ko rin yung scene na matapos niyang malaman na buntis siya dumiretso agad siya sa simbahan para mag dasal. why? kasi may guilt siya part niya sana gets niyo ako, staka super religious o predominant catholic itong bansa natin, sana gets hahahaha...tapos diba yung binilhan ni Sunshine ng pangpa abort parang katabi o malapit sa simbahan parang na pinipilit ng relihiyon at batas ang mga babae sa isang krisis, ngunit ang parehong lugar din ang kanilang takbuhan para maghanap ng bawal na solusyon. Sobrang konserbatibong bansa. At sunod ulit yung pag bili niya ng illegal na pangpa abort, no choice e, walang health care sa mga katulad niyang may ganoong problem. diba? ang lala ng sistema, walang program na pwedeng lapitan right away. Kasi ano ang unang nangyayari o ginagawa ng mga tao pag ang isang babae ay buntis, ang gagawin ng ibang tao manghusga ngunit hindi naman handang magbigay ng practical na tulong. Kaya ang katuwang lang ng babae ay sino? Sarili, dignidad, at pangrap. Kaya, gets ko si Sunshine sa mga desisyon niya, it's a relief for her kung gagawin niya yung illegal. At huli, sobrang galing ni Maris Racal, hanga ako, dalang-dala niya talaga yung bigat ng karakter. Mata-mata acting at yung pag perform niya galing. Huli na talaga, gustong-gusto ko ang mura ng batang si Anika, galing! HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA

Hindi lang tungkol sa kung ano ang pinipili mo, kundi kung bakit mo kailangang pumili.The film reminds us that while we argue about what's right and wrong, may mga taong bitbit ang bigat ng mundong hindi natin kailanman mararamdaman. And those people have to make decisions that sometimes are not acceptable to norms or beliefs. But Maris Racal delivers a story of a girl na hindi humihingi ng sympathy kundi karapatan. Karapatan na mamili. Karapatan na magpatuloy. Karapatan na mangarap. For me, it's not just a simple talk tungkol sa abortion; it‚Äôs about access, fairness, and acknowledging na hindi tayo pare-pareho ng laban.We don‚Äôt have to personally want what Sunshine wants. Pero we must understand why she has to fight for it. Kung bakit may mga oportunidad na dapat bukas para sa lahat kahit na hindi natin ito kailangan. Kung hindi mo gets kung bakit may kailangang pumili, maybe you are privileged enough na hindi mo pa kailangan mamili.And that‚Äôs exactly why we must always choose compassion.

Amazing! I felt all the raw emotions and napapa-tangina ka talaga. I didn't have an opinion about Maris Racal as an actress before, granted because I have never seen any movies of hers, but wow grabe galing niya dito. I wasn't just empathizing with her because I'm a woman myself, but because Maris was believable.

It‚Äôs always ‚Äúlabag yan sa batas ng Diyos‚Äù but never ‚Äúnaiintindihan mo ba ako?‚Äù This film carefully define failures of this country. Ang ironic lang for me na kalat sa labas ng Quiapo ang bentahan ng mga gamot pampalaglag, habang ang sistema natin ay patuloy na tutol sa ganitong paraan. Goosebumps when my friends and I noticed the sign sa jeep saying ‚ÄúGift of God‚Äù, we came up with only one assumption of what that sign is trying to tell the viewers. Simply, babies are a blessing. And that‚Äôs what they‚Äôll always say whenever abortion comes up in a conversation.The symbolism of the Kid who has been following Sunshine all throughout the film. My first assumption was‚Äî she was the conscience of the latter. Obviously, lumalabas siya every time na may gagawin si Sunshine sa pagbubuntis niya. Siya ang constant reminder na lahat nang gagawin niya ay mali. Second, it was Sunshine‚Äôs younger version. Trying to tell her something. Pero bandang dulo ng film it was revealed na it was the baby. I would like to believe na malaki ang naging parte niya sa naging desisyon ni Sunshine. Because Sunshine was the happiest when she‚Äôs doing what she love. Walang karapatan ang kahit sino man sa magiging desisyon ng babae para sa katawan niya.Super dami kong pang gustong sabihin sa film na ‚Äòto kasi super pleased ako sa mga details and symbolisms. Right, decision din to watch it with my friends hahaha. Ayun lang! Maris Racal is a really really remarkable artist. And also, Direk Antoinette Jadaone always timely and relevant ng mga films. Super galing!

gets ko nakuhang-kuha ng pelikulang ‚Äòto ang puso at kaluluwa ko. it is not like typical tear-jerker indie films out there pero yung mga linyahan ng characters at yung buong mensahe ng pelikula, talagang makatotohanan at tagos kung tagos.ang sakit sa damdamin na ito talaga ang reality ng maraming kababaihan at kabataan dito sa Pilipinas at nakakapoot isipin na hanggang ngayon, wala pa rin silang sapat na proteksyon para sa ganitong sitwasyon, kaya sobrang nakakaputangina lang talaga ng mga lalaking puro sarap lang ang nasa isip pero walang puso at paninindigan, pati na rin ng gobyerno at ng mga relihiyong tumutuligsa sa sex education at safe abortion. isang malaking pakyu para sa inyong lahat! hands down din kay miss maris racal. hinding-hindi maipagkakaila na magaling talaga siyang artista. makikita mo talaga sa kanya yung passion at dedication niya sa pag-arte sa pelikulang ‚Äòto, lalo na sa part na nagsumikap talaga siyang matutuhan ang gymnastics para maisabuhay ang character ni Sunshine.anyway, ayoko nang pahabain ‚Äòto.... para sa mga Sunshine at Mary Grace, at sa lahat ng mga babaeng nakararanas ng iba pang kalupitan ng tunay na mundo, hindi kayo nag-iisa dahil kasama niyo ako sa laban niyo. hindi natin sila bati, pangit silang lahat! at para naman sa mga Miggy at Tito Bobot, pakyu! sana mabaog kayong lahat.

mahal na mahal kita Sunshine!!! bigla kong na-gets yung sinabi ng mama ko na tumatak talaga sa‚Äôkin. she once told me, during a fight, na sana hindi niya na lang ako binuhay. i know it‚Äôs an inappropriate thing to say to your child, pero now i kinda understand where it came from.hindi ko siya kayang i-hate. alam ko na she was once a ‚ÄúSunshine‚Äù too na punong-puno ng pangarap, at nawala ang lahat ng ‚Äôyon nung nabuntis siya sa‚Äôkin. maybe we can use the quote ‚Äúrejection is redirection,‚Äù pero masakit isipin na she could‚Äôve done better. i can‚Äôt blame her for having the what-ifs of her past. hindi niya kasalanan na she grew up in a conservative, religious country. systemic talaga ang lahat. alam ko na mahal na mahala ako ng nanay ko pero hindi ko rin siya masisi kung may regret pa rin siya about the dreams she never got to chase.this movie helped me understand her side a bit more, and somehow, it helped me forgive her for saying that thing.sana maging legal na ang abortion sa Pilipinas. at sana mas maraming kababaihan ang maging katulad ni Sunshine na patuloy na pipiliin ang sarili at pangarap.

This movie unveiled how every unexpected pregnancy burdens solely the women. The men who always attempt to get away with their responsibility after learning the byproduct of their act. More significantly, the relevance of the depiction of the child on how the story and the plot progresses gives an emphasis on the acceptance of the sentiment of not wanting to conceive a child. How Maris' character dedicated most of her life doing something she loves: gymnastics, which can be taken away from considering her pregnancy--- she literally did everything and sacrificed everything to reach her dreams. The movie has conveyed the weight of abortion and how motherhood is a choice which is not tailored for all women.

this movie was heavy to watch. it showed how poor our public health system is in the philippines, especially for women. we see abortion as a sin rather than healthcare. we label it as an ‚Äúeasy way out‚Äù without considering the many factors that may lead a woman to choose not to continue her pregnancy. we forget that not all pregnancies are the result of consensual sex. what about those who were raped? those who didn‚Äôt want to get pregnant but were forced by their partner?abortion isn‚Äôt about killing a life; it‚Äôs about saving two lives‚Äîthe unwanted child‚Äôs life and the mother‚Äôs life.another sad reality shown in this movie was the condition of our public hospitals, once again highlighting our broken healthcare system. how is it that the department of health has a budget worth billions of pesos, yet filipinos are still crammed into overcrowded rooms because there aren‚Äôt enough facilities? billions in funding, yet doctors and nurses remain overworked and underpaid. billions in funding, yet patients are still forced to pay in public government hospitals.tangina. i hope filipinos watch this movie and finally wake up to how corruption is ruining everyone‚Äôs lives. everything is political. hold the government accountable!

‚ÄúNaiintindihan mo bako?‚Äù‚ÄúGets ko na.‚ÄùGets ko na/naiintindihan ko are the words na lagi kong sinasabi sa mama ko but in so many different situations, the child and sunshine‚Äôs similarity to us is that, laging nabibring up sa usapan naming mag-ina yung mga what ifs ko for her as her daughter, what she could‚Äôve been if she chose herself years ago. Hindi ko naiintindihan, are the words na lagi kong sagot kada ang response niya sakin ay ‚Äúkasi ikaw ang buhay ko‚Äù, kasi ang kapalit nun sakin ay yung mga responsibilidad na maging mas matalino, mas magaling, na hindi option ang pumalpak, especially when it comes to decisions.Sabi ko, hindi ko naiintindihan kasi sayang. Lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, lahat ng mga narating ko ngayon, dapat siya na yun, o mas higit pa kung nilakasan niya lang loob niya. Ika nga, in this world we can‚Äôt always get all that we want, kaya sa kabila ng bawa‚Äôt hindi ko maintindihan, siya ring may katapat na naiintindihan ko. Gets ko na, hindi pala na sayang, dahil siya din naman ang lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, dahil dun palang sa pinili niya ako para maging anak niya, kahit pa na may kapalit iyong mga responsibilidad hindi lang para sakin kundi para din sa kaniya, dun palang sa araw na yun, isang matapang na pagpasya din ang ginawa niya para piliin na kaming dalawa ang magkakampi sa bawat laban na haharapin namin. Gets ko na, na hindi lang sakin to mahirap, na masyado ring mahirap itong mundong ito para sa kaniya, kaya‚Äôt ano pa‚Äôt para dumagdag pa ako sa mga kalaban niya.I feel like most daughters shares this same sentiments and dreams for their mothers of wanting them to choose themselves even if it means not having the chance to be born in this world, and that‚Äôs what makes me love this movie. It comforted me to have the perception of making that dream come true for my own mom. It showed the depth of the understanding between the mother and their child especially their daughters. Just when we thought it‚Äôs already deep, it could get more deeper.Gets ko na. Sabi ng anak ni sunshine sa kaniya, whom I still and highly believe na kakampi niya (bukod sa ate niya) on every step of her way dahil lahat ng pangarap na meron sila, lahat ng bawat sumunod na tagumpay ay para padin sa kanilang dalawa.

Sunshine (2024) looks soft, warm, almost gentle on the surface. the colors cradle you, the scenes feel tender, and at first, you think it is comforting. but beneath all of that warmth carries a weight that is impossible to ignore. it is about abortion in the Philippines, where it is illegal, and labeled as ‚Äúblasphemous,‚Äù ‚Äúdisgraceful,‚Äù and judged above the lives it affects. the film does not shy away from showing how cruel reality can be. people, even doctors, prioritize morality over humanity, ignoring the pain, the fear, and the uncertainty of the woman at the center. it shows a woman whose future and potential clash with society‚Äôs judgment.the unknown girl who follows Sunshine feels like a younger version of herself. she is the part of Sunshine that believes abortion is wrong, the part that cannot yet grasp the weight of a life lived on someone else‚Äôs terms. and yet, by the end, she mutters, ‚Äúgets ko na.‚Äù she sees that Sunshine‚Äôs life is not a simple question of right and wrong. she feels the burden Sunshine carries, the life she cannot give without losing herself. she recognizes how much was left for Sunshine to live, how much potential to burn bright, and how pregnancy would have dimmed it. she senses the life that should have belonged to Sunshine alone.the realization does not absolve, it recognizes the choices forced upon someone who should have been free to live her life on her own terms. that recognition shatters you more than any argument, any moral lesson ever could.watching this film, you feel everything at once. the warmth of the colors, the softness of the scenes, the love in small gestures, and then the ache, the rage, the grief that lingers because the world can be cruel, unfair, unfeeling. Sunshine is about life that is too heavy for the judgment of others. it is about the potential snuffed out when morality is chosen over empathy. it is about understanding, even when the world cannot. it is gentle, devastating, and necessary. it will stay with you long after the credits roll.Sunshine is soft to watch, hard to forget, and brutally honest about the ways society fails those who need understanding the most.it will make you feel what it is to live, to choose, to survive, and to understand when understanding is all that remains.

This movie really captured the whole idea of ‚Äúwhat if my parents chased their dreams instead of having me?‚Äù The film shows how teenage pregnancy and child sexual abuse really happen not just because of irresponsible boyfriends who don‚Äôt use protection, but also because it can come from anyone and i mean ANYONE. your own dad, uncle, cousin, friend, or partner.Its eye-opening how teen pregnancy has become so normalized in the phillipines of ages 13 to 18. And to my mom who had dreams too, until she found out she was pregnant with me, she was torn a real 50/50 on whether to keep me or not. She chose to keep me and eventually married my dad.Sometimes I can‚Äôt help wondering what her life could‚Äôve been if she pursued her own dreams. Sobrang pulido. Sobrang raw. Sobrang ‚Äúay oo, ganito talaga buhay ng babae‚Äîlalo na kung babae ka sa Pinas.‚ÄùSa wakas, may pelikulang hindi takot maging totoo. At bilang bansa na predominantly Catholic (sigh), alam mo na agad na taboo ‚Äôto. Ang hirap maging pro-choice sa isang lugar na agad kang hinuhusgahan bago ka pa marinig.Kaya huge deal talaga na may pelikulang gaya nito na nag-oopen ng usapan. At pinaka-tumatatak sa akin ‚Äôyung paalala na ang babae‚Ä¶ tao. Hindi lang ‚Äúmay dinadala.‚Äù Hindi lang vessel. Tao.Na may nararamdaman, may konsensya.Na may sariling isip at puso.Na may takot at pangarap.At hindi biro ‚Äôyung bigat ng bawat desisyong kailangan niyang pasanin mag-isa.Tapos Manila as the backdrop??? YES.Hindi siya ginawang poster aesthetic! Totoong Maynila talaga: mainit, masikip, magulo, pero buhay. Like literal na buhay. Mga mukha ng taong araw-araw lumalaban sa sistema na hindi naman talaga pumapanig sa kanila.And the film doesn‚Äôt say ‚ÄúMaawa ka.‚Äù Hindi.Ang sinasabi niya is: ‚ÄúMakinig ka naman kahit minsan.‚ÄùKaya oo.Isang malaking oo.Gets ko na, Sunshine.(At medyo hindi ko kinaya emotionally kasi DAMI KO PANG NASASABI pero grabe, kudos talaga!)

Sunshine is one of those rare Filipino films that refuses to look away. Instead of sugarcoating or romanticizing the world its characters inhabit, it confronts the audience with the uncomfortable truths we collectively sidestep‚Äîthe toxic mindsets we inherit, the social issues we normalize, and the moral rigidity we mistake for virtue.What makes the film remarkable is its honesty. It acknowledges how deeply ingrained complacency is in our culture, how we often witness injustice, misogyny, or dysfunction and simply shrug, labeling it as ‚Äúganun talaga.‚Äù Sunshine exposes that mentality for what it is: a quiet violence that enables suffering. The film does not preach; it simply presents the weight of these realities with clarity and emotional intelligence, letting the audience feel the consequences of silence and inaction.Its commentary on anti-abortion attitudes is especially bold for Philippine cinema. Rather than reducing the debate to dogma or melodrama, the film shows how anti-abortion rhetoric becomes a peril for women; not just physically, but emotionally, socially, and economically. It reveals how denying reproductive autonomy restricts their futures, limits their ambitions, and punishes them for choices men are rarely held accountable for. Sunshine portrays this with nuance: the internal conflict, the fear of judgment, the systemic lack of support, and the complete absence of safe options. The film understands that this isn‚Äôt just a ‚Äúmoral issue‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs a structural one, tied to poverty, misogyny, and societal expectations about what women owe to the world.Ultimately, Sunshine is more than a movie; it‚Äôs a critique of the culture that raised us. It forces us to ask why we maintain harmful traditions, why morality is weaponized against women, and why we accept inequality as a norm. Its power lies in its refusal to let the audience remain comfortable, and in reminding us that the first step toward progress is learning to confront what we‚Äôve been taught to ignore.

Films like this make me realize how great the potential of the PH film industry is when it comes to storytelling, creativity, and taking risks. Sunshine proves exactly that. Ang tapang ng pelikulang ‚Äòto, not just in the execution, but sa choice of subject matter. Makamasa, madaling kapitan, and at the same time, a real eye-opener. From start to finish, ramdam mo yung puso at bigat ng kuwento, and yet ang linis ng pagkakadala.Maris Racal shines in a way that‚Äôs both raw and controlled; she gives a performance that stays with you long after the credits roll. Jennica Garcia is equally powerful, grabe yung presence niya, every scene hits (we all need a family member like her!!). Together, they carry the emotional core of the film so well na hindi mo mapigilang maapektuhan like ALL I CAN SAY IS I REALLY LOVE WOMEN SM.But above all, very important yung conversation na binubuksan ng Sunshine. Abortion is a difficult, nuanced topic‚Äîone that should be openly discussed not just within families, but within our society and government. And I firmly believe na choosing yourself first, your success, your safety, your future matters just as much. AND, women should be able to decide for themselves: their body, their rules. This isn't a simple issue, and the film treats it with the depth and humanity it deserves.Sunshine is indeed a courageous and a necessary film that everyone should watch!!

this is what the filipino people need to see more often. it might be obscure for some, but it is timely and important. teenage mothers are often judged for carrying a child; whether they keep it or not, judgement will still eye on them. the guilt of their conscience will still haunt and hunt them. but we never get to see their point of view, we only see them for the mistakes they have done. where is that energy when it comes to boys who choose to abandon the outcome of their bad decisions? nowhere. i love how this film doesn‚Äôt just show us the story of a teenage girl who got pregnant while chasing her dreams‚Äîit is a story of all the girls and women who are forced to carry a baggage they never asked for. we saw their hardships and struggles. it also shows us how flawed our system is and how hypocritical some religious people are. this should be a wake up call. the little girl (annika) doesn‚Äôt just represent sunshine‚Äôs unborn child‚Äîshe also represents us. we only see abortion and choosing oneself as something wrong and sinful because we are too blinded by what was merely taught to us. we never get to see or feel what others feel. and once we do, we will understand them. that is when we will realize. let‚Äôs be more like the little girl, let‚Äôs try to understand more.i also love that they chose manila as the setting of this film. it might not be important but i think it is. manila is messy, scary, and it will kill you. but once you overcome it, you‚Äôll see its beauty.lastly, sorry pero super bothered talaga ko sa part na nasa lope de vega na sila tapos ang layo pa ng hospital na pinuntahan nila e mas malapit naman ang metro, san lazaro, or jose reyes. üòûüôèüèº bothered lang ako pero gets ko naman kung bakit, so wala na lang yon, di siya mahalaga. hahaha

Gets na gets kita, Sunshine. Nakakapanlumong isipin na bilang isang babae, ultimo katawan mo, hindi mo masasabing may full autonomy ka to do whatever you want with it and with your life. Kapag naman gusto mong kumawala sa idinidikta sayo ng relihiyon at ng konserbatibo nating lipunan, parang hindi tama na hindi ka kainin ng konsensya mo; dapat pa yatang lumuhod ka sa harapan nila kahit para sa ikabubuti mo naman ang magiging desisyon mo‚Äîparang mali pa sa mata nila na unahin mo ang sarili mo. Kailanman ay hindi magiging pro-women ang kahit anumang sistema dito sa Pilipinas kung patuloy na babahiran ng relihiyon ang mga batas na ipinapatupad. Dahil dito, imbes na bumuo tayo ng isang lipunan kung saan walang babae ang kinakailangang dumaan sa butas ng karayom para magkaroon ng access sa isang serbisyo na DAPAT ay parte ng healthcare system natin, we continue to condition women into shaming themselves. Walang Sunshine, o kahit sinumang babae, ang dapat na isakripisyo ang kanyang mga pangarap.

‚ÄúGets ko.‚ÄùThis is the first time na medyo mag-essay ako here because just‚Ä¶ wow. Usually, when I watch films, madaldal ako with side comments here and there. Pero habang nanonood ako ng Sunshine, tahimik lang ako. Walang imik. Kasi it didn‚Äôt feel like I was watching a script come to life, it felt like I was actually watching Sunshine. Not Sunshine as the protagonist of a movie or a character that Maris plays, but Sunshine as a real person‚Äîher, as someone like me. A young girl struggling with the kind of belief system that we have in our country. Bilang babae, nakakatakot na malagay sa sitwasyon na mapapahamak lahat ng pinaghirapan mo, lahat ng pinagtrabahuhan mo buong buhay mo, lahat ng mga pangarap mo. Lahat tayo may karapatan mamili ng kapalaran natin. Kaya gets ko, Sunshine. Gets na gets ko. Hindi dapat tayo inihahalintulad sa demonyo o pinipilit na humingi ng kapatawaran sa kahit sino dahil lang gumawa tayo ng isang desisyon na para sa sarili natin. Hindi para sa pamilya o sa kaibigan, para sa atin.Would I say na the Philippines is ready for these kinds of films? I don‚Äôt know, pero parati akong naniniwala na hindi kailangang maging handa ang isang tao o bagay sa lahat ng oras. I think a more important question is: do we need these kinds of films? Then my answer would be yes. We do.

Women in the Philippines continue to grapple with deeply rooted issues such as teenage pregnancy which is made even more complex by the country‚Äôs predominantly Catholic identity. The moral codes and expectations instilled in us from childhood often determine whether society views abortion as a sinful act or a necessary choice, and this cultural tension becomes the silent force shaping many young women‚Äôs lives.In the film, Maris Racal embodies this struggle with striking emotional clarity. She carries the weight of a decision that no young woman should have to make alone: the impossible choice between holding on to her dream of becoming an Olympian or confronting the life-altering reality of an unexpected pregnancy. Her performance is powerful not because it dramatizes the dilemma, but because it mirrors the experiences of countless Filipinas whose voices are often dismissed or shamed into silence.What elevates the film is how it frames her situation not as a moral failure, but as a human story: one shaped by fear, hope, societal pressure, and the search for agency. Through Racal‚Äôs nuanced portrayal, the narrative exposes the cultural contradictions we live with: a society that celebrates the achievements of young women yet imposes rigid expectations on their bodies and choices. The film invites the audience to move beyond judgment and recognize the quiet courage required to stand at the crossroads of identity, aspiration, and responsibility.In grounding a personal crisis within the broader context of Philippine social norms, the film becomes more than a character study; it becomes a commentary on how we, as a society, often fail to extend empathy to young women navigating impossible circumstances. And in that sense, Maris does not just act the role; she embodies a truth many are too uncomfortable to confront.

ABORTION IS KILLING!! THEN JERK OFF AND DON'T FUCK WOMEN!!What makes Sunshine haunt me is how real it feels ‚Äî not just as a story of a gymnast‚Äôs dream, but as a raw, painful portrait of what it means to be young, afraid, and fighting when everything seems stacked against you. The moment the truth sinks in ‚Äî that this girl, brimming with hope and ambition, is now carrying a life she never asked for ‚Äî the world she built starts cracking. Maris Racal gives a performance that doesn‚Äôt feel like acting ‚Äî even when she‚Äôs silent, you feel every tremor of fear, every doubt, every moment she prays for a different ending. The film doesn‚Äôt paint shades of grey ‚Äî it throws you into a world where choices are dangerous, and every door seems closed.And the way the city closes in around her ‚Äî tight alleys, cold clinics, judgmental stares, desperation disguised as quiet ‚Äî Sunshine doesn‚Äôt just tell a story. It burrows underneath your skin and refuses to leave. This film isn‚Äôt easy or comfortable, but it‚Äôs needed ‚Äî for the stories it refuses to sanitize, for the voices it pulls from the shadows, and for the courage it asks from us to look. If you think you know pain, you might not until you watch Sunshine.

"naiintindihan mo ba ko?"ang gagago ng mga lalaki. ang kakapal ng mukha na magdecide para sa hirap na haharapin nating mga babae para sa pagbubuntis. 'alam mo na gagawin' pag hindi ready maging tatay, 'ako na bahala sa expenses' pag ready. na para bang sila ung magbubuntis sa baby kung maka desisyon? men are stereotypical viewed as the stronger ones, and yet women carry the most pain in life. our law, our society, our healthcare system, our religion, and sometimes even we ourselves are against us in claiming our own rights. mahirap bang intindihin na hindi sa lahat ng kaso ng abortion ay lagi lng sa pagiging ignorante para sa sex, pero sa pagiging ignorante ng mga lalaking hindi nagpull out gaya ni miggy, ng mga lalaking kating kati ang tite na pati mga bata dinadamay nila gaya nalang ng gagong tito ni mary grace, at pinaka importante sa lahat para rin sa mga kawawang babaeng nabiktima ng ganitong klase ng mga lalaki gaya ni sunshine at mary grace. i really cried during this whole movie. the way only women‚Äîstrangers or not, understood sunshine, understood the women who chose the same decision. like sunshine's ate, i support her, i support these women who remain so strong despite every part of society looking down on them. naiintindihan ko sila.
