I love this film. It captures so honestly how hard it is to get an abortion in an anti-abortion country ‚Äî the judgment, the lack of empathy, and the reality of how poor our healthcare system is.Salute to the director for making a film like this. Maris Racal was incredible as Sunshine. And the way Annika and Ariana‚Äôs characters were written ‚Äî symbolic and intentional ‚Äî made everything hit even harder.

Finally had a chance to watch this, i was meant to watch this when it was showing at the cinemas but so busy until recently saw news that it was gonna come out on Netflix so i was elated. Haha.I like it so much, i love the cast in this film, and i love seeing this kind of quality in Filipino movies which is super rare these days. The story is about a young woman who has a dream that she pursued her whole life and suddenly she becomes pregnant which risks this dream, and now she has to weigh everything carefully because either which choice she pick will be life-changing. The whole movie revolves around that and we get to be introduced to the characters and the environment around her that is essential and will influence the choice she will make. Here we get to see a real picture even though the story is fictional, as filipinos you could almost grasp the realness out of this film and say, this is the REALITY but we don't have to embrace it, WE HAVE TO CHANGE IT. As a man, I always believed that i am no position to speak about what women should and shouldn't do about their bodies, but will absolutely support the concept of abortion. When we speak about abortion in a country that is like the Philippines, that is so centered on religion, abortion becomes a taboo, illegal and unethical. We also see these professionals, government leaders that support this kind of ideology that abortion is bad blah blah blah. This film is a great commentary and an eye opener to what young women and women in general what they go through, and that abortion should become an option for all women in our society. I will just make it clear that i think this film is not pro abortion or anti life, without directly stating it, the film focuses on making better decisions, the importance of protection, sex is more common than we think which is ironic in the Philippines that is so religious but that‚Äôs ok, this country just needs proper education and thats it. PS. If you are going to argue with me about me being ok about abortion or use of protection, I‚Äôm going to tell you this, how dare you bring a life in this world, in this country that cant do anything about poverty, cant do anything about corrupt politicians, cant vote right, doesn't have an accessible healthcare and on top of that, if you‚Äôre a man, stfu, and if you‚Äôre a woman, who is not ready, physically, mentally and financially, Ari and that young girl doesn‚Äôt deserve to live like that, on the streets or getting abused. But if you are, financially stable, mentally stable and physically stable with a nice and healthy environment to grow a living thing then go fucking crazy.

ang hirap maging babae parang pasan mo ang mundo.ilang minuto pa lang sa pelikula, ramdam mo na kaagad, pinakita na ni direk tonet. una, yung kawalan ng akses sa impormasyong pangkalusugan. karamihan ng babae, katulad ni sunshine, umaasa lang sa sabi-sabi. libo-libong babae ang kumakapit sa peligro ng pagpapalaglag: ilegal na gamot, hilot, o pribadong clinic.pangalawa, babae rin ang makatutulong sa kapwa babae ngunit babae rin ang pwedeng magtulak sayo sa kapahamakan. parehong biktima at minsan instrumento ng isang macho-pyudal na lipunan. maraming eksena ang nagpapakita ng pagtutulungan: si aling nagtitinda ng pampalaglag, buena mano kahit gabi na, may tawad pa dahil alam niyang gipit ka. si ate sa motel, kahit anong sungit, kukuha pa rin ng tulong dahil duguan ka. pero sa kabila ng tulong, nariyan ang mga babaeng nakakulong pa rin sa lumang paniniwala: si doktorang victim-blamer at relihiyosa, yung nanay na nagpapadala sa lalaki niyang kapatid kapalit ng kaligtasan ng kanyang babaeng anak. sa lipunang matagal nang pinagsasamantalahan ang kababaihan, nakakalungkot isipin na nasanay na tayo sa ganitong galaw.maganda ang sunshine, pero higit pa doon, kailangan itong mapanood ng bawat babae‚Äîbata man, teenager, o nakatatanda. dito pa lang makikita na may kailangang baguhin sa sistema; hindi tayo dapat masanay sa ganitong kalagayan.sunshine, pangalan mo pa lang, alam mong isa itong pelikula na magpapaalala na lilipas din ang pagpasan ng mundo. para sa lahat ng babae, sabi nga ni sunshine, "laban lang tayo. kapit lang tayo." sa dulo, malinaw ang mensahe: hindi babae ang dapat magbago, kundi ang sistemang matagal nang mali ang takbo.

Ang hirap maging babaeng puno ng pangarap. The film Sunshine (2024) resonated with me because it honestly depicts how unforgiving reality can be. It shows how quickly people judge young women, often before they even have a chance to breathe or ask for help. The film also makes painfully clear how the lack of reproductive rights pushes women toward risky, sometimes dangerous choices. You can almost feel Sunshine being boxed in on all sides, not because she did anything wrong, but because society refuses to give her real options.Women in the Philippines face judgment, limited choices, and immense pressure around pregnancy. And the film makes a point I strongly agree with: no government or religious institution should dictate what a woman does with her body. Those decisions belong to the person living that reality, not to people watching from a distance.Sunshine made the right choice. Sobrang taboo sa Pilipinas ang usapang abortion, pero at least the child didn‚Äôt grow up feeling guilty or resenting their mother for what might have happened if they hadn‚Äôt been born. It‚Äôs better for a child to know they were truly wanted, rather than feeling like the product of someone else‚Äôs dilemma. Constantly being told they‚Äôre a blessing can‚Äôt replace the sense of being genuinely chosen.Sana ma-gets ng lahat si Sunshine.

gets na kita... gets na kita...admittedly, heading into this, i didn't know what to expect. i didn't know how sunshine's story of seeking out abortion could extend to 1 hr 30 mins without either being unrealistic or unnecessarily cruel. despite being titled after the main character, this movie was so much more than just about sunshine. it's a microcosm of philippine culture at its core: the traditions, values, history, and gender roles. sa totoo lang, mula lang sa pelikulang ito pwede nang himay-himayin yung kultura natin.itutuloy ko nalang to at a later date, 2:30 am na. basta ang ganda salamat antoinette jadaone salamat maris racal

gets ko na.this is why giving women the right to make a choice is so important. we live in a country where people will use god‚Äôs name and teachings in vain to justify their own selfish beliefs, but would god truly want their child to go through this pain and suffering? rhed was thirteen. 13. and yet due to this corrupted system she was forced to find help using dangerous means and almost died. sunshine on the other hand, was a rising athlete, she was about to make her breakthrough, but because her boyfriend couldn‚Äôt simply pull out, she almost lost her life long dream and had to make one of the hardest decisions of her life. if the choice was there in the first place, so many women all around the world wouldn‚Äôt have to face these depressing situations that society thrust upon them.

‚Äéang masasabi ko ay tangina, ang hirap maging babae lalo na nasa pilipinas ka pa. walang maayos na healthcare (tangina, may public hospital nga pero sobrang hirap at kailangan mo pa ng backer para lang maasikaso ka ng doctor. puta, malapit ka ng mamamatay kailangan mo pa mag hintay sa emergency bago ka nila i-check at asikasuhin.)‚Äé‚Äéwala pang maayos na suporta sa gobyeryno, hindi binibigyang atensyon ang reproductive health ng mga babae. sobrang relihiyoso, masyadong takot at kinakasuklaman ang usapin sa abortion. kung tutuusin, hindi naman dapat taboo ang abortion. abortion is women's healthcare. no man, no religious beliefs should take a woman's right to her own body. let women decide for themselves, lalo na kung nabuntis sha sa maling paraan at ayaw niyang maging isang ina.‚Äé‚ÄéPAKYU sa lahat ng lalaki (lalo na sa mga katulad ni miggy, jaime, at lalo na sa tulad ni bobot.) pakyu din sa mga overly religious na tao na sobrang taas ng tingin sa sarili. fck the patriarchy and fck the government.nakakagalit knowing this is someone's life right now. ilang babae at batang babae pa ba ang makakaranas ng ganitong hirap bago mabigyang atensyon ang karapatan sa reproductive health ng kababaihan?

SOBRA SOBRANG GANDA NG PELIKULA NI DIREK TONETsa sobrang ganda i had to watched it 2 times. hindi ko alam ma fefeel ko after kong unang panuodin ito, sobrang lungkot at bigat dahil alam kong hindi lang ito basta pelikula kundi realidad ng bawat babae, bawat tao, at bawat batang muntik makita ang mundo.i love the jeepney scene, It was a really heavy scene, I think it was me interpreting na iniisip na ni sunshine na 'bakit??, bakit saakin pa? baka hindi na ako makasama sa olympics na ito- bakit?' maybe there was this question of confusion na kahit siya hindi niya masagot.. na kahit saan siya dalhin ni kuya manong at ibaba dala dala parin niya talaga ito (yung bata)I loved how this film not only focuses on abortion rights, but also shows many of the real problems in the Philippines.Napakita talaga kung gaano ka‚Äìfucked up ang sistema ng mga hospital dito‚Äîkulang sa pasilidad, nagsisiksikan, at ang daming pwedeng mamatay dahil sa ganitong sistema. Sobrang nakakagalit isipin na sa hospital ka pa dapat may chance mabuhay, pero doon ka pa pwedeng bawian.It also shows the messed-up beliefs of people who think it‚Äôs ‚Äúeasy‚Äù to raise a child. Yung mga nagsasabing ‚Äútakot mo sa una lang ‚Äòyan‚Äù at ‚Äúbiyaya ‚Äòyan ng Panginoon.‚Äù I‚Äôm not against their beliefs‚Äîthey‚Äôre entitled to them‚Äîbut I find it toxic. Paano mo kayang sabihin sa isang tao na ‚Äúbiyaya‚Äù ito kung galing sa karumaldumal at walang kamalay-malay na kasalanan ng ibang tao? Paano mo sasabihing tanggapin niya na lang ito?I think not everything can be called a blessing. And I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs fair to say ‚Äúbinigay ito ng Diyos‚Äù kahit mali ang pinanggalingan. When I watched it for the second time, ang dami ko talagang na-notice. Naging malaking tanong sa‚Äôkin kung *paano* at *saan* narealize ni Sunshine ang lahat.At first, akala ko si Annika (yung batang babae) was her inner child someone who guides her, the version of herself who dreamed of becoming an Olympian but never got the chance.Yung part sa ilalim ng tulay, nung lumabas na si Ariana ‚Äî doon ko talaga na-connect. I think Sunshine realized it too. Habang hinahanap niya si Sunshine, hindi siya mapakali. Naging question ko rin talaga kung paano kilala ni Sunshine si Ariana if kakakita niya lang dito? Diba??!And what Ariana said made sense. May part sa movie na sinabi niya na ayaw niyang bumalik sa bahay dahil wala namang may pakialam sa kanya. sabi ni Sunshine doon ‚ÄúHindi, naguguluhan lang siya.‚Äù i think she was referring to marygrace.The conversation between Ariana and Annika (the little girl) really altered my brain.The way they pictured the life they could‚Äôve had in a world they will never get to be part of sobrang bigat..And that line, ‚ÄúPangarap ko kung anong pangarap ni Sunshine,‚Äù grabe.sobrang naiyak ako sa part ng ate niya at si sunshine, grave sobrang galing talaga ni direk tonet. tinanggap at inintindi niya ito ng buong buo mabuhay talaga ang pelikulang ito.Lastly! finally!(ang sobrang daming yap)the last part, yung ‚Äúgets ko na.‚Äù Those words explained everything.It felt like Sunshine was saying,‚ÄúI hope naiintindihan mo kung bakit ko ‚Äòto ginagawa.‚ÄùAnd i know that‚Äôs exactly how she felt.Maybe the girl can‚Äôt have the world.But no‚Äîactually, she did.Because she gave Sunshine the world she always wanted, even if she couldn‚Äôt have it herself. "Pangarap ko kung anong pangarap niya"That ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù part really hit me.Sobrang bigat. And right after that line,there was a cut showing Sunshine in this moment of relief and it says so much kahit na walang description kahit walang explanation.i love this film na gustong kong yakapin si sunshine at hawakan ang kamay niya at sabihing "hindi mo ito kasalanan"

i have a lot to say about this movie but if i were to describe it in one sentence, it would be: ang hirap maging babae, at mas mahirap maging babae sa pilipinas. i can tell that this story is well-written. it is my first time watching a filipino movie so realistic and women-focused. this movie depicted the struggles of being a woman‚Äînot just sexually, but in all aspects. women are expected to be perfect‚Äîcapable of carrying the weight, not expected to make any mistakes despite everything hateful is being thrown at us. we are expected to meet and be the standard even if it is out of our capabilities. dahil? babae tayo. at kung ‚Äòdi man natin maabot ‚Äòyon, isa tayong kahihiyan. dahil nga, mga babae tayo. kalaban natin ang relihiyon, gobyerno, at bansa na mapang-husga. ika nga ni coach, drown out the noise. but that is not the case. even if you force yourself to be apathetic, you‚Äôll still hear the the voices of the people. mga kabataan nga naman ngayon, hindi na makapag-pigilbawal ‚Äòyan sa batas ng Diyoshindi ko ma-a-admit kaibigan mo dahil illegal ‚Äòyonkung buntis ka, i‚Äôll have to kick you out of my rosteranother thing i loved about this movie is that it was shot in manila and covereed many social issues‚Äîmaking it even more relatable to us filipino. especially when it comes to poverty, dito talaga natin masasabi na mahirap maging mahirap. the film showed the reality of life for those without privilege‚Äîstruggling to find a tricycle, not having enough money for basic needs, and doing everything we can just to earn a little. even parents are driven to the point of selling their own children.some men, on the other hand, can run away from everything. nakabuntis? kasalanan pa rin natin ‚Äòyang mga babae! kesyo hindi tayo nananamit nang maayos, kesyo tayo raw ang may mali kahit sila naman ang tumakbo sa responsibilidad. here, i saw how cowardly some men can be‚Äîafraid to take responsibility for their wrongdoings, and always ready to cling to anyone who will shield them from consequences.lastly, i love how the kids represented their inner child‚Äîsunshine‚Äôs bata symbolizing her dream of becoming an olympian, while menggay‚Äôs bata represented the lgbtq community and her longing to get revenge on those who wronged her. each represented their dreams, no matter how impossible they seemed in their circumstances. each represented their dreams, clinging to whatever little piece of themselves the world hasn‚Äôt taken away.

I don't remember where I first heard of it, but the idea has always stayed with me: for every abortion, miscarriage, or infertility, if a women desires to be a mother, it will come to her at the right time‚Äîin one form or another.And I think this film beautifully echoes hints of that belief.The part where Sunshine asks the little girl, "Naiintindihan mo na ba ako?" And the child replies, "Gets ko na," feels like a simple, but so profound of an exchange of words. It feels like a hand that's gently soothing a wound she's been carrying all this time. A wound that asked to be seen with the nuances that came with it, not the fantasies the society chooses to blind themselves with.Another thing that stood out to me abt this film is how it challenges the viewers to confront the expectations forced onto women simply for existing. Not with judgement, but with a silence that understands what it means to be human.I just love that this film respects women's choices. It doesn't force a message or a narrative that motherhood is the only path to walk through once it enters in a woman's life. Instead, it says that your life, dreams, and timing are all yours regardless of what everyone thinks nor says abt it.Because to be a mother means to be ready mentally, physically, and financially. Love alone isn't enough to carry a life, just a majority of its suffering.

‚Äúgets ko na‚Äùcrying in the jeepney, walking around in quiapo, the maternity ward, the female rage. there‚Äôs something special and heartbreaking in seeing manila and its inhabitants this way, eternally cruel and chaotic‚Ä¶ sunshine encompasses the plight of every filipina, the quiet ache and exhaustion of navigating a world perpetually against her entire being: a country built on catholicism, patriarchal values and misogyny. but sunshine also captures the perseverance that every filipina were forced to cultivate, not because we are naturally stronger but because we are given no other choice in life.should be a required viewing for everyone in this country.

ive been waiting for this to come out on netflix and it is honestly such a GREAT commentary on anti-abortion laws in the philippines and in religious/third world countries as a whole. it truly is a privilege to have the right to our own bodies.the writing of this movie was quite interesting and i believe the children held so much significance to the development and the decision making of the main lead. i believe they are the make-believe consciousness of the ‚Äúthing‚Äù (lets stop calling them babies PLEASE) inside the main lead and the 13yo girl, and i LOVED being so confused and then realising this later on. ‚Äúdrown out the noise‚Äù something we need to tell ourselves more often than not. we shouldn‚Äôt listen to outside opinions of what to do with ourselves and our own bodies. it is the happiest way to live and love life.i hold this movie very close to my heart and living in a country where abortion is legal is a HUGE privilege and i look forward to the days where religious doctrine dont run the government and put its citizens in a chokehold. religious or not, DON‚ÄôT tell ANYONE what to do with their bodies, we are all in different circumstances and have wants/dreams/aspirations we‚Äôd like to pursue for our own happiness and that‚Äôs not selfish.

my best friend sent a message in the group chat saying ‚Äúguys please don‚Äôt ever get pregnant‚Äù fresh after watching this. i laughed in my mind thinking how is that even gonna happen. but here i am sobbing like a child and wishing that nobody ever gets pregnant against their will. what a demented, horrifying, and pathetic world we live in. this film plunged my heart deep into my guts from the very beginning. it‚Äôs already hard being a girl and then you have systems in place that form a fist around your throat. this was so well made that none of it looked fake. i mean it‚Äôs so funny to see the juxtaposition of the church and the ‚Äúpamparegla‚Äù vendors that are still there today. maybe it‚Äôs more sad really but that is the reality. i don‚Äôt know i guess it is so hard to explain the horrors of being a woman. men get to conveniently be selfish as part of their nature but putting yourself first as a girl needs an apology from god. men regard laws only when they can deny women any autonomy, but break them with ease for their own disgusting desires and freely laugh about it with their friends. i am so glad this film ended the way it did but i am also very sad and angry that girls who meet the same fate have to suffer maybe even worse than this. and that‚Äôs when i know god is not a woman.

Society claims to protect the ‚Äúunborn child,‚Äù yet the conversation often leaves out the women whose bodies, health, and futures are directly involved. It feels unsettling to watch how easily society dismisses the experiences of women, as if their lives become secondary the moment they become pregnant. I can‚Äôt ignore how deeply this connects to the patriarchal norms I‚Äôve grown up seeing. From subtle expectations to outright judgment, there is a long history of controlling women‚Äôs bodies and decisions. The shame placed on those who consider or seek abortion is not just personal; it is cultural and religious, embedded in systems that teach us to shame and question women‚Äôs choices instead of supporting them. This made us more aware of how easily society turns compassion into condemnation when it comes to reproductive health.P'wede ba pag walang matres, 'wag na bumoses?

it‚Äôs beautiful. it‚Äôs brave. it‚Äôs heavy. it‚Äôs painful.it‚Äôs hard to be a woman. even harder to be a woman in the philippines.one of our professors once told us that our laws are deeply embedded into our culture. that‚Äôs why there‚Äôs no abortion in the philippines‚Ä¶ because of our strong religious beliefs. if you choose abortion as your option, you‚Äôre immediately seen as a murderer, a sinner, by our legal system and, of course, by god‚Äôs law. the same religious beliefs hiding under the skirt of a patriarchal culture, doing nothing but scaring women away from their own choices.sana, ngayon, gets n‚Äôyo na. gets na ng marami.that this kind of decision has never, ever been easy.and i hope that now, we finally push for comprehensive sex education, free check-ups and contraceptives as reproductive health rights, and the legalization of abortion in the philippines, so no woman ever has to resort to unsafe methods while carrying the guilt and the danger all on her own.there are so many deep-rooted problems tied to abortion that we need to confront and tear down. only then can we truly set women free.

first of all, gusto ko rin ng isang ate geleen üò£hands down to maris' restrained but deeply affecting performance. ramdam mo 'yong bawat pag-aalinlangan at takot‚Äîevery moment where the world presses a little too hard on a young girl who only wanted to chase her dream.what makes the film even more powerful is its raw, unflinching portrayal of philippine society. the story exposes how reproductive rights in the country are entangled with religion, shame, and systemic neglect. it shows how a woman's body becomes a public issue the moment it no longer fits moral expectations, and how access to safe, affordable healthcare quickly turns into a privilege instead of a right. ultimately, sunshine champions a woman's right to her body, her choices, and her future‚Äîeven in a society that constantly takes those away.

What stayed with me long after the credits rolled is how Sunshine understands the quiet corners of being young. The ones filled with fear you don‚Äôt even have language for yet, and the hope you still hold anyway. The film doesn‚Äôt chase shock value; instead, it trusts stillness, letting the soft ache of its characters speak for themselves.And then there‚Äôs that storyline about the 13-year-old girl, pregnant because of her own uncle. OH GOD. That shattered me. It‚Äôs horrifying, devastating, and the film doesn‚Äôt sanitize the truth of it. It shows how violence like that hides inside families, how children are left carrying consequences for sins that were never theirs. I felt so much grief and anger for that kid; it‚Äôs the kind of scene that makes you sit there and go quiet because it hurts in a very real way. The film‚Äôs exploration of choice, shame, and the pressure to ‚Äúgrow up correctly‚Äù hits even harder because of moments like that. It never lectures. It simply shows how heavy it is to carry circumstances shaped by adults who should‚Äôve protected you. Maris Racal delivers an immaculate kind of devastation in this role. There‚Äôs a sharpness to every look she gives, a trembling truth in every word, that feels painfully real. She breaks open the character‚Äôs longing, lets the fear spill out raw, and turns her strength into something that rises slowly from the wreckage. It‚Äôs a performance that destroys you and stays spotless in its honesty.Sunshine is the kind of film that lingers. Soft, bruising, furious when it needs to be, and quietly bright in all the places that matter.

A challenging plot to bring to the screen and a harsh and sad reality for many women. The strong hold religion has over the Philippines is especially frustrating. The hospital scene where you would expect empathy from the doctor pissed me off. The pastor and Miggy especially bothered me ‚Äî Miggy because he‚Äôs a little shit and the pastor because his reaction reminded me of my father. Other people can get away with abortion because they have the money so they can just go freely with their lives, but for younger women like Sunshine and Ariana, it‚Äôs life or death. Ariana‚Äôs situation is especially heavy, something I‚Äôve heard about from people I know. This film is going to bother me for a while.

Ang pelikulang Sunshine ay hindi lang simpleng kwento ng isang babae‚Äîisa itong salamin sa maraming isyung matagal nang umiikot sa Pilipinas pero pilit pa ring isinasantabi. Nagawa ng pelikula ito na ilahad ang mga sakit ng sistemang kinabibilangan natin: mula sa pakikibaka ng kababaihan sa kanilang sariling katawan hanggang sa nakakalungkot na estado ng ating healthcare system.Isa sa pinakamalinaw na ipinupukol ng pelikula ay ang isyu ng aborsyon. Ipinapakita ng pelikula kung gaano kahirap ang desisyong hinaharap ng mga kababaihan‚Äîlalo na sa bansang halos bawal pag-usapan ang reproductive rights. Nakakahalit dahil hanggang ngayon, marami pa ring kababaihan ang hindi ganap na malaya sa sarili nilang katawan dahil sa malalim na kapit ng konserbatismong relihiyoso. Sa halip na suportahan, hinuhusgahan sila. Sa halip na pakinggan, pinapatahimik. At gaya ng ipinapakita sa pelikula, napipilitang harapin ng mga babae ang mga sitwasyong hindi nila pinili, wala man lang ligtas o legal na option para makaligtas..Kasunod nito, mariing binabangga ng pelikula ang realidad ng ating healthcare system. Hindi na bago ang nakikitang eksena sa ospital: siksikan, kulang sa gamit, at kapos sa espasyo. Dalawa, minsan tatlong ina sa iisang kama‚Äîhindi dahil gusto nila, kundi dahil wala talagang mapaglagyan. Ito ang reyalidad na hinaharap ng ordinaryong Pilipino araw-araw, habang ang mga pulitikong may kapangyarihan ay kayang lumipad paabroad para magpagamot sa mas kumpletong pasilidad.Sa kabuuan, nagsilbing boses ang Sunshine para sa mga isyung matagal nang dinidinig ngunit hindi pinakikinggan. Maris Racal did her best one on this. Kudos!

A very realistic movie. ang ganda ng portrayal ng stigma at discrimination na nararanasan ng mga kababaihang dumadaan sa ganitong situation sa bansa natin. At, sana buksan na ng mga Pilipino ang kanilang isipan at intindihin na ang abortion is healthcare at hindi dapat ituring na uri nang pagpaslang. Also, I appreciate how this movie shows na accessing safe abortion care from clinics is far better than relying on herbal remedies or sa mga faithhealers. And of course, this also shows the effects of our flawed healthcare system, it's inaccessible and expensive, pushing women to resort to those kinds of practices. But, It's important to remember that we have the rights to make a choice about our own bodies, but we should make those choices wisely and safely.

Sobrang tapang ng pelikulang 'to. Sobrang tapang ni direk tonet. Sobrang tapang ni Sunshine. Sobrang tapang ng mga kababaihang nagpapatuloy, lumalaban sa mga hamon ng lipunan. Dinala ako ng pelikulang 'to sa kung anong klaseng lipunan ang kailangang harapin ng mga kababaihan araw-araw ‚Äî lahat ng husga, dikta, at pangungurakot. Wala sa kahit anong batas or salita ng diyos ang makatutulong sa mga taong kagaya ni Sunshine, kung 'di ang maayos na health care system, maayos at tapat na gobyerno, at isang mapagpalayang lipunan ‚Äî malaya sa kahit anong dikta at husga ng mga taong hindi kailanma'y namroblema sa kanilang kaligtasan kapag maglalakad mag-isa sa madilim na kalsada, sa kanilang kasuotan at pananamit, sa kung anong pananaw ng iba sa kanilang katawan, sa kakayahan makapag-luwal ng anak, sa mga tingin at pagnanasa ng mga mabababang-uri, at sa mga marami pang bagay. Napakaraming aspeto ng pelikulang Sunshine ang paulit-ulit sinasampal sa atin para lang magising sa realidad ang bulok na lipunang 'to. Isa na rito ang pagbibigay sa mga kababaihan ang kalayaang mamili, kalayaang magdesisyon, at kalayaang mangarap, kasama ang proteksyon para sa mga batang katulad ni Mary Grace.Ilang kababaihan at bata pa ba ang kinakailangang maranasan ang hirap nina Sunshine at Mary Grace bago mamulat at umusad ang lipunang sakop pa rin ng makalumang pananaw ‚Äî mga pananaw na hindi nila alam ay unti-unting ginigilitan at pinapatay ang karapatan, kalayaan, at kakayahan ng mga kababaihan. Ang mga taong tulad nina Bobot, nanay ni Mary Grace, at Miggy ang tunay na lumalabag sa sa utos ng diyos, ang tunay na gumagawa ng krimen, at ang tunay sa nagpapabulok pa sa inuuod na sistema para sa mga kababaihan at bata, hindi ang mga taong tulad ni Sunshine na pinanghahawakan ang karapatan nilang mangarap at magkaroon ng desisyon para sa kanilang sariling katawan. Tangina gaano ba kahirap isipin yon?Napakaganda ng cinematography. Lahat ng baho, usok, lagkit, at sikip ng Maynila; lahat ng mga matang mapanghusga, mga taong makasarili, mga komentong nananakal, at bigat na dala-dala araw-araw ng mga babae at bata, lahat ito ipinakita. Ibang klaseng sining ang ipinakita nina direk tonet, maris, jennica, annika, at sa lahat ng cast ng pelikula.Mahigpit na yakap para sa lahat ng Sunshine na patuloy bumabangon at lumalaban. Abante, babae!

I know this movie feels heavy and complicated the first time you watch it. It‚Äôs about a girl who is struggling against the world and against herself. She loses her way, and she could lose her dreams if she doesn‚Äôt stand up to the world.From this movie, I learned one important thing in life, everyone has their own problems, different kinds of problems. But the important thing is what you choose to do when you‚Äôre going through something difficult and nobody is there to help you. Even when you feel alone, useless, or hopeless, don‚Äôt give up. You can still reach what you want and chase your dreams. Just keep going and keep fighting.As a man, I feel sorry for Sunshine, but believe me, there are many good men in this world better than selfish and stupid men and I learned from this movie how to be a better man. Use protection when you‚Äôre doing something intimate, and if you don‚Äôt, make sure you can take responsibility for your actions. Live wisely and don‚Äôt make rushed decisions. Every choice you make shapes your future. We may not regret our actions in the moment, but we regret them later.And for other men, I want to say this if you have a girlfriend, make sure she‚Äôs happy with you. Don‚Äôt be rude to her, and don‚Äôt ruin her life because of your desires. As a man, I promise myself that I'll be better. I‚Äôll treat women with respect, and I'll never raise my hand when we have problems or arguments.

kababaihan nga ba ang kanilang pinoprotektahan, o ang sariling takot na mawalan ng kontrol sa buhay ng kababaihan?sobrang ironic lang na ang simbahan at ang kanilang pananampalataya ang itinuturing na pinakamalaking hadlang sa pag-legalize ng abortion sa ating bansa. pero sa mismong labas ng kanilang pintuan, makikita mismo ang serbisyong pilit nilang ipinagbabawal. minsan katabi pa nga ng mga santong sinasamba nila.kung ganoon katibay ang kanilang pagtutol, bakit hindi nila mapigil ang realidad na nasa harap nila?dahil sa hindi pagtanggap sa aborsyon, maraming kababaihan ang napipilitang gumamit ng hindi ligtas na pamamaraan, na naglalagay sa kanila sa kapahamakan.kung ang ipinaglalaban ng kanilang moralidad ay ‚Äúproteksyon ng buhay,‚Äù bakit parang hindi kasama sa buhay na iyon ang mismong babaeng nagbubuntis? bakit ang potensyal na buhay ang pinapahalagahan, pero ang buhay na humihinga, nagdurusa, at nalalagay sa panganib ay tila pangalawa lamang‚Äîo minsan, hindi man lang isinasama sa usapan?hindi kayang resolbahin ng moral absolutism ang totoong problema. ang kababaihan ang nagbabayad ng presyo‚Äîhindi ang simbahan, hindi ang mga pulitiko, at hindi ang mga taong nagtatakda ng mga patakaran na kailanman ay hindi nila mararanasan sa sarili nilang katawan.ang karapatan sa sariling katawan ay hindi dapat ipinaglalaban sa husgado ng relihiyon o pulitika. ito ay desisyon na dapat ibalik sa taong may katawan, may buhay, at may tunay na pinansyal, emosyonal, at pisikal na pasanin.

And the cinematography is a solid 10 out of 10.this movie shows how cruel the system is for women in general. with a patriarchal society and a conservative country, talagang ‚Äújackpot‚Äù maging babae. it also highlights how badly we need proper sex education and why decriminalizing abortion should be pushed hard!gigil ako dun sa hayop na bobot, yung unang doctora na super pabida, at siyempre special mention kay miggy at sa pastor niyang tatay.overall, this movie hit me in a way na kahit hindi ako in sunshine‚Äôs situation, ramdam ko pa rin. as a woman, it just made me realize again how much we deal with. it‚Äôs not just a good movie it‚Äôs the type na kahit okay ka naman, pero pag may sad song, bigla kang nagrereflect. that‚Äôs exactly the energy it gave me. kudos to the director, and of course maris, who always gives justice to every character.

i want to say a lot of things about this movie pero ang hirap niya i-form into words. pero una sa lahat, i love this film. umpisa palang, ang bigat na sa feeling manuod. siguro kasi i‚Äôve been to those places? na it felt too real. lahat ng sulok na dinaanan ni sunshine at mga lugar na tinakbuhan niya, parang nandon lang din ako. i know some will say na maling desisyon yung mga ginawa ni sunshine pero ano na bang pwede niyang gawin? sa bansang walang maayos at ligtas na healthcare para sa mga kababaihan, saan pa siya lalapit? kahit nung dinala siya sa ospital dahil sa epekto nung pampalaglag, hinusgahan pa siya. ganyan ang estado ng healthcare ng mga kababaihan dito sa bansang to. i love the ‚Äúwhat should have been her daughter‚Äù na character na sinusundan si sunshine sa bawat sulok ng maynila. alam natin sa umpisa palang na ayaw ni sunshine maging nanay at gagawa siya ng paraan para magpalaglag. pero hindi parin mawawala yung parang ‚Äúguilt‚Äù na meron ang isang babae lalo na‚Äôt lumaki tayo sa katolikong bansa. kita rin ito dun sa pagpunta ni sunshine sa simbahan tuwing dumadaan siya sa quiapo. mahirap siguro hindi isipin ang mga ‚Äúwhat ifs‚Äù pero kung hindi handa ang isang babae maging nanay, hindi siya handa. dapat ganun lang kadali. i also like how they added the side story of mary grace. kasi totoo naman. ano ang gagawin ng isang babae (at sa lagay ni mary grace na 13 palang) kapag ni-r*pe siya ng tito niya? hindi kailanman magiging handa maging ina ang labintatlong gulang na bata lalo na‚Äôt bunga ito ng abuse sa bahay. also ang galing ni maris! sobrang husay niya sa pelikulang ito. kahit yung mga mata-mata acting lang, damang dama ko. you can say anything you want about maris pero no one can say anything bad when it comes to her as an actress. ang dami ko pang naiisip and i think i need days to reflect and form my thoughts pero ang masasabi ko ay we needed a movie like this sa pinas. kailangan talaga marinig ang mga kwento gaya ni sunshine (at ni mary grace).

‚ÄúGets ko na.‚ÄùIn a country like the Philippines, where everyone has an opinion on your body except you, this film hits a nerve that‚Äôs been aching for a long time. The way the film shows her struggle, the shame, the fear, the judgment, the dreams she‚Äôs forced to postpone, feels like a mirror held up to countless Filipina girls who had to grow up too fast. You can feel how her choices are never just hers; they‚Äôre tied to religion, family, and the weight of ‚Äúdapat‚Äù at ‚Äúbawal.‚ÄùBut what makes Sunshine beautiful is how it refuses to punish her for wanting more. For wanting herself.When she finally chooses her dreams, finally chooses herself and it doesn‚Äôt feel selfish. It feels like survival. Like finally stepping out of a shadow she never asked to stand under.This is a reminder that a woman‚Äôs future shouldn‚Äôt be treated like a sin.And that the sun doesn‚Äôt ask permission to shine‚Ä¶ it just does.The best Filipino Film of 2025.

Ayokong maging nanay! Ano bang pakielam nyo?!Followed by her Ate's support is what every young woman's response to people trying to dictate what to do with her body. not when she's not ready, not whenever. In this world, we need an ate like her, Dok Helena, and ate pharmacist who completely shows support no matter what her decisions, does not have malicious mindset and judgmental tendencies. Sunshine reflects the reality all young women face, the struggles of being a woman in a religious third world country and it is so brave to create this kind of film, so kudos to Direk Antonette Jadaone, Maris Racal, and to everyone behind this. Sunshine's bravery for fighting for what she wants, her exercising her rights, and her choices are what young women of today should follow. It is important to see how women who plan to abort or did abort are NOT completely cruel nor sinners, as they also have a conscience and dilemma as they go through every consideration. Her conscience, being represented by "bata," goes to show how she considered having her, but of course it all just boils down to her body, her choices, and her future. And the rights to have access in safe abortions does NOT only applies to rape victims but all WOMEN. ABORTION IS HEALTH CARE. AND ACCESS TO HEALTHCARE IS HUMAN RIGHTS. Sunshine showed how hard it is to receive health care in the philippines; that we resort to what is accessible even if it meant danger for herself. This is sad but this is reality. We need more films like this!!!

do i love this movie because i relate to it the most or because it is beautifully written and perfectly carved for this generation? either way, hands down to everyone who took part in this film. a solid watch. people often says that our society has become "pro women"‚Äîfrom the laws created to protect and empower us to the countless celebrations of women‚Äôs lives. pero, matatawag mo bang pro women ang isang lipunan kung babae lang ang naipapako sa tuwing nagbubunga ang isang bagay na hindi lang sya ang gumawa? sunshine had to go through everything‚Äîbuying the pregnancy test kits on her own, enduring the crippling anxiety while waiting for the result, desperately seeking help in terminating a pregnancy she wasn‚Äôt ready for, and then facing judgment from almost everyone around her. and ano yung na-experience ng boyfriend nya? napagalitan, siguro, pero he had the fucking audacity to chill while the girl he knocked up had gone through all phases of desperation and grief. and he thought one conversation with her, plus his dad, and he really thought that would fix everything? bffr. this is our society. despite the progressive movements, women are still seen as an object that can be controlled, blamed, and burdened with responsibilities others refuse to share.i am proud of sunshine for choosing herself.

a well-crafted filipino movie made by a woman for women. napakagaling ni maris (OH MY GOD TALAGA) napaka oscar worthy ng performance niya. so happy to see xy and rhed too! ang galing ng buong casts! production design team deserves so much flowers too!ramdam na ramdam sa Sunshine gaano kahirap maging babae sa isang patriyarkal na lipunan. ramdam na ramdam din ang korupsyon ng gobyerno: kalagayan ng mahihirap & bulok na healthcare system ng pilipinas. sobrang daming issues ang natackle on this movie (and i believe they were not surface level at all). nakakalungkot at nakakagalit ang realizations 'to the point na maiiyak ka talaga (i Can vouch. lmao)."Naiintindihan mo ba ako?" "Gets ko na."i interpreted the child as her inner conscience kasi pinakita how societal standards (ex: religion na sobrang evident sa movie) affected her decision-making. thats why gustong gusto ko yung linya na yan, kasi sunshine felt na everything was already settled for her and all noises were finally shut out. mas mahalaga parin talaga ang mga pangarap niya para sa kanya.this movie begs the watchers to Be More Understanding. ganun lang kasimple. intindi na hindi lahat ay pare-pareho; at for sunshine & menggay's cases, intindi na hindi lahat ay handang maging ina. unawa lang sa sitwasyon ng iba. tunay naman na abortion is not for all, pero may iba parin na Kailangan ito. why restrict the choices of others diba? legalizing accessible and safe abortion helps girls like sunshine and menggay. no one deserves to be go through those levels of pain. direk tonet's best work yet imo!!!! sunshine is indeed a movie that can move you + can change one's thoughts about abortion. altho i believe sobrang long way to go pa natin. malayo pa tayo sa pinaglalaban natin, ngunit walang imposible. :)

Nakakalungkot lang. Basta. It brought me back to the Fangirl days when it gave me the chills about how being a delulu can bring you to your worst disappointments. But this time, Sunshine hits different. When you realize what she did to achieve her dreams, you'd be flabbergasted. It's giving The Unforgivable dilemma. Biktima lang din talaga si Sunshine ng circumstances.Sunshine is just one of the many girls in the society who still get solely blamed for the acts that should also be blamed on the boys. This movie is not just your typical feminist film; it speaks of depth, especially on the challenges of women and the dilemma they face. Isa pa sa nagustuhan ko sa film na to is yung pinadama niya yung hopelessness ni Sunshine. Di naman sa ayaw ko ng movies na binibigyan ng pag-asa ang main character sa huli, pero this served something different and it worked. It's when she was forced to choose between two things, and ended up choosing what's best for her, even if it meant‚Äîbasta. May empathy ka pa din kay Sunshine kahit labag sa iyong kalooban ang kanyang gagawin (as a Filipino Catholic).Sobrang ironic lang din ng title, which I admire. Yung nakita ni Sunshine ang liwanag ng kanyang mga pangarap, pero di man lang nasikatan ng araw ang kanyang‚ÄîAng sa akin lang, ***** Bobot yan ü§¨.

it's no surprise to me that a lot of filipinos will misunderstand the whole point and premise of this movie. ang pagb-buntis ng maaga ay madalas nakikita lamang bilang topic ng chismis ng marami kaya di na ko nagulat na madami ang di nakakaintindi sa istorya ni sunshine. i love the inclusion of mary grace in the story, it's a bleak reminder that the women who want and need to get abortions aren't always the stereotyped madonna who's into casual sex,(granted women shouldn't have to fit into a "perfect victim" image just to be granted bodily autonomy) but they are also minors who were victims of rape from family members. mary grace's story adds so much to how deeply the film tackles the conversation around abortion as well as making it known to the audience that abortion is not a black and white subject. additionally, it also does a good job in portraying the role of men in these women's lives as well as how little guilt they shoulder from something they also took part in. sobrang little ng guilt at remorse na nararamdaman nila miggy at yung tito ni mary grace. the fact that miggy was only able to help and apologize to sunshine when his father was involved was so putangina. if male audacity had a poster child it would be him. never fucking trust a man (period) who says his "pull out" game is strong, especially if that motherfucker is named miggy and talks like he consumes red pill content on the daily.

nakakatakot kasi totoo. kung magiging babae, bakit sa pilipinas pa? sa bawat sulok may mga umaalingawngaw na tigang, ang pagtangkklik sayo kasi ika nga ‚Äúhorny‚Äù sila, pag-ostracize at pag-iskandalo, yung preachy tangents nila para lang itemper ang karamdaman mo, the misogny, the commodification, the devastating __ of it all. yung paglagay ng bag sa harap kasi baka manakawan, yung pagtago ng pampalaglag sa mga imahen ni mama mary, at yung desperasyon (mula sa labas ng simbahan kasi ikaw ay naging ‚Äúmakasalanan) sa musmos at awa ng diyos. sa kinaingay at sulasok ng siyudad, nariyan ang mga pusong may kinakapitang mga pangarap; at kung kailan andyan na ang pinakaninanais mo, wala ka nga palang karapatan sa iyong katawan. mas alam pa ng mga doktor at gagong hindi mo kilala ang gagawin sa sinapupunan mo. ‚Äòyan si sunshine. at ‚Äòyan rin kamigrowing up in a devout catholic household in a predominantly catholic-practicing country, mahirap ang maging progressive. there are days na makikipagdebate ako sa parents ko at matatapos sa mga dabog at pagkulong sa mga kwarto. bilang pro-choice, bilang babae, at bilang isang tao, wala talagang ikakukumpara yung mental process of choosing between your dream and something that wasn‚Äôt even in your control (kasi nga sabi hindi ipuputok sa loob)‚Äîthis movie has it all: the catholic guilt, yung mga minuto ng katahimikang naaaning dahil sa kakaisip, yung lito at pagkamatigas sa iyong desisyon. i‚Äôd like to imagine sunshine lived the ribbon kasi nakokontrol niya ito: na sa bawat pitik ng kamay sumusunod ang ribbon na kahit anong gawin ay maganda tignan at delikadesa mahulog, kahit anong buhol, kaya pa ring mahulas, kahit anong gulo sa galaw, maganda pa ring ang kinalalabasan. GRABE. sunshine, with her ribbon, was able to be free on the mat. now, clad in her shimmering pink and purple bedazzled spandex, she walks out with the brightest smile in her force and, like the ribbon she‚Äôs been acquainted with since childhood, is finally able to take control of her own life. Putangina, hanggang ngayon, ang daming lalaking nag-aakalang may karapatan silang magpasya para sa katawan ng babae. What stays with you long after Sunshine ends is how the film treats every moment as something pulled straight from real Filipino girlhood. You see it in the small, mundane ways Sunshine tries to keep herself together like the way she tightens her jaw during training to hide the panic creeping up her spine, how she forces a neutral expression when adults around her throw judgment disguised as concern and the humiliation of realizing everyone expects her to handle a crisis she never chose.Girls grow up by being punished for becoming women. Sunshine is still a teenager, but the moment her pregnancy becomes known, people start talking to her like she owes them maturity, penance, and accountability she was never taught to carry.When Pastor Jaime steps in, offering moral pressure, you can feel the room closing in on her again. Everyone wants her to be a mother. Everyone thinks they have the right to her future. Despite all that pressure, Sunshine‚Äôs refusal hits like a rupture in a system built to control her.

[ system log : 001 ]user : haziah | age : 23status : active // processingI liked Sunshine because it speaks volumes about the lack of real sex education among teenagers‚Äîhow so many are left to navigate consequences without ever being given proper knowledge, guidance, or protection. It shows how quickly people are forced into rigid sides‚Äîpro-choice or pro-life‚Äîwithout being allowed the space to exist as confused, scared, and human first. I didn‚Äôt like it only because Maris Racal‚Äôs acting was phenomenal‚Äîraw, restrained, and painfully real‚Äîbut because the film chose to center understanding instead of judgment. It didn‚Äôt sensationalize the situation; it made you sit with it.I liked it because it treated the experience as what it truly is: a life-altering moment that cannot be simplified into slogans, morals, or online arguments. It showed how heavy one decision can feel when the world is already crashing down on you. I liked it because it refuses to make the audience comfortable. It doesn‚Äôt beg for sympathy, it doesn‚Äôt chase approval, and it doesn‚Äôt try to make itself digestible for everyone.And most of all, I liked it because it never tells you what the ‚Äúright‚Äù answer is. It simply lays everything bare and lets you face it on your own. It allows you to choose what to feel, what to believe, and what to carry after the credits roll.Some people say it lacked something‚Äîespecially in its length‚Äîthat it should‚Äôve been longer, that it ended too soon. But I don‚Äôt agree. I think it had to end exactly where it did. Because some stories aren‚Äôt meant to be over-explained. Some experiences don‚Äôt offer neat closures. The ending didn‚Äôt feel incomplete to me‚Äîit felt honest.

apaka hirap maging babae.sunshine did the right thing. she wasn‚Äôt being selfish; she was being honest. she knew, deep within herself, that she wasn‚Äôt ready to be a mother, and because of that self-awareness, she understood that ending the pregnancy was the most responsible choice she could make.i genuinely love this film. it exposes the harsh reality of living in a country dominated by catholic doctrine‚Äîwhere the people around us can be relentlessly cruel, judgmental, and unforgiving. the film tackles abortion with remarkable depth, showing how society instinctively treats it as a sin, a crime, even a form of murder‚Äîwithout ever pausing to consider the woman‚Äôs circumstances, pain, or autonomy.sana mapanood ‚Äòto ng lahat, para maintindihan nila na hindi masama ang pagpapalaglag. people forget that there are reasons‚Äîreal, painful, and valid reasons‚Äîwhy someone would choose it.the storyline of the thirteen-year-old child, impregnated by her uncle, shattered me. it happens in real life. children‚Äîliteral children‚Äîforced to carry pregnancies at the cost of their own safety and future. it‚Äôs heartbreaking that instead of being allowed to end the pregnancy for their well-being, many are forced to keep it simply because abortion is illegal. the kid didn‚Äôt even know she was pregnant‚Äîshe only realized when her stomach started to swell. that level of innocence being burdened with trauma feels monstrous.i truly hope our country stops clinging to extreme conservatism and learns to be more open-minded‚Äîto understand that these things do happen outside the walls of their moral fantasies. legalize abortion. educate children about sex. there is nothing lewd or obscene about knowledge‚Äîmalisyoso lang ang mga utak ng mga ayaw magturo.at tangina si miggy. walang kuwenta.

‚ÄúGets ko na.‚ÄùAng dami kong gustong sabihin na feeling ko, hindi ko kayang masulat in a movie review. Literal na daramdamin mo lang yung pelikula and your emotions will be enough for people to understand.Gets na gets ko si Sunshine‚Äîfrom thinking you‚Äôre an adult yet feeling like a child; an ambitious girl to a woman on a tightrope; from being alone and criticized by society as a whole to finding your space, your people, your support system despite what people have to say‚Ä¶ and ultimately choosing your own peace and happiness‚Äîsomething that is deemed a privilege for women. Hindi naging madali ang pinagdaanan ni Sunshine at ng milyong-milyong babae sa Pilipinas, sa mundo. May mga babaeng katulad niya na hindi sinasadyang mabuntis, may mga babae namang katulad ni Menggay na posibleng ginahasa at pinagsamantalahan. Hindi ko masikmura kung gaano karaming babae ang dumadaan sa ganitong hirap araw-araw at nakakaramdam na wala na silang mapanghahawakan pa. At dadagdag pa sa pasakit ang ang mga lalaki, ang simbahan, gobyerno at mga sarado ang isip sa ganitong sitwasyon. Why is it that women have to suffer the consequences alone, with the whole world‚Äîheaven and hell‚Äîblaming them for what happened. A world that continues to place heavy pressure on a woman‚Äôs shoulders yet crucify them the moment they make a mistake. Society needs to be more forgiving to women who are trying their best to make and take up space without making them sacrifice their whole life and identity. Every woman is a Sunshine of their own, and I hope that they realize that their happiness, their life, their voices and choices matter.

Ang sarap mabuhay sa panahon kung saan accesible na sa midya ang mga ganitong klaseng pelikula. Set in the busy, chaotic streets of Manila. Raw, unfiltered at eto ang realidad na nangyayari. We've all had our fair share of having a ‚ÄúSunshine‚Äù in our lives and we've all been Geleen, Thea, the kid or even Ariana at some point. All I could say was "gets ko, sunshine."

this isn‚Äôt really a film about mistakes. well, at least for me. it‚Äôs a film about the quiet burdens women carry‚Äîthose moments when the world expects you to stay composed while everything inside you is breaking apart. what stayed with me wasn‚Äôt the plot itself, but the feeling of watching a girl stand at the edge of her dreams while life keeps pulling her in directions she never asked for.there is a particular kind of loneliness here that Filipinas know too well: the pressure to be strong, the fear of being judged, the lack of safe spaces to fall apart... The film captures that ache, the way society can be quick to moralize but slow to understand.For me, it felt like looking at a reflection of a system we‚Äôve all quietly learned to navigate: the whispers, the shame, the institutions that pretend to help but rarely do. Yet in those heavy moments, you still see a girl trying to choose herself, even when the world insists she shouldn‚Äôt.it‚Äôs messy, raw, and painfully familiar‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs why it felt less like watching a film and more like remembering something you wish you could forget.

just had to rewatch once more. ito, seryoso na at skl ko lang din this anecdote of mine. i remember being a transferee in sixth grade when i was suddenly forced into an intra-school debate tournament. one of the motions i had was about the legalization of abortion and i was placed in the opposing team. i vividly remember kung paano ako naging mulat sa topic na ‚Äòto and i thought to myself, ‚Äúoo nga, ‚Äòno? bakit nga ba bawal?‚Äù i honestly had a hard time countering the government side‚Äôs points, so i just ended up focusing on my own arguments (without saying any rebuttals) instead ‚Äî buti leader of the opp. lang ako no‚Äôn, lol. our debate teacher, or the madam chair, was very strict about not using the church as a basis when making an argument. but all i could think of then was the bible, i couldn‚Äôt think of any other countering argument na pwede kong maibato.and so, if a small-scale school debate tournament prohibits using the church as an argument, why can‚Äôt we demand the same from our government? bakit patuloy na iginigiit ang impluwensya ng simbahan sa batas if we supposedly live in a secular state?sunshine and all filipino (women) do not deserve this bullshit. free and accessible (reproductive) healthcare for filipinos!on the side note, this film is incredibly well-made and fearless. salamat, direk tonet and to everyone involved. give maris racal her flowers juseyo! i‚Äôm sooo glad i finally got to watch this kasi i missed the local screening months ago. i really hope na maging mulat ang bawat manonood kung bakit napaka-timely at mahalaga ang mga pelikulang tulad nito.

PRO-LIFERS.WOMEN'S RIGHTS SHOULDN‚ÄôT BE SOMETHING TO BE DEBATED!‚ÄúHindi pa ako ready maging nanay‚Äù is already a valid reason for abortion. It‚Äôs her choice, not a moral issue for everyone to judge. Nakakalungkot noong ipinakita sa movie na ito kung gaano kalala ang situation sa public hospitals‚Äîkulang sa resources, walang safe at stigma-free options, mayroon pa ngang nanganganak na lang sa sahig dahil sa kakulangan sa mga tao at kagamitan. Kaya hindi nakapagtataka na for many women, the ‚Äúsafest‚Äù choice ends up being underground options, kahit sobrang risky. Mas ironic pa, kasi nasa paligid lang ng simbahan ang mga nagbebenta ng pamparegla, hilot, at kung anu-ano, tapos ang narrative ng church: ‚Äúkung natukso ka, talo ka.‚Äù Kaya understandable that the ‚Äútukso‚Äù becomes sometimes the only lifeline for someone desperate. Women bear the brunt of the hypocrisy. That‚Äôs literally the only way a woman could access it. Hindi ko alam kung bakit kapag babae ka, ang daming bawal sa‚Äôyo. Pero hindi ka naman bibigyan ng reliable options. Napaka eye-opening nito sa atin, lalo na‚Äôt ipinakita sa atin na wala tayong karapatan husgahan ang batang ina kasi hindi natin alam ang pinagdadaanan nila. Rape victim man o hindi, a woman should always have the right to decide for herself‚Äîher body is never up for debate.

'Yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya.Ang hirap maging babae sa bansang 'to.Gusto ko lang sabihin na napakagaling ng mga gumanap sa mga karakter sa pelikulang 'to, hindi ako usually umiiyak sa mga pinapanood ko, pero dito, nagawa ko. Para sa'kin, purong-puro 'yung mga scenes, naipakita talaga 'yung reyalidad ng buhay pagdating sa mga taong katulad ni Sunshine, mga pangyayari na katulad ng sa kanya. Pati 'yung sitwasyon na nangyayari sa mga public hospitals, 'yung mga facilities na binabayaran natin gamit ang tax natin, ay hindi nila magawang maayos. May mga doktor pang kung umasta ay hindi sila propesyonal at napaka-condescending. It is the reality of life here in the Philippines. Napansin ko rin that hatred for abortion is rooted from patriarchy and religion, napakahirap maging babae kapag ito ang mga kalaban mo, 'no? Sa babae ang sisi, sa babae ang lahat ng kasalanan habang ang mga lalaki ay may tinatawag na "free pass." Sabi pa nga nila, "Ba't ka kasi bumubukaka," o kaya naman, "Kung sino-sino na lang kasi ang kinakalantari mo." Those things are the representation of the mindset of those who deem themselves as religious, but for me, they are just a bunch of hypocrites. Men can even be erased from the picture, and women will continue being condemned. Fuck people with double standards. Our society is so hypocrite that 'yung mga tinatawag na "pamparegla" ay natatagpuan malapit sa labas ng simbahan. Gaano sila kamapanghusga sa mga babaeng may karapatan sa kanilang sariling katawan, ipinapakita 'yan sa paniniwala nilang biased at outdated. It is sad to think na kailangan pa ng mga kababaihan na mag-lean towards these illegal means just to afford being free, when in the first place, it is their right to have a legal, safer, and non-demoralizing way to abort when it means taking care of their body, preventing the unborn from having a miserable life, and just letting women have their right to bodily autonomy. It just shows na napaka-patriarchal ng batas, sumabay pa 'yang pagiging misogynistic ng lipunang ginagalawan natin. These force women into motherhood and to have a life they do not want, and guess what happens after that? The cycle continues. Sa mga katulad ni Sunshine, at sa mga kababaihan, I'm proud of you. Sana'y buhay pa ako kapag nawala na 'yang ganyang kabobohang mindset na laganap ngayon.

Nothing beats reality when it is transformed into art. It may be written as fiction, but it reflects the reality of many young Filipino women who fall victim to sexual assault and unwanted, unplanned pregnancy‚Äîexperiences that eventually lead to deep psychological trauma. This movie was bravely written and produced. It encapsulates the hell that exists in the very streets we call home. The uncomfortable and unsettling feeling is present throughout the film, demanding to be felt by the audience‚Äîas it should be. We need to face this reality. Check on our siblings, sons, and daughters. Isang mahigpit na yakap para sa lahat ng mga kababaihan.

Patawad, patawarin mo ako.This movie is a hard watch. If Jadaone wanted to make the audience uncomfortable, then she did a great job at doing so. this film doesn't just tell a story; it exposes a system. for that reason, it stands as one of the most important films ever made in the philippines. honestly, it deserves far more attention, discussion, and recognition. include it in school curriculums too if possible.you don't need tearful monologues, or dramatic breakdowns (not that there's anything wrong with them) to understand the full weight of sunshine's situation. the film uses restraint as its sharpest tool. the dim, muted visuals; the overwhelming noise of her environment; the way the camera locks her in the centre of the frame.. always boxed in, always between lines.. all emphasise how trapped she is by the social and religious stigma, and by a society that refuses to recognise abortion as a woman's right. the blurred backgrounds aren't just aesthetic; they reinforce her disconnection from the world around her. she doesn't have the luxury to care about anything beyond her immediate reality: herself, her dreams, and the looming consequences of every decision she faces.and that is the tragedy, sunshine is a young woman with ambition, yet she navigates a world that is unforgiving. she is asked to seek god's forgiveness for attempting to abort the baby, yet if god is understanding, wouldn't he understand that she is not ready, and that she acted out of necessity? with abortion vilified and access almost impossible, the film illustrates how society corners, isolates, and silences young mothers.. not with loud condemnation, but with quiet, crushing inevitability. it is a devastating portrait of how systemic and cultural forces conspire to limit women's autonomy, and a reminder of the human cost of denying choice.one of the most striking elements of the film, for me, is its gendered power dynamic. every character, without exception, imposes his own beliefs onto sunshine. urging her to keep the baby, citing legality, morality, or personal conviction. their "advice" is never about her well-being, it's about controlling her choices. the absence of a single moment where a man asks what she wants is not accidental, it reflects a broader social structure where women's autonomy is secondary to male authority.the women in the film, however, present a more nuanced spectrum. some internalise patriarchal norms and unintentionally reinforce them, but many others recognise sunshine's struggle immediately. they empathise not because they have the answers, but because they understand the emotional, economic, and social burden that falls disproportionately on women. their solidarity is quiet but powerful. a direct contrast to the coercive, dismissive tone of the male characters. the film ultimately critiques how systems built and upheld by men deny women agency, especially around reproductive choices. in a society where institutional and cultural norms consistently silence women, the film shows that women often became each other's only source of validation, understanding, and empowerment. no scene is waster. nothing is filler. every character is intentionally placed, each one shaping or limiting sunshine's decisions in ways that feel painfully real.

Alas tres na ng madaling araw pero I have to get this out kahit medj unorgnized pa ang thoughts ko.!! MAY CONTAIN SPOILER !!GRABE. GRABE. GRABE. MARIS RACAL I WAS NOT FAMILIAR WITH YOUR GAME!Ang kwento, ang cinematography, ang emosyon!!! Sobrang raw and realistic from the familiar ‚Äújeje‚Äù song playing sa jeep pagsakay ni Sunshine, to the 13 yr old na nakaranas ng pang aabuso mula sa kanyang tito (talamak ang kaso ng incest sa pinas, thank u direk for highlighting that). Sa sobrang realistic pati ang inis ko kuhang kuha ng conservative doctor. Literally had to pause and say ‚ÄúPutangina‚Äù pag sabing ‚ÄúBaka yan pala ang magiging future presidente ng Pilipinas or ang makakagamot sa AIDS.‚ÄùAng pelikulang ito ay napakatapang. It had the guts to shine a spotlight on a longstanding issue sa bansa na lagi na lang inooverlook. It dare call out and address what Filipinos considered as taboo. And as someone who had a debate with her mom over dinner about abortion, this film is so special to me. ‚ÄúHindi ka ba kinikilabutan?‚Äù were my moms‚Äô exact words but I cannot blame her. Being a country deeply rooted in Christianity, where morals and teachings of the church are deeply ingrained in you ever since you were young, it is actually hard to speak freely about this things without the catholic guilt creeping up on you. Kaya ang laki rin ng significance ng pagdasal muna ni Sunshine before nya gawin. To ask the lord for forgiveness.Plus it doesn‚Äôt shy away from showing the state of the country‚Äôs public healthcare system. Nakakaputangina lang. Putangina ng gobyerno. Putangina ng sistema kung saan kailangan maging life-threatening situation ang pagpapalaglag. Banning abortion does not end it, it only makes it unsafe for women since it causes them to resort to underground means. drown out the noise.kung iisipin, malaya ba maging isang babae?mapagpalaya ba ang manirahan sa ganitong klase ng bansa bilang isang babae? kailan darating yung panahon na hindi na kinakailangang kumilos ng babae sa isang lugar kung saan malayang malaya siyang husgahan dahil sa kaniyang mga desisyon? tuwing kailan mo masasabing malaya ka sa sarili mong bansa; kung nakakulong ka pa rin sa gate ng simbahan, sa ingay ng dyip at tren sa kalsada, sa konsensya mo, sa sarili mo? paano mo aasahang gumalaw ang isang babaeng hindi lang isa o dalawang tao ang "masasagasaan" sa pagtindig sa kaniyang nga karapatan bilang babae‚Äîkundi isang buong relehiyon at batas ang haharapin mo na dapat sana ay nangunguna sa pagbibigay sekuridad at protekta sayo. malinaw sa pelikulang ito ang mga problemang nagpahirap kay sunshine, pero higit na mas malinaw ang mga dahilan kung bakit mas lalo itong nahirapan. hindi sana kinakailangang mag-alala ni sunshine sa mga posibilidad na maaaring may maging sagabal sa natatangi nitong pangarap. dito ipinakita na kahit nakatira si sunshine sa lugar kung saan madilim, madumi, maingay, at dikit-dikit ang mga marurupok na bahay ay mayroon pa rin itong isang ate‚Äîisang babae, na lagi't lagi niyang ipapaalala na may kakampi pa rin siya sa hinagpis ng buhay. dito ipinakita kung paanong sa kabila ng mga taong maaari mong lapitan sa gitna ng problema ay mapipilitan ka na lamang maglakad nang mabilis at balisa sa quiapo sa takot na may makakita sayo, o di kaya'y mag check in sa isang motel sa pag-asang sa madilim na kwarto ring iyon matatapos lahat ng problema mo. para sa akin, sapat na ang mga eksena sa simbahan at mga rebulto sa harap ng mga pampareglang itinitinda patago upang malinaw na maihatid ang mensaheng nais maparating ng pelikula; na isang malaking sagabal ang mga aspetong isa tayong bansa na karamihan ay mga katoliko, at lahat ng pilipino'y mga hipokritong deboto, at mas may pakielam pa ang mga ito sa mga desisyon ng mga babae para sa kaniyang sarili, kaysa sa kani-kanilang mga buhay. ang pahayag na hindi handa si sunshine maging isang ina ang siyang dapat na tumapos sa lahat ng mga opinyong wala namang maitutulong sa kaniya. ganoon lang sana kasimple ang lahat. pero higit sa mga eksenang nakaangkla sa ating pagiging katoliko ay ang mga doktor, mga propesyonal na edukado, sa pelikula kung saan mas narinig ko pa silang nanghusga kay sunshine kaysa sa sarili nitong konsensya. paano ka nga naman hihiling na sana'y gawin nang legal ang aborsyon sa bansa, kung yung mismong mga pribilehiyo at edukado na mismo ang nagbibigay rason sayo upang mas lalong matakot at panghinaan ng loob? sa mundo na kagaya ng kay sunshine, sino nga ba ang maaari nitong kapitan? hindi ba't mapipilitan ka na lamang tahakin ang landas ng mga naging desisyon ni sunshine? nakakagalit isipin na sa pagtagal ng panahon ay mas lalo lamang dumadami ang mga kaso ng mga babaeng gumagawa ng sariling diskarte para mailaglag ang kanilang mga dinadala; na higit pa sa nagbibigay kapahamakan sa kanila. napakagaling ng eksena niya sa motel; naghihikahos sa pag-asa na mamamatay din yung reyalidad na nagdadalang-tao siya. mistula ko ring personal na nararamdaman yung pisikal na sakit na nagpapadugo sa kaniya. pero tumulo talaga ang mga luha ko nang napagtanto ko yung papel ng karakter dito ni rhed bustamante. hindi matatawaran yung dating ng kuwento niya, dahil nirerepresenta niya ang bawat batang babae na dumanas ng karahasan sa sarili nitong tahanan, mula sa sarili nitong kadugo. sa bawat katagang pagsambit ni coach na "drown out the noise." ay ang reyalidad na hindi lahat ay katulad ni sunshine‚Äîsa bawat pitik ng mga kamay at lambot ng kaniyang katawan ay may kakayahan itong lunurin ang isip sa katahimikan. hindi lahat ng dumanas sa teenage pregnancy ay may kakayahang isarado ang isip sa bawat panghuhusga at pagsabi ng mga tao na, mali iyan, kasalanan iyan, malay pa natin at balang araw ang laman na gusto mong ipalaglag ay ang magiging presidente ng pilipinas. higit sa katotohanang dapat ay nasa lalake ang lahat ng sisi, malaking parte rin ang simbahan, gobyerno, at ang mga taong nakapaligid sayo, kung bakit hindi mo magawan ng desisyon ang sarili mong katawan at kinabukasan. pangarap ko rin ang lahat ng pangarap ng mga sunshine.

this film is so close to my heart and i don't think there's a word in any dictionary that can explain how much value i put in this movie. sunshine is the representation of many young girls in the philippines and the cultural violence that filipino women have to face every single day. manila is home, but what home turns away its daughters? what home is so noisy that it becomes hard to hear the plea for change? it's hard to drown out the noise when manila is nothing but the howl of traffic and trains grinding along rusty tracks. it's hard to drown out the noise when every corner of the city carries the weight of other people's opinions about you. it's hard to drown out the noise when people love nothing more than the echo of their own voices. it's hard to drown out the noise when the government chooses to not help. it's hard to drown out the noise when the hospitals meant to care for you are bursting in the seams. it's hard to drown out the noise when you're a woman in manila. besides, why are we expected to keep drowning out the noise? why can't the noise just stop. i am tired of seeing women seek help from the narrow and noisy streets of quiapo to get unsafe abortion simply because there's no other choice available to them. women should be able to walk into a hospital and feel protected in their own decisions, in their own bodies, without a doctor insisting they ‚Äúthank God‚Äù for something that has broken them. sunshine, i dream the same dreams you have. gets na gets kita

Hands down, wala akong masabi sa palabas na ‚Äòto. This film reveals everything about the Philippines that we don‚Äôt often talk about. Many Filipinos have no choice kasi illegal ang abortion dito, and young women are forced into situations THEY NEVER REALLY WANTED. It shows the harsh reality of how society constantly pressures women into motherhood, ignoring their dreams, their health, and their right to make decisions about their own bodies. The film doesn‚Äôt sugarcoat the pain physical, emotional, and mental‚Äîthat comes with being trapped in a system that refuses to acknowledge their autonomy.What hits the hardest is how normalized this struggle has become, and how many are suffering in silence. Especially the story of rhed bustamante‚Äôs character. Grabe. 13 years old nag cacarry na ng baby ‚òπÔ∏è a child carrying a child. This is a message to all the people to talk more openly about abortion, to stop victim-blaming, and to hold those useless shitty ass irresponsible men accountable. It‚Äôs more than a movie‚Äîit‚Äôs a wake-up call, a plea for empathy, and a DEMAND for change. Sobrang gets kita, sunshine.

the premise alone is enough for me to give it a full rating. to come up with a movie about one of the most taboo topics in this predominantly catholic country‚Äîgiven how conservative almost everyone is about it, how it‚Äôs actively vilified and condemned, how those who seek it are treated as no better than murderers, and how women are left to fend for themselves and look for alternative ways, whether through an underground clinic, safe or unsafe, or a seller‚Äôs comforting words when you don‚Äôt even know if the medicine will work‚Äîis a huge feat. it has been long overdue, but this is already a big step for everyone. abortion is, and will always be, healthcare.film-wise though, i absolutely LOVE the color grading. i usually hate SOME filipino movies (omg i‚Äôm sorryyyy) because the coloring pisses me off (like ik we can do better). idk how to pinpoint what gives me the ick but,,, yeah. sunshine‚Äôs though was nice. and it was a delight to see bits of manila‚Äôs vibe. always shady, dirty, BUT well, that‚Äôs our country and i loved the actual showcase of it. there were some symbolism and stills of how ironic some scenes can be too!! nice touch :) from the pills next to the statues to the jeepney signs. the plot is predictable for me (re: what those kids are), but not in a bad way. it just shows that it‚Äôs working, and i feel seen. a lot of women will feel seen. not saying we went through the exact same thing, but generally, the gist of thinking your life is over, or will be if it does happen, because we don‚Äôt have a choice in the first place, and are expected to just live with it, is familiar. the amount of mental gymnastics people will spew about ‚Äúthe future of the children,‚Äù how they could be ‚Äúthe next inventor of a cure,‚Äù while never considering the mother, who has her own ambitions, who has to give birth, raise the child, and provide the system and support for their hypothesis to even happen‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs all broken-record arguments. these are the usual lines they‚Äôll say, and some of their reactions (doctors, friends, ‚Äúpartners‚Äù) really DO HAPPEN irl and it‚Äôs proof that the film is heavily based from real experiences, and well researched enough about the actual process people will go through (and went through) for this. here‚Äôs to shed light, to inform, and hopefully, to make people more open, thoughtful, and willing to give women the autonomy they deserve.mic drop

ok‚Ä¶ two things: ang ganda at ang tapangang ganda kasi kuhang kuha yung manila as in!!! yung opm rap sa jeep, yung kabusyhan ng quiapo, yung juxtaposition na sa tabi ng simbahan mo pa makikita mga nagbebenta ng abortion pills, yung vibe ng recto (tangina heavy on this)accordingly, kuhang kuha din nito yung Pilipino ‚Äî kung paano tayo nasshape ng religious ideals, kung paano pineperceive ng karamihan yung mga babaeng gustong magpa-abort, even kung ano yung tingin natin sa teenage pregnancykaya ang tapang ng movie na to for delving into sunshine's inner struggles - bilang isang teenage Filipina na working class, na nagkaroon ng unexpected pregnancy, na nakatira sa isang bansa na hindi accessible ang reproductive healthcare at sobrang religious lang ng mga tao (intersectionality af) oo, first choice niya talagang ipa-abort ang bata, pero makikita na hindi to naging madali for her - eto ang crux ng movie. pinakita nito na hindi madali ang daan sa abortion - sa kalooban ng babae at sa mga methods na available sa kanya (esp sa bansa natin). pinakita ng Sunshine kung gaano ka-ingrained sa kababaihan na makaramdam ng guilt kapag cinoconsider nilang magpa-abort. HINDI SIYA MADALI, lalo na if may iba pang circumstances na kailangan tignan. sana magets ng mga close-minded people yung point pag pinanood nila.kung iisipin, buhay ng isang babae in real life ang buhay ni sunshine sa pelikula. pero kahit nakikita natin si sunshine sa ordinaryong Pilipina, napakahirap pa rin ng conversation surrounding abortion. kaya ang tapang talaga ng movie for inviting discussion on this topic.hindi ko nagets at first pero i appreciate how the kid represented her unborn child. ang ganda nung "yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya" nakakaiyak...ang galing galing galing ni maris racal!!!!!gets ko na :)

SUCH AN IMPORTANT FILM!!!!During these times, we genuinely need more films like this. First, not only does it touch on the struggles of a young woman faced with an unwanted pregnancy. It also shows how easy it is for the men to rid themselves of the responsibility. Miggy DID NOT give a fuck about Sunshine. He wanted her to deal with it herself; he wasn't even going to give her money if she didn't threaten him. It was his fault that she got pregnant, and yet she has to suffer the consequences of their unprotected sex, which he insisted upon. Second, it is very important how this film shows that early/childhood pregnancies are not just because of young people's 'kapabayaan.' More often than not, young girls' pregnancies are results of sexual assault and rape by predators. I cried when I saw Mary Grace, even more when we were told she's just 13. JUST 13!!!!! She wasn't "wreckless," she wasn't out there having sex with anyone; she was raped by her own uncle. And she's just expected to mother the child born out of such a horrific thing done to her?Third, it shows you just how important legalizing abortion is. It's already happening out there. People are selling abortive pills or concoctions. People are doing basement abortions, in unsafe conditions, without licensed doctors. It's happening and it's dangerous. Sunshine was hospitalized. Mary Grace almost died. If abortion was legal, none of this would've happened. These girls would've been safe and cared for.Again, what an important film! It also shows how abysmal the healthcare system is in the Philippines. Overcrowded hospitals, little to no financial support, etc.On top of that, phenomenal performances all around. Maris Racal was great. Jennica Garcia was, as usual, brilliant. Rhed Bustamante, you will always be a star.This might be the longest entry in my letterboxd rn. I'll end it with: COMPREHENSIVE SEX EDUCATION NOW!! LEGALIZE ABORTION!!!

Ang hirap mangarap sa pilipinas, at mas lalong mahirap maging babaeng nangangarap sa pilipinas. Here, our dreams can be taken away in just one snap. The hardship every woman face in this country was shown in this movie ‚Äî everything in every angle. From the lack of support from the government, the inequalities women face, how fucked up the mentalities of most of the Filipinos, struggles in the face of poverty, to the fragility of our dreams. "Libre lang mangarap" they say, but it's not really free when you live in this country. It costs you your dignity, and even your life.---- I just know na I chose Humanities and Social Sciences to broaden up my understanding, perspective, and empathy like how this movie exposed and depicted our reality. We all need exposure to learn, since parang hindi sapat yung everyday witnessed struggles nating mga Pilipino, let this movie open your eyes on how f-ed up our system in this country really is. Mahirap i romanticize ang mga ganto, at hindi dapat i romanticize ang mga ganto.

Sunshine (2024) is the most needed Filipino film of our generation and the generations to come. Beyond the excellent storytelling and technicalities, the message it conveys in a predominantly Catholic & conservative country is a long-overdue revelation of the reality of women.The film opens conversations for the uncomfortable truth of human nature. This is not just Sunshine's story. This is also the story of every woman and every young girl who face the challenges of being silenced and whose rights are being dictated and stepped on by our society.Maris perfectly portrayed Sunshine as a woman who knows what she wants and realizes the power that she and every other woman should have.The rest of the cast realistically depicted the Filipino society that reflects their morals on the teachings of Christianity. Moreover, the two "imaginary" characters brought life to the film by displaying the faces behind the masked moralities our society tells us.As a child of unwanted birth and as an adoptee, I know deep in my heart how much I advocate for abortion. I will always side with what is just and right; the ability of women to have access to reproductive health and the power of women to make decisions for their own life.Maraming salamat sa tapang at galing mo, Direk Tonet.
