I watched this film with my very religious family. I didn't say a word the whole duration of the film‚Äî yet every few minutes, without fail, at least one of my family members would nag me about teenage pregnancy and promiscuity. I heard countless demeaning phrases like "kita mo yan? alam mo na ha, pag ikaw" and "san ka pupulutin kung di namin sinasabi sayo 'to?". I'm 15, they don't even let me watch movies with sex scenes on the family tv. (but obviously i still do watch movies beyond my age rating) The overbearing nature of religion is truly a problem in the philippines; and among our people, the vast majority of our country is made up of catholics, and it seems like the state is sometimes one with the church because of that fact. I commend this movie for being a step in the right direction. It's showing the true nature of these things to our often ignorant and close-minded society. I know it's still a long way to a progressive philippines, but atleast i know there are still measures being made to ensure that we will get there. Someday, somehow.

Authentic depiction of how the female reproductive health is viewed and discussed in the Philippines. It is terrifying and undeniably demeaning that many, if not all, do not have access to these basic rights and thus continue to endanger the lives of many women out there. It is more infuriating to know that this also includes children as young as 13. Though this inclusion in the film may seem minor, it actually emphasizes that not being able to be given a choice to our own body steals our futures away.I also liked the nuances and subtle details that made this film feel more humane and relatable, including the motto etched on the Jeepney Sunshine rode when she found out she was pregnant, which was ‚ÄúGIFT OF GOD.‚Äù Hands down, Maris Rascal nailed this role. Those facial expressions? Period. Bonus na rin appearance ni Piolo Pascual.ü§ûI could yap about this film but for the sake of my fingers typing this review, I‚Äôll leave this as it is for now.All in all, this one is a great watch.

Excellent, timely, and heartfelt. Sunshine is not only a film but an important and timely discussion about the concepts of abortion, teen pregnancy, and womens agency over their bodies. Antoniette Jadaone has always been one of my favorite filipino directors and this is project to me, solidified her place in the contemporary filipino directorial space. Maris Racal at her best, a grounded and sincere performance. This movie deserves the recognition that it got and hopefully it becomes a catalyst towards discussions surrounding these topics especially in the Philippines. An excellent film across the board. Women should have the choice and agency towards their bodies. I'll die on that hill.

Nadama ko sa pelikula na mag-isa si Sunshine sa kanyang tinatahak ngunit nadama ko din na may iilang sumoporta sa kanya at ito ay mga kapwa kababaihan.Ito ang mga babae sa istorya na tumatak para sa akin: Sa eksena kung saan tinanggihan ng isang lalaking doctor i-attend ang batang nag pahilot sa takot na mawalan siya ng lisensiya at isang babaeng doctor ang nag lakas loob na tulungan ang bata. Ito ay realidad na ang batas sa bansang ito ay nakaka apekto sa pag lilingkod kapwa. Ang ate ni Sunshine na inintindi at sinuportohan hindi lamang ang desisyon kundi ang pangarap ni Sunshine. Malaking aspeto ang pagkakaroon ng kapamilya na hindi ka i-guiguilt trip o susumbatan ka sa nagawa mo, bagkus nag tiwala siya na alam ni Sunshine kung ano ang makakabuti para sa sarili niya. Ang imaginary child na nag boses na gets niya ang alab sa puso na makamit ang pangarap ni Sunshine. Sa tanong na who will protect women? Ang sagot ay tayo. Tayong kapwa kababaihan ang palaging tumutulong sa isa't isa dahil alam natin ang bigat ng mundong pasan pasan natin. Sa bansang hindi prayoridad ang kalusugan ng kababaihan, napakita ng pelikulang ito ang realidad ng isang babae kakapit sa kung anong meron sa paligid niya na paraan para mag palaglag dahil pinag kakait sa atin ang accessible healthcare. Ang pelikulang ito ay para sa lahat ng kababaihan na tahimik lumalaban sa ingay ng paligid na palaging may kuda sa kung anong daan ang dapat nating tahakin.

Gets ko si Sunshine.This film really captures me the most. As a woman who grew up in a most conservative country and a religious family, I feel the comfort of the movie. I know that tackling this kind of topic would raise brows to the people especially the one who‚Äôs spirituality believes that a women shouldn‚Äôt undergo abortion even if she really didn‚Äôt want to bear the child. Actually, it‚Äôs even funnier that this country preach that abortion should ban but the truth is there is a lack of education about sex, abortion, and contraceptives. Additionally, it‚Äôs so hypocrisy and misogynistic that people really blame woman for getting pregnant but NOT THE MAN?! In fact, they are the ones who put babies inside the woman‚Äôs womb. I really learned so many lessons in the movie which open my mind to the struggles of a woman. It‚Äôs disappointing that people keep preaching what‚Äôs right or wrong but THEY NEVER HELP AND UNDERSTAND THESE WOMEN. The movie open my mind that abortion SHOULD BE LEGALIZE. Abortion ISN‚ÄôT a sin, murder, nor crime. IT‚ÄôS A HEALTH CARE. It‚Äôs NOT selfish. It‚Äôs okay.But it is just sad that the Philippines is not yet ready to understand and tackle this kind of topic. I get Sunshine. The guilt-tripping, shame, and misogyny are tackled in a best possible way to give the viewers assurance and comfort. Also, it gives reminder that Filipinos should really open their minds and change their mindset. Women didn‚Äôt deserve the shame, the hate, and mostly the expectations that have been throwing to them just because THEY ARE WOMEN. For fucking sake. WOMEN NEED SUPPORT NOT A FUCKING JUDGEMENT FROM THE PEOPLE WHO‚ÄôS CLAIMING TO BE A SPIRITUALLY ACTIVE BUT CANNOT OPEN THEIR MINDS AND THINK RIGHT.I hope and wish that the government legalize abortion. It is not a shameful thing to do. It is not killing. It is a self-care ‚Äî A HEALTH CARE. People should know and understand that.Overall, I really love the movie and it will have a special place in my heart. I hope, Filipino directors would produce many movies like this to promote woman and to educate people that abortion is a health care.

From the very beginning, the film doesn‚Äôt sugarcoat anything. It throws you straight into the raw, unfiltered reality of the city. You feel the noise, the chaos, the sense of being overwhelmed, like you‚Äôre standing right in the middle of it all.Pero beyond the city‚Äôs noise, Sunshine digs into something heavier. It shows the weight of Sunshine‚Äôs struggle, the clash between personal pain, religious expectations, and society‚Äôs harsh judgment. The movie doesn‚Äôt shy away from the reality na hanggang ngayon, ang hirap mag-access ng abortion services sa Pilipinas dahil illegal pa rin ito. It captures how isolating it is to face a problem this heavy, and how hard it is to seek help in a system that refuses to understand.Overall, I like it.

Hands down. One of the best filipino films I have ever seen.This deserves more than what I‚Äôll write. More than the stars I‚Äôve given. More than a mere category of ‚Äòfavorites‚Äô.This is worth talking about. The film I should see when tackling feminism. The film that shows how the Philippines lack support for its beautiful and brave women.Una sa lahat, fuck quiapo air. Quiapo‚Äîang baho, ang sikip, ang init! Pero Quiapo‚Ä¶ a place where you‚Äôll find even the tiniest bit of hope, a place where even an ounce of solution can be found, a place where help exists, even if only through a few people.i also loved how fuckass men were portrayed in this movie. walang kwentang jowa, walang kwentang kapatid, walang kwentang tatay, walang kwentang tito, walang kwentang doktor. Tangina ang may kwentang lalaki lang ata rito is yung tricycle driver eh. Tangina ng mga lalaking ganyan. Patriarchy at its finest! Also, fuck women who let themselves be abused by this power. Yes, I‚Äôm talking about YOU nanay ni Mary Grace.as it progressed, onti-onti kong nararamdaman yung emotional sincerity ng film. yung dilemmas of decisions ni sunshine and yung heartbreaking truth about Mary Grace‚Äôs pregnancy. 13 years old pa lang siya? Yes, 13 years old pa lang siya. The movie refuses to romanticize their situation. instead, it leans into the uncomfortable truths of being a young woman in a society that praises discipline, resilience, and sacrifice yet offers little support when life derails. Director Jadaone shapes the film with a raw, documentary-like honesty: tight shots of silent breakdowns, stripped-down scenes with no dramatic score, and a narrative that mirrors the suffocating pressure placed on young Filipinas navigating taboo choices.Lastly, ang nagustuhan ko talaga sa film na to is the fact na the film didn‚Äôt fail to show and acknowledge the other women surrounding sunshine. women who, though not always in the spotlight, embody the many forms of pressure, expectation, and silent resilience that shape the world she moves in. they all carry their own versions of sacrifice: women praised for being disciplined, nurturing, and endlessly strong, yet rarely offered the same support they tirelessly give. like seriously? the maternity ward scene broke my heart so much üíî seeing allthe women sharing the same beds also shows how fucked up our healthcare system really is. Tayo-tayo lang rin nagtutulungan. Tayo lang ang sumusuporta sa isa‚Äôt isa. Tayo lang mga babae. Kudos to that tindera. Ironic lang na sa harap pa talaga ng mga rebulto ni santo ni√±o nagtinda ng pampalaglag ü§ç these kinds of religious beliefs shouldn‚Äôt really hinder us from doing what‚Äôs right and best for ourselves. and in showing these women‚Äôs quiet struggles, the film expands its emotional weight, reminding us that the story isn‚Äôt just about one girl‚Äôs burden but about an entire generation of women expected to endure everything while being thanked for it in silence. kulang pa tayo sa pansin, sa pagmamahal, at sa suporta. i hope that someday, all of us can finally feel how to live as a woman and be loved as a woman.

people often judge teenage pregnancy as the result of ‚Äúgiving in to temptation,‚Äù but this film shows the other side‚Äînot all teenage pregnancies are wanted or chosen. what i love about the film is how powerful it is; it resonates deeply with viewers and delivers a clear message consistently from start to finish.maraming sunshine sa lipunan‚Äîna biglaan, takot, at walang lakas ng loob na harapin ang pagiging ina‚Äîpero hindi ito usapin na masama ng tao si sunshine kaagad nang dahil lamang sa hindi pa siya handa. a moment of temptation is not enough reason to demand she accept her situation, as forcing a woman into parenthood before she is ready is a far greater mistake.i hope this film opens more eyes and highlights the need to strengthen reproductive rights in our country, recognizing that abortion is a right for all women. men who cause pregnancies rarely face the same scrutiny or shame; women, on the other hand, bear society‚Äôs judgment alone.abortion is not always chosen for pleasure‚Äîoften it is the result of abuse or exploitation.it is heartbreaking that in the philippines, a case of violence against women is reported every 57 minutes. globally, over 30% of women‚Äîmore than 737 million‚Äîexperience abuse from partners or non-partners. many feel trapped, unable to leave because they are pregnant and have no right to terminate.in february 2024, save the children urged stronger reproductive rights in the philippines, noting that 35% of filipino girls under 15 became pregnant from 2021 to 2022‚Äîclear victims of abuse and exploitation. this is a critical issue that the government must address.women have the right to control their own bodies and make their own choices‚Äîregardless of religion, culture, or social pressure. they are often the most vulnerable and left behind in such situations.thank you to sunshine for her courage in standing up for herself and pursuing her dreams, and thank you to the film for portraying these realities.as i read somewhere, ‚Äúmarami ang hindi mapapatawad si sunshine dahil sa ginawa niya, pero sapat naman nang napatawad ni sunshine ang sarili niya.‚Äù
‚Äú‚Äòyung pangarap ko, kung ano‚Äông pangarap niya.‚Äù

lahat ng tao ay may sariling ingay na tinatahak. sa pelikula, hindi lang ito ingay ng traffic o tambutso. ito yung ingay ng moralidad, ng tsismis, ng relihiyong mabilis magturo pero mabagal magmahal. ito yung ingay ng mga taong hindi naman mabubuhay sa katawan mo pero sila ang pinakamalakas magdikta kung ano ang dapat mong maramdaman, gawin, at piliin. at sa lahat ng ito, isang nineteen-year-old girl ang pasan ang mundo‚Äîa girl who should‚Äôve been allowed to dream freely, pero sinasakal na ng lipunang takot sa kababaihang may sariling isip.isang bagay na ramdam mo agad sa pelikula: magkakampi ang mga babae. halos lahat ng karakter ay babae, at karamihan sa kanila may dalang munting piraso ng simpatya. isang kolektibong danas. isang unspoken sisterhood built on the multiple burdens that women carry: being caregivers, dreamers, breadwinners, shock absorbers of society‚Äôs cruelty. pero hindi rin romantisado ang pelikula‚Äîmay mga babaeng kakampi, at may mga babaeng hindi. katulad ng doktor na ultraconservative, na nagpapaalala sa atin ng painful truth: hindi lahat ng babae ay mapagpalaya, at hindi lahat ng babae ay kakampi sa kapwa babae. minsan, ang mismong sistemang umaapi ay umiiral din sa mga babaeng natutong ipasa-pasa ang sakit.pinaka-mahalaga sa lahat: hindi totoong pagiging makasarili ang pagdedesisyon ng babae para sa sarili niyang katawan. kung may isang ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù moment ang sunshine, ito ‚Äòyon. kung sarili lang niya ang iniisip niya, wala sana tayong ganitong pelikula. wala sana tayong ganitong lalim. pero ang totoo, bawat desisyon niya ay puno ng takot, pagmamahal, at pag-asa‚Äîlahat ng bagay na kinalimutan ng lipunan kapag babae ang may kailangan pumili.dito rin pumapasok ang simbolismo ng batang babae‚Äîang unborn child, ang personified conscience. ariana is 13 y/o's own past self, her own fear, her own what-if. lahat ng interaction nila ay nangyayari ‚Äúsa loob,‚Äù sa pinakatahimik na sulok ng isip ng babaeng hinahati ng daigdig. at nung ending, it‚Äôs for herself. the hug is acceptance. ang yakap na iyon ay tahimik na paglaya.pero kahit sa mundong pilit nagpapatahimik sa kababaihan, may irony na hindi kayang itago ang pelikula: sa isang konserbatibong lipunan, ang nagbebenta ng religious figures ay siya ring nagbebenta ng abortion pill. ang ob ay bigot. ang bahay ay hindi laging ligtas. ang simbahan ay humuhusga. at ang babae? wala man lang tunay na espasyo para huminga. bakit ang mga lalaki, may opsyon? bakit ang kababaihan, pilit pinapapili pero hindi ginagawaran ng tunay na choice?dito nagiging mas malakas si sunshine. hindi siya martyr. hindi siya sainted victim. she doesn‚Äôt just endure‚Äîshe decides. she chooses herself kahit alam niyang bawat galaw niya may kasamang kurot ng panibagong judgment. she‚Äôs not fearless, but she moves anyway. at minsan, iyon na ang pinaka-matapang na pwedeng gawin ng babae sa bansang sobrang hilig kontrolin ang katawan at kinabukasan niya. dedma sa ingay. dedma sa prejudice. kung may pangarap ka, hawakan mo, kahit pa buong mundo pa ang naka abang na magkamali ka. ang sabi ni direk jadaone, ang pagbubuntis ay magbabago sa katawan ni sunshine, sa career niya, sa buong trajectory niya bilang atleta. at totoo‚Äîpara kay sunshine, ang pregnancy ay literal career suicide. at dito umaalingawngaw ang tanong na gusto talagang ipukpok ng pelikula: bakit ba laging kababaihan ang kinakailangang magsakripisyo ng pangarap? bakit ang freedom ng babae ay laging conditional?kaya oo‚Äîdecriminalize abortion. kasi ang autonomy ay hindi dapat ipinaglalaban, dapat innate. ang katawan ng babae ay hindi battleground para sa moralidad ng iba.in the end, sunshine reminds you that sometimes the bravest thing a girl can do is to choose herself, quietly, consistently, even when the world says she shouldn‚Äôt.

It‚Äôs a film about women ‚Äî their suffering, their heartbreak, their impossible choices ‚Äî in a society that pretends to protect them yet refuses to listen to them. Especially when it comes to abortion, the film exposes how cruel a world can be when faith is used not for compassion, but for judgment.Ang lalim ng emosyon sa bawat eksena. Just the truth, plain and heavy. The kind that sits on your chest long after the lights come up.Maris delivers a performance that feels painfully honest. Ang galing ni Maris, and I‚Äôve never doubted her talent, pero dito she carries a story so much bigger than her character ‚Äî a story shared by countless women who are tired of being silenced.At Maraming salamat sa sining mo, Director Jadaone.

grabe. SUNSHINE absolutely wrecked me in the best way possible. hindi ko in-expect na ganito katapang, ganito ka-personal, at ganito ka-Pinoy yung atake. ang tapang talaga ng pelikulang ‚Äòto not loud, not preachy, just brutally honest.from the first few minutes pa lang, ramdam mo agad yung bigat na dala ng story. the way the film paints the reality of women in the Philippines‚Ä¶ sobrang tumatagos. ang galing ng pacing, ang ganda ng visuals, and the emotions?? solid.what I love most is how real it feels. walang sobra, walang kulang just a story na kailangan talaga mapakinggan. sana mas marami pang ganitong pelikula na hindi natatakot mag-open ng conversations we rarely talk about pero sobrang kailangan.and honestly‚Ä¶ I have my own sunshine and gets ko sila :)) kaya siguro mas tumama lahat. when you‚Äôve lived even a tiny part of it, ang sakit niya panoorin in the best way.and that public hospital scene? grabe. damang-dama mo yung pagiging mahirap imagine mga bagong panganak na magkakasama sa iisang malaking ward, siksikan, pagod, walang choice. ang bigat niya panoorin kasi alam mong totoo.

If your moral values believe that no child should be aborted, sana kasama rin sa values nyo na walang babaeng deserved na mahirapan dahil sa unwanted pregnancy. Women needs to have choice, if we always shame women na nabuntis, bakit hindi natin ibaling sa mga nakabuntis ang sisi? Sa buong panonood ko, nainis ako kay Elijah Canlas, sa nanay ni xyril, kay Piolo Pascual, dun sa nagtitinda ng pampalaglag, dun sa doctor na ayaw mag-admit ng batang naghihingalo dahil gumawa daw ng ilegal (mind you, narape yan kaya sya buntis), at sa ospital na hindi kayang i-cater ang pangangalaga sa mga kababaihan. Sana imbes na ijudge si sunshine sa choices nya, sana namulat tayong lahat na we should be free of our choices. Na hindi tayo selfish dahil lang ayaw natin ng anak. And that we are entitled to be taken care of kahit ano pang desisyon natin when it comes to our pregnancy. Sobrang lupit ng mundo natin, na patuloy na nagtataas ng kilay kapag tungkol sa usapang sex pero wala ring ginagawang hakbang kapag nagkakaroon ng unwanted pregnancy ang mga kababaihan. definitely direk antoinette‚Äôs best work so far. simula pa lang, damang-dama ko na si sunshine. lahat ng naramdaman niya‚Äîyung takot, galit, inis, lungkot‚Ä¶tumatama sakin. kahit na gets ko agad yung role ni annika, i didn‚Äôt expect that surge of emotions sa dulo. as much as i am pro-choice, hindi talaga mawawala yung catholic guilt. and aside from that, ewan ko if ako lang, pero ramdam ko rin na in some way may fondness si sunshine sa bata. maybe it‚Äôs something mothers feel, even yung muntikan na, or baka kasi babae tayo.tbh, parang hinuhulaan ko na yung mga susunod na mangyayari (ganun ako sa lahat ng movies ;-;), pero nagulat pa rin ako dito. damang-dama ko yung pagkababae ko rito, parang universal feeling for women ganun. kita ko sarili ko hindi lang kay sunshine, pero pati sa ate niya, bff niya, si menggay, yung doktora, yung ate sa pharmacy, yung coach niya. hayyy naluluha pa rin ako kapag iniisip ko to HAHAHA.pansin na pansin ko rin na talagang englishera si annika HAHAHA. iniisip ko parang hindi swak, but i remembered na englishero yung tatay niya (character ni elijah). idk if on purpose ba na englishero si elijah to match annika or the other way around HAHAHA.

Love how the film depicts the harsh reality of what women have to go through just to be able to decide for themselves and their BODIES!! This movie really goes to show how making abortion illegal makes it so much harder and dangerous for women. It does not sanctify the value of life since in the first place the life of the woman is endangered. Moreover, I love how Manila gets depicted in this light, it shows the good and bad that comes with the city. It is bad for obvious reasons, the normalized chaos that is happening around it, how every night Sunshine is there, a mayhem ensues. However, I appreciate how Manila became a sanctuary place for her, where we can see how despite the chaos that happens every night, there are bits of humanity that saves her. The girl dun sa hotel, yung tricycle driver, and the 13-year-old girl that she met.Furthermore, I would like to commend the addition of having childrens act as her conscience or the "what if child of hers". It's a great addition because we can see how in the beginning of the film the girl was literally shouting "murderer" over and over again because in her perspective, her mother is harming her. But in the end when she said "gets ko na", it became a cathartic scene as it finally hits us that it isn't about being irresponsible and selfish ---- rather it is something more than that. The whole line of the girl saying to her friend Ariana that her dream is the same as Sunshine's is a great addition because I think it rings true with reality. As every now and then, when a child hears about the dreams of their parents and how they had to stop it to take care of their children, especially when it comes to Mothers, the child often feels bad and just wished that thier Mom was able to live out their dream first.Lastly, I love the relationship of sunshine and her older sister, the fact that never once pinagalitan o diniktahan ng ate nya sa kung paano nya haharapin yung sitwasyon niya goes to show how much she trusts and love Sunshine. I also love the contrast that all throughout the film there were different sides of the story whether labelling her as a "murderer" o miggy telling her to do what you got to do that once you reached the end scene when her sister just told her "kahit ano maging desisyon mo kampi lang ako sayo" made it soo impactful. Kase in the end yun lang naman ang kailangan niyang marinig, we have seen her face through that circumstance alone with nothing but her conscience, that the moment na sinabi sa kanya yun, it became a relief to her as well as allowed her to finally tell someone or at least cried it out to them na natatakot din siya kase nga bata din siyaa and hindi pa siya ready maging nanay. All in all, the film was a 10 out of 10, and I appreciate how the film wasn't all in the face about what you should believe in and what you shouldn't. It just presents Sunshine's story and her decision which should be acknowledged because hindi dapat humantong sa isang sitwasyon na mas uunahin pa ng isang doktor ang kaniyang lisensya kesa sa buhay ng isang tao dahil lang "nagpalaglag" siya. If you really value life in its essence then we should also acknowledge the life of the person carrying the baby so bakit niyo papabayaan lang na mamatay yung batang 13-year-old???????? so in conclusion:TANGINAA NG MGA LALAKETANGINA MO MIGGYTANGINA NUNG DOKTORATANGINA NUNG LALAKING DOKTORTANGINA NUNG TITO TANGNIA NUNG WALANG KWENTANG NANAY (?) - di nya deserve matawag na nanay

In a country like ours, where religion holds so much influence, making this film is such a courageous decision. Filipinos tend to be religious but their actions contradict the values they claim uphold. It‚Äôs about time we normalize conversations abortion and sex education. How many more women will go through what sunshine went through? Women should not be forced into motherhood because not all of us are made to be a mother. Every women deserves the rights to decide and to be seen.Sunshine is such a beautiful film. It‚Äôs very raw which makes it easy to connect with the audience especially with women. To all the sunshines out there: you are heard, and you are seen. Your voice matter.Pangarap ko rin ang mga pangarap mo, Sunshine:)

Holy shit, this film had me in tears. Not only is it extremely well made, the cinematography and the characters were so raw that it had me stressing over them. I have never rooted for anyone so much to get rid of that damn baby. The movie also shows the darkest sides of the healthcare system in the Philippines, religion, and most of all, fucking men. It is unfortunate that us Filipina women have it the fucking worst. Not only are we in a third world country where it is illegal to abort, but we are guilt tripped over and over again by society to not choose ourselves. We are literal machines for them to procreate and forget ourselves in the process. We are not human to them.Right from the get-go it is shown how unprepared (who I assumed is 20) 20 year old Sunshine is. Even when she is cleaning up her sister‚Äôs child, she raises her hand as if to scare the child, when the child clearly does not understand this gesture. The men in this film are shown to be no help at all, may it be sibling, the boyfriend, the men in the streets, every. single. man. The concept of birthing a child will never be their problem, it will never even cross their minds. I love how realistic the scenes were when all the pregnant were all together, aiding each other and comforting each other; that is the harsh truth‚Äî men will never know the connection us women have with one another. Even if they are strangers.Rhed (Mary Grace) is the exact reason why abortion should be legalized in the Philippines. Young women subject themselves to improper medical procedures because that‚Äôs all they have access to (and hardly)‚Äî they do not know the severity of what their bodies will go through. In the first place, sex education is still frowned upon in the Philippines. God, I really hate, HATE how religion proves time and time again that they are the main reason why we cannot progress as a society. This film is beautifully filmed, I loved every bit of it. My heart sank deeper whenever she struggles, but the weight lifts whenever she chooses herself. Ladies, please choose yourself, above everyone else.

'Yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya. Isang mahigpit na yakap para sa mga sunshine diyan:) at fuck you sa mga Miggy at Bobot diyan. Putangina niyong mga lalake, mga walang dulot. Gets na gets ko‚Äîand I hope many more people will get it, too. This film struck a deep chord with me. Nearly every scene felt like it could happen in real life‚Äîand in many cases, it truly does.Abortion is treated like a sin in this godforsaken conservative and dominantly Catholic country. Many people disagree, but it really doesn‚Äôt matter whether you agree or not. In the end, the decision should be up to the woman who‚Äôs pregnant. We shouldn‚Äôt have an opinion‚Äîjust understanding is enough. After all, it's her body, her life, her future, her choice. That's why I'll always firmly believe that abortion should be legal and safe. There are women‚Äîand even girls‚Äîwho are far too young, forced into pregnancy, still unstable, still trying to build their own lives, and completely unprepared to raise a child while chasing their dreams. Abortion is healthcare, and access to it is a basic reproductive right.This film captures that reality so loudly. It‚Äôs loud with the streets of Manila, with people‚Äôs judgment, with hypocrisy. You can hear it all so clearly‚Äîthe way society pushes women toward unreliable and dangerous methods like pamparegla in Quiapo or hilot, simply because abortion is condemned and proper reproductive healthcare is lacking. It‚Äôs so fucked up and heartbreaking. Tangina, ang hirap-hirap maging babae sa bansang ‚Äôto‚Äîsa mundong ‚Äôto.'Yung scene na walang filter na ipinakita ang estado ng public hospitals‚Äîmga serbisyong galing sa buwis ng tao pero hindi nila kayang ayusin‚Äîsobrang sakit panoorin. Sobrang bulok ng sistema natin. And there‚Äôs probably something even worse behind it‚Äîwe are so fucked.So when Sunshine finally went through with the abortion, I felt relieved. For a moment, I was scared she might keep the baby. Bringing a child into the world when you‚Äôre not ready‚Äîand being forced to give up your own dreams because of it‚Äîis one of the most cruel things you can do to yourself and to that child. And that‚Äôs exactly why choice matters.Gets ko na.

Drown out the noise.The double meaning behind this line in the film holds so much meaning. everything moving, heartbreaking, and gut wrenching has already been said about this film so i‚Äôll add my favorite short sequence that left me breathless:sunshine‚Äôs attempt at self-induced abortion was at this tiny raggedy inn room; a rule of thirds composition using the windows to divide the shot, sunshine in the rightmost basked in green light, which feels cold and lonely, away from the leftmost corner of the room lit in warm orange light emitting from a small lamp. she‚Äôs boxed and contained and helpless, it‚Äôs just her carrying the weight of her own problems and decisions. as she slowly carries out the procedure of the abortion, the train rolls by‚Äîloud and deafening‚Äîlike the heavy guilt and grief setting in. she can‚Äôt drown out the noise, she‚Äôs drowning in the noise of her troubled thoughts.(not great at writing and describing things sry but yeah the inn scenes were the start of my ugly sobbing throughout the movie)

beautiful, just absolutely beautiful ü•πthis has got to be one of the best filo movies i have ever watched, like EVER. i honestly cannot find the words right now but i have never felt so affected, like i was the one experiencing it. from sunshine drowning out the noise, to her practicing the last time (we see) before the olympics. all of this was just so beautiful, i felt her struggles and everything that happened to her.this movie made me tear up atleast 3 times. it was just so sad seeing the reality, and thinking that someone might be experiencing this - that this IS someones life. its sad, really to think about just how many women have to suffer and give up their lives, their DREAMS just because of this stupid anti abortion law. and its crazy how so much women have to go through suck risky procedures just to get rid of a baby. its not helping either that the philippines is a catholic/ christian heavy country. meaning that in their eyes, abortion is evil and murder. we see this in the film, and the film executed and protrayed it perfectly. we see how sunshine is slowly becomes confuse because why should sunshine apologize? if god is so forgiving, couldnt he forgive her for fighting for her dream? i am catholic but people who think that god wouldnt forgive women for aborting their children confuse me. also, i forgot to mention that we also see how sunshine prays before doing anything bad, just shows that she has some catholic guilt/ conscience.sunshine didnt even want a baby, was it her fault miguel didnt pull out? why should she be pressured to give birth when she never wanted it? think about it, why should women pay for mens incompetence? its crazy how so much men think that just because women carry the baby means that they have to carry all the burdens and troubles too, like hello? ure also a part of this too LOL. speaking of men, FUCK that bobot guy üñï sunshine was so right for what she did to him and i will forever defend her for that. but, lets not forget that this is the reality of some women. its just gross and inhumane. FUCK YOU BOBOT!! now lets talk about the people who supported sunshine along the way, starting with her sister. Honestly, with how close they were i was really surprised that sunshine never told her. all of their scenes were just so heart warming and it really just felt so comforting. i feel like she was someone that sunshine really needed at the time and yknow those words probably meant so much to sunshine. i got a little teary eyed during that scene cuz it was just so ü•πnext, the doctora. notice how it was a woman who risked her lisence and did everything to save the pregnant girl? yeah, thats what i call girlhood üòé but yeah, i was just so happy that someone, an actual stranger, reached out a helping hand. even though she had very little screentime, i really enjoyed her character and it really just showed that there are still some good people out there.moving on, we have the pregnant girl. her hug with sunshine absolutely made me cry. idk, maybe seeing someone going through the same things as her just brought some comfort like atleast theyre both in this together. her almost dying made me feel something, it was either goosebumps or just deadass misery.. i guess a HM would be the coach. (no i am not mentioning the kid cry about it üòí)overall, this was such a beautiful movie. i felt everything and it just captured the life of a filipina so well. just shows how much one person could be going through and how much a woman has to do to simply get rid of her baby. def watch this if you have time!!

this was so realistic. and also so realistic in showing how fucked up the system in our country really is.people say things like "paano kung 'yan yung maging susunod na president?", "paano kung 'yan yung makahanap ng cure sa ganito gan'yan?" when talking about a fetus that might be aborted, when those questions should honestly be applied more about kids who were forced to live a messed up system that was also because of adults, just like yung kay mary grace. her case happens a lot in real life. many children as young as 13 are forced to be pregnant and become mothers. like imagine, a 13 year old?? that's a kid. anddd hindi ko rin talaga magegets (and never will, honestly) yung mga tao na hindi pro-choice who doesn't care if pregnancy happened because of rape. tangina niyo. another thing, dahil nga illegal pa ang abortion in the philippines, a lot of kababaihan would resort to "pangpa-regla" and other unsafe procedures para lang makapag-abort. if the healthcare system truly cares about the people, why prioritize the "life" of a fetus, imbis na sa taong buhay and humihinga na? bakit kailangan pa silang maghirap? and i like annika's character here also symbolizing sunshine's guilt. kahit na parang desidido na talaga si sunshine noong una pa na she wouldn't keep the baby, there still lingers a feeling of guilt inside her, yunv parehong religious and personal guilt. and yung sa last part, her saying na "gets ko na"... ay, putangina, i love it.i really hope this movie would serve as an eye opener sa bansang 'to rsgarding abortion, and i also hope that people become more open-minded. sana maging legal na ang abortion. hay, tangina kayo

waited so long na maging available on digital 'yung movie na 'to and needless to say it was worth the wait because wtf ilang beses ako naiyaküò≠ from the depiction pa lang ng daily life sa pinas, the customs and norms we have, to the imaginary children representing the "could-have-beens", and also in a way, the girls' own guilt following them with every decision they try to make for a common situation that girls‚Äîespecially the young ones‚Äîsuffer through here sa bansa na 'to (not just the pregnancy itself but also the internal battles that come with religious guilt and having dreams beyond what other people would call as "a gift from God").na-bother lang ako sa texting scenes because ang random ng pag-type sa keyboard, but hindi mo na talaga maiisip 'yon at present sa sobrang daming na-tackle for such a short film. and yet it was done so beautifully. the pacing was SO GOOD and i couldn't help but fall in love with the cinematography, the WRITING, the ACTINGGG because of how natural the lines were delivered. kudos kay direk at pang top 4 films na ata 'to !!two takeaways for me dito: there's really no hate like christian love and seeing female solidarity in films will always make me cry. (pwede na 'to i-add sa films about girlhood bcs it would be my fav on the list).

nakakahiya mang aminin pero sa totoo lang, kahit bukas ako sa usapin at practice ng abortion, hindi ako lubusang sang-ayon dito. possibly, dahil lumaki ako sa sobrang relihiyoso at conservative na pamilya. isa pa, kahit ang mga professor ko na ilang taon nang naninilbihan sa hospital at komunidad ay hindi rin sang-ayon dito. ang mga courses namin na tinatackle ang morality at ethics sa field ng kalusugan ay wala rin klarong impormasyon ukol sa abortion dahil malaking debate pa rin ito. pero gets ko na.sobrang raw lang ng sunshine. sobrang totoo ng pagkaka depict sa maynila, sa mga karakter, lalo na sa mga ‚Äôirony‚Äô sa paniniwala at kilos ng lipunan natin. habang nanonood napaisip ako na shet oo nga? hindi tanggap ng marami ang aborsyon dahil predominantly isa tayong relihiyosong bansa. pero sa quiapo ang takbo ng mga babaeng naghahangad ng sagot at tulong para mawala ang kanilang dinadala. kuhang-kuha ni maris yung galit, yung dilemma, at yung guilt. ramdam yung galit niya sa jowa niya, sa hypocrisy ng mga tao, at sa sarili niya. kita rin yung bigat ng dilemma niya: pipiliin niya ba yung pangarap o yung anak niya? at higit sa lahat, yung guilt na meron siya sa pagbitaw sa bata na nasa sinapupunan niya.yung pagcapture sa estado ng mga bagong panganak at mga nanay sa public hospital, totoong-totoo. ang tapang rin nung klarong tema ng incest at rape, malalaki na isyu pero hindi napag-uusapan nang lantaran sa bansa natin.kaya ngayon, gets na gets ko na. Basta, ang take-away ko dito ay abortion should be safe, accessible, and legal for anyone despite of their circumstances‚Äîdahil karapatan din ng mga kababaihan ang maging malaya sa pagpili ng buhay na gusto nilang isabuhay.

By default, the film itself is already good enough with its intriguing but very necessary discussion on women's choices and how that still is an issue in the country.To discuss performances, though; Maris is consistently excellent on this one from start to finish‚Äîwithout a doubt. What's insane to me is the attention to detail that Antonette Jadaone has that even the random supporting characters manage to feel very convincing as real-world individuals that you get to converse with everyday.The film itself does not need to be ambitious (and by that, I mean unique, somewhat avant-garde) with its cinematography. The raw, authentic, and simple presentation sells the film's main themes and doesn't aim to be the main discussion.

marami akong nabasang theories na si Anika raw yung unborn child ni Sunshine. Pero sa interpretation ko, Anika represents Sunshine‚Äôs younger self, the child she used to be...nandoon s'ya sa mga moments na lost si Sunshine, parang comforting presence The film isn‚Äôt about Sunshine being pregnant at a young age. Instead, it serves as an eye-opener to the difficult realities in the Philippines, youth forced into responsibilities too early, lack of guidance, and the fear and shame surrounding conversations about teen pregnancy and reproductive health, like, the need for safe, accessible, free reproductive care. Hindi ito tungkol sa pag-encourage ng abortion, but about recognizing that young girls deserve proper education, protection, and safe options. Walang kabataan ang dapat mapahamak dahil sa kakulangan ng tamang impormasyon(edit)Omg, bigla ko lang narealize after everything: nung nakilala ni Anika si Arianna, tapos bigla siyang nawala nung nag-success yung abortion ni Rhed Bustamante‚Ä¶ doon ko na nakita yung deeper symbolism. Arianna disappeared the moment the abortion succeeded. Si Anika pala yung magiging anak sana ni Sunshine. The kids represent the unborn child. GETS KO NA

i wish for a world where women everywhere are able to have full autonomy over their bodies. one takeaway i got from Sunshine is how unlucky we are as women, and as filipinos, that abortion is still not a legal procedure. there are teen pregnancies in the Philippines that never get reported, especially when the abuser is a family member, something Sunshine portrayed painfully well.because that's what Sunshine is! it tackles harsh truths and realities of what it is like to be a woman (or a girl) in our predominantly conservative country. you can even say that Sunshine has highlighted the ugly parts of the Philippines‚Äô healthcare system. nakakalungkot that the average Filipino has a slim chance to experience high quality healthcare, because good service is often times a luxury‚Äîbawal sa mahihirap.i will admit that it's my bad that i often overlook the Filipino movie industry, but this movie allowed for more appreciation. it had brilliant direction and i was sincerely moved by how grounded it felt.i also really loved that Sunshine had a strong support system, her sister. i'm a little sensitive when it comes to siblings, and Jennica Garcia has reminded me of my own sisters. they're sisters who would stand by me in the same way. from my observation, Geleen has gone through a similar path, which is why she stands strongly beside Sunshine.gets na gets kita

Don't let the title fool you; ang bigat ng emotional weight ng movie na 'to. It felt less like a film and more like a camera pointed at a conversation na alam kong nangyayari million times in real life. The story went exactly where it needed to, pinakita talaga kung gaano ka-complex at messy ang ganitong discussions. That kind of situation is the hardest thing to navigate, and the movie didn't shy away from the awkward silences or yung masakit na feeling of having to draw a boundary. Ang ganda.And honestly, this was Maris Racal‚Äôs redemption arc, full stop. After all the ridiculous media noise trying to shame her for just being "normal" or "too real," this performance was her ultimate, quiet clapback. She showed up as this fully nuanced, complicated character, delivering every fragile, quiet moment with such authenticity. Hindi niya kailangang mag-effort or mag-glam up; she just let us breathe with her. It felt like she was finally allowed to breathe.I ended up loving it because it was brave enough to be sad and imperfect.

The girl can ACT, period.Second, this movie really shows the reality for so many Filipino women. It‚Äôs wild how we‚Äôre constantly being robbed of our choices. Religion getting shoved down our throats every five seconds, the government acting like women‚Äôs health isn‚Äôt even part of their job. Sometimes it really feels like the PH is just‚Ä¶ anti-women. And it‚Äôs honestly so frustrating. I just hope things change soon, because it‚Äôs not about religion or ‚Äúmorals‚Äù all the time. It‚Äôs about actually having the choice, the chance to do what‚Äôs right and do it safely. Not end up risking your life because you had no real options.This is lowkey turning into a whole debate, but whatever. I really hope this movie opens people‚Äôs eyes. Though let‚Äôs be real, some folks will still twist the message or straight up miss the point‚Ä¶ or maybe they‚Äôre just stupid af. Anyway, Sunshine hits hard, and it hits exactly where it needs to.

Entry #2, less of a movie review and more of a rambling on how this movie helped trigger a reflection on how I process my own emotions as a woman haha.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Sidenote, but there's something abt Sunshine's self-restraint that makes me want to cry.When she finally confronts Miggy, she doesn't start beating him up or screaming at him. Instead, she simply says that she's pregnant, as if she should be ashamed that she needs to talk to Miggy about it.And you can see why, the moment her frustrations start bubbling up, Miggy tells her to calm down. Miggy even leaves before he gets a full taste of her wrath.Oh my god. It reassured me so much that people who hold themselves back during confrontation aren't any less brave, or deep, or strong. It's just that we've been societally conditioned to always be the better person. Always consider the emotions of the person you're talking to.And maybe, much like Sunshine, I know it's a hopeless cause.It echoes how I've dealt with family and situations I've felt misunderstood by. Why communicate with someone who can't be communicated with? Why escalate the situation? Why be vulnerable with someone who doesn't know how to handle it? Yung nasa debate team ako, at ang hahaba haba ng letterdbox reviews ko, pero kunting sigaw lang sa akin natatameme na ako. It's especially disappointing when you've already communicated with them in the past and they don't change. Sabay na sa sakit ng concern mo yung kahihiyan ng pag-express mo ng damdamin sa wala. Sabay na yung disappointment na hindi humihigit pag-ibig nila sa bad habits nila. (LUH, SAAN YON NANGGALING COUGH COUGH)And what's left is I leave those situations much like Sunshine, with so many unsaid words and emotions bubbling underneath the surface that I want to smash someone's car. Even my unsaid thoughts get clouded by me almost instinctually trying to put myself in the other person's shoes, or trying to understand where I went wrong and how to do better next time. Then suddenly, even in the privacy of my own headspace, I can't process my own emotions. Suddenly, even long after the moment has passed, I feel less whole and less human.I was raised to never raise my voice. And I have a subtle respect yet envy for women who do. A small, conservative part of my brain goes, "You know we're not allowed to shout, right? Why can't you be the better person?"But maybe it IS possible to strike a balance between communicating your concerns with someone and still being sensitive with their emotions.Maybe it's not such a hopeless cause.

PHENOMENAL, DIREK TONET AND MARIS.‚Äúnaiintindihan mo na ba ako?‚Äù‚Äúgets ko na‚ÄùSANA MAS MARAMING MAKA GETS!!

I have a lot of feelings to share about this beautiful and heartbreaking film. Truly a big eye-opener to many Filipinos.Women carry a biological physical pain we are given the moment we are born. Period, childbirth, postpartum, etc. But we also carry the pain this world and men cause. The pain men should be held accountable for. Emotional labour, cultural and religious expectations, rape, pregnancy, forms of abuse, etc. It's like our suffering is pre-written, pre-approved, and expected. And yet the world still has all the audacity to treat us as if we're lesser, fragile, dramatic, overreacting. I think I will never be able to understand the logic of a world that demands strength from women and then punishes us for being strong.Like Sunshine and Menggay, a lot of women out there don't have choices. A lot of women are already deprived of basic rights before they even learn to speak. But then again, society still keeps finding new ways to take more from them.The hypocrisy of the Filipinos in this film is also insane but couldn‚Äôt be more well depicted. (It‚Äôs actually so much worse in real life.) Filipinos will praise God with one hand and strip women of autonomy with the other. Anti-abortion because ‚ÄúGod said so,‚Äù but silent about abuse, poverty, rape cases, or the girls forced into motherhood long before they even have the chance to understand themselves. They defend unborn children better than they defend the living women who have to endure the burden of carrying them. Because if they don‚Äôt, you will judge them. You will shame them. How is that love? How is that morality? Abortion is criminalized, but sexual abuse cases get dismissed.It‚Äôs exhausting. It‚Äôs enraging.To all of the Sunshines out there, gets na gets ko kayong lahat. The world keeps underestimating and shaming us, but here we are, still standing, still surviving.To end this, I want to share that one monologue in Fleabag that came back to me after watching this film and inspired my entire review:"Women are born with pain built in. It's our physical destiny‚Äîperiod pains, sore boobs, childbirth. We carry it within ourselves throughout our lives. Men don't. They have to seek it out. They invent all these gods and demons so they can feel guilty about things, which is something we do very well on our own. And then they create wars so they can feel things and touch each other and when there aren't any wars they can play rugby. We have it all going on in here, inside. We have pain on a cycle for years and years and years, and then just when you feel you are making peace with it all, what happens? The menopause comes. The fucking menopause comes and it is the most wonderful fucking thing in the world. Yes, your entire pelvic floor crumbles and you get fucking hot and no one cares, but then you're free. No longer a slave, no longer a machine with parts. You're just a person."
LEGALIZE ABORTION NOW!!!!!!

since sunshine is on netflix and can now reach wider audiences, i DESPERATELY hope this film radicalizes everybody about how unreliable our health-care system is especially for women. pregnancy is often treated as a one-way situation in which a woman becomes a mother (regardless if the man even acknowledges it) all because we are driven by misogynist, fascist, religious (derogatory) society and it's time we drift away from that system. our progress is beyond long overdue. sunshine and menggay are just two out of the thousands‚Äîmaybe even millions‚Äîof filipino women experiencing unwanted/accidental pregnancy everyday. just imagine how many of them had to put their lives on the line to go through unsafe abortion practices and how many of them are housing children while not being ready in any means. all because the fucking government thinks abortion is an ungodly act. nakaka-tangina talaga ang gobyerno.ps. maris was SO good in this ykw i always believed in her!!!!! idc

Gets.I was gonna leave it there but I have thoughts so full steam ahead‚ÄîManila is a staple in almost every Filipino film, being the capital and all, but rather than the large city itself‚Äî Sunshine specifically captures the essence of Quiapo so well. The bustling markets, the overcrowd and kids begging for alms, and religion is embedded everywhere‚Äî whether it be its churches, the posters within the buildings, street stalls selling rebultos and rosaries, or the people themselves. I don't usually care for the setting of the story but I always think it's smart when it actually helps drive the narrative forward, so I find this neat little aspect of the film amusing (also, while we're at it, props to whoever the prod designer is wow). I watched this at 3AM during a vigil so I had all the time to read other reviews and can I just say, while I understand how it could be viewed as such‚Äî I don't think this film was didactic or propaganda. I love films that open conversations and Sunshine opened a lot, but more than the conversations it opened, I love how the center of it has always been women. The heart of Sunshine is Sunshine herself, and Maris Racal definitely gave the performance of a lifetime in this one. The fact that she filmed this the same time as Can't Buy Me Love is insane, talk about range.Also, props to Direk Tonet 'cause I have only watched this film a day before, but it is so dear to my heart. Pangarap ko ang pangarap mo, Sunshine <333PS.Also, whoever decided to cast Piolo Pascual and Elijah Canlas sa father and son deserves a raise.

ilang taon ka na ba? ba't andami mong alam?in a society where age is almost always equated to maturity, even victims like sunshine herself fall prey to a system that keeps information that they need inaccessible‚Äîjust because certain topics like sex education are deemed unfit for the youth. as a result, generations of filipinos grew up and continue to grow up without the right tools on handling such discussions. even our own parents never knew how to properly teach us regarding sex‚Äîbecause those tools have always been gatekept for some conservative reason.it also mirrors how this lost to magellan for that coveted philippine oscar submission. an academy award would've been a bonus, and a nomination would've been a long shot‚Äîbut i reckon its campaign alone would've already led overseas conversations on female reproductive healthcare particularly here in the philippines.i'm glad i experienced this the first time in the theater. i'm thankful i get to watch it again in my tv. i remember it being grittier and noisier on my first watch, what with the film being drenched in the cruel acoustics of the ever-unyielding quiapo district. upon second watch, however, the film feels emotionally subtler, remembering to pause for quieter moments to drown out the noise when it gets too heavy or intense, and the trucks that tread along carriedo hiss fiercer. it steadily permits you aboard the world of maris racal's sunshine, allowing you to feel her feelings, especially the humane ones. even for such a grounded film, it's surprisingly hopeful, just like the kind of light the film's protagonist is named after.

sobrang hirap maging babae lalo na sa pilipinas tangina. this film is so raw: mula sa mga babaeng hindi pa handa maging magulang at walang reproductive or at least karapatan mag na desisyon para sa sarili na nag reresort sa unsafe, illegal means to abort their babies. ‚Äòyung kamahalan ng mga abortion pills, kung paano sila hinuhusgahan, kinakahiya, at pinagdadamutan ng tulong lalo na ng mga prupesyonal. pinipilit na sundin ang takda ng relihiyon, batas, at gobyerno. sobrang hirap maging magulang kapag walang pera. sobrang hirap maging nanay nang mag-isa. at sa kahit saang aspeto, sobrang sama ng tingin sa mga babae; nabuntis ka at nagpa-abort, o kahit pa buntis ka at kineep mo, sa‚Äôyo pa rin ang sisi. kahit pa ‚Äòyung bumuntis sa‚Äôyo ang gago. kahit pa pareho naman kayong hindi pa handa maging magulang.sa movie napakita din na ‚Äòyung mga may bayag, relihiyoso, at mayayaman pa ang pinaka-gustong ituloy ‚Äòyung pagbubuntis ni sunshine eh tangina ayaw nga niya eh. hindi ba puwedeng desidido ka lang at hindi laging pera ang dahilan?hirap maging babae hanggang ngayon. sa sobrang hirap dire-diretso ko ‚Äòtong tinype nang ‚Äòdi iniiisip kung coherent pa ‚Äòtong review ko. bahala kayo tangina basta maganda ‚Äòyung movie. tagos sa puso, realistic, totoong-totoo.

This film was such a hard watch. I found myself taking breaks in between the scenes that struck deepest, especially as a young woman in a country where you can be punished simply for existing in a female body. It made me sit with an unsettling truth‚Äî in this supposedly modern year 2025, the progress of feminism still feels painfully small. Women are still scraping by, still fighting to breathe, still surviving in impossible circumstances caged by situations we are put into just because we're girls. </3

Gets mo ba?one of the best movie i watched this year. heard many good reviews abt it and it did not dissapoint! like damn the plot, the injected social commentaries, the actors, all of these factors really helped the movie to be so great.although the plot is not something i could really relate to kasi never naman ako najontis. as someone who aspires to be a doctor, this really made me re-think the specialization i want to take in the future. this made me eager to help women more. like tangina nung doctor na matanda, co-gender at nasa OBGYN pa tapos ganon umasta.the kid "annika" is the character that stick to me the most aside from‚Äîof course, yung bida na si sunshine. i think we all have different interpretations about the kid and sunshine, but i interpret the kid as "us" or the viewers. Kasi the whole movie, we saw and witness sunshine's dream and struggles trying to abort the child. The "gets ko na" is one of the scene na 'di ko makalimutan. Kasi nung sinabi niya 'yon, we also did‚Äîna-gets na rin natin.the implied abortion was symbolic for me kasi aside from sunshine reaching her dreams (to compete), it also shows the contrast of her (sunshine) experience to Rhed's. Kasi deba, Rhed's abortion experience was done illegaly, while hers was a second try pero done by an actual professional. it is implied, but it shows the two endings of getting an abortion. Na kaya naman pala sa maayos at ligtas na paaran para mag pa-abort. This is the result if abortion is legalized here in the Philippines. Walang babae ang mag-ririsk ng buhay para lang malaglag ang dinadala nila, at walang babae ang nagdudusa at mawawalan ng pangarap.

Good social commentary on the Filipino society of the stigma women go through even when considering an abortion. Shame is everywhere (older women, men, and religious folk) and the only people around her that can help are younger women who understand. Ang sarap din sapakin ng mga tao sa paligid ni Sunshine.Being torn between the people with your shared beliefs around you and your dreams, is a difficult problem to bear.The atmosphere is so jarring even though it reflects our own reality, the symbolism of the child being her conscience...Maris Racal did an amazing job of playing Sunshine and to co, for making the atmosphere feel believable.

things that pissed me off while watching this film:‚Ä¢ the government (as usual)‚Ä¢ public hospitals na pinabayaan like background character‚Ä¢ men whose only contribution is‚Ä¶ well, you know‚Ä¢ religious people na mas invested sa moral panic kaysa sa actual people‚Ä¢ women being denied control over their own bodies‚Ä¢ rapists ‚Äî rot in hellanyway. this film? pure womanhood. exactly what the trailer promised: rage, softness, grief, strength ‚Äî all in one. love that it shows women surviving and thriving without needing a man (derogatory). hate that the government remains allergic to understanding the female body, mostly because the people in power are men (derogatory) who treat women‚Äôs voices like background noise. but the real heart of it? women helping women. women supporting women. women saving women. that solidarity??? that‚Äôs cinema. that‚Äôs the entire point. and that‚Äôs exactly what I wanted to see. I adore women like Sunshine ‚Äî loud, brave, unbothered, and done with everyone‚Äôs bullshit. women who refuse to be silenced. women who know their worth. women who fight for each other.

‚Äúdrown out the noise.‚Äù but for sunshine, the noise is impossible to silence. and perhaps that‚Äôs the point !!sunshine drops you right into the chaos of manila‚Äôs slums‚Äîthe blaring streets, the pollution you can taste, the constant fight to find your place in a city that refuses to make space for you. it‚Äôs loud, messy, heavy, and honestly, so beautifully shot it almost hurts. the film doesn‚Äôt sugarcoat what it means to grow up on the poor side of the metro. instead, it immerses you right into the confusion, the grit, and the impossibility of finding your way through everything that tries to block your path.also, one thing that dir. jadaone nails is the film‚Äôs cinematography. the visuals don‚Äôt just accompany the story‚Äîthey carry its heartbeat. the way the camera moves, the grime-colored palette, etc.. it all builds an atmosphere that makes you feel like you‚Äôre right there with sunshine, breathing the same heavy air. but here‚Äôs where my frustration kicks in: sometimes it felt like it was the coach who dreamed of the olympics more than sunshine herself. it is as if her ambitions weren‚Äôt fully her own. and then there‚Äôs this big question: how is sunshine on her way to becoming an olympian when no one seems to recognize her outside? no hype, no chatter, no community buzz ??? who is she really in the world beyond ??? the film teases her potential but never quite anchors her identity in reality. the movie also strongly exposes how messed up the ph public health system is. watching the overcrowded hospital and the beds practically stacked on top of each other, is just infuriating. women deserve comfort, yet the film shows how even those basic things become luxuries.though, what kept my heart in the film was ate geleen. i hope every sunshine out there has someone like her !!!!! someone steady, warm, and willing to hold space when everything else is collapsing. and on the opposite end of the spectrum: miggy üñïüèª i hope every miggy rots in hell. women deserve better than being tossed out of the bus like a trash. GROW A SPINE.sunshine is messy, raw, and chaotic. maybe that‚Äôs exactly why it lingers. it perfectly captures a world that feels too loud to ignore even when the characters try to drown it out.it‚Äôs not perfect, but it hits hard where it matters.

After watching the film (thrice this year), it has become clear that such issues are far more complex than simply being immoral, illegal, or against certain religious beliefs. Some beliefs are held as non-negotiable, no matter how liberal or progressive the world becomes. But the reality for women like Sunshine is that restrictive laws can make life dangerous.Morality, legality, and lived experience are not the same. Laws may make something illegal, but they don‚Äôt erase the underlying reality or the demand for care and safety. Sunshine‚Äôs story embodies this tension. She had access to a supportive family and a thriving career as gymnast, yet the illegality of abortion forced her into danger. Clearly, a systemic failure.People will always find ways to survive, and without proper regulation, it becomes deadly. The existence of quack clinics, ‚Äúhilots,‚Äù and underground networks is proof of systemic neglect, not moral failure of individuals.I hope many legislators, lawmakers, leaders, or whatever we call them, see this film.

What a film. Putangina.Perfectly executed, anxiety-inducing, and so full of rage, anger, and love that it‚Äôs almost hard to breathe through it. Dare I say the most important film of our generation? And Maris holy shit, that was one of the best performances I‚Äôve seen in the last ten years. Raw, terrifying, and painfully real.I know I‚Äôll never fully understand the complexities of what women go through, and that‚Äôs exactly why films like Sunshine hit this hard. They ground us in stories that have always existed, stories that deserve to be acknowledged, stories that some films, especially in the Philippines, hesitate to touch.Sunshine doesn‚Äôt just tell a story, it makes you feel it in your chest. It sits with you, heavy and unshakeable. And maybe that‚Äôs the point, to leave you changed, even just a little, and to make sure these truths are never brushed aside again. And if cinema has any purpose at all, it's to let us feel the world through someone else's skin, even for just a moment.Philippine healthcare is genuinely fucked. We‚Äôve talked about it for years, we scream it straight into their faces, and still, nothing changes. But good fucking god, when will this finally get better? Tangina naman, ilang pelikula pa ba ang kailangan nyo?

This picture didn't impose or preach, it showed the reality. This unacceptable reality where women doesn't even have a choice regarding their own bodies. let me sit and reflect for a moment, babalik ako kasi what the fuck, gets ko na.. . . edit:mula sa viewpoint ng madamdaming babaeng walang ibang gusto kung 'di mabigyang atensyon ang mga pangangailangan ng mga kapwa babae, gets na gets.sa daming pelikulang pilipino na napanood ko, ngayon lang nagmukhang malumanay at mabait ang maynila. 'yung maingay at magulo na mundo ng kamaynilaan, naging komportable at nagmukhang tahimik para sa aligagang dalagang naghahanap ng tulong. i've only had nothing but depressing thoughts when i'm in manila, pero kay sunshine at sa kalagayan niya, the place looked ironically full of hope.sunshine successfully represented the women of the philippines. sa mundong palaging dessert ang patriarchy sa hapag kainan, patuloy na nalulunod ang mga boses at pangangailangan ng mga kababaihan. mapapatanong ka na lang talaga kung ga'no pa ba katagal bago tuluyang buksan ang pinto para sa mga nakatagong karapatan at sagot sa mga hiling ng mga babae.i love womanhood and i love fighting for our rights. masaya lang akong tumatango sa mga desisyon ni sunshine at pinagmumura ang mga lalaking sumusubok pigilan siya. gets kita, sunshine, kasama mo 'ko sa laban.what a thought provoking film. oh, how i love you antoinette jadaone. you just never fail.ipaglaban ang boses ng kababaihan! ipaglaban ang karapatan! you have one hell of a big place in my heart, sunshine (2024). i have so many things to say. i fear i won't even stop talking about you, sunshine. you are so dearly loved by me.

this film felt like getting hit in the chest and then hugged after. sunshine isn‚Äôt just a story, it‚Äôs a mirror held up to every girl who grew up being told to keep quiet, to behave, to carry consequences that were never ours alone. i swear i felt my throat close up in half the scenes.there‚Äôs this painfully ironic moment that won‚Äôt leave my brain. sellers of ab0rtifacients literally standing in front of the church like it‚Äôs just another day. the hypocrisy is crazy. the shame is pushed on women but the system keeps handing out the same cycles on the sidewalk. the film knew exactly what it was doing there.and maris racal . . . oh my god. she didn‚Äôt act like sunshine, she was sunshine. the fear in her eyes, the softness, the way she held her sadness like it might spill. she carried the whole emotional weight of the story so naturally it hurt. this is one of her strongest performances and you can fight me on that.what hit me the most is how the movie never backed down from the truth. that women‚Äôs bodies are theirs and they are the ones to decide what to do with it. full stop. no guilt, no shame, just autonomy in its rawest form.sunshine is the kind of film that stays in your chest long after the credits end. it‚Äôs heavy but it‚Äôs also hope. a reminder that girls like sunshine deserve softness, choices, and safety. always.

sinusulat ko 'to habang 'di pa tuyo ang mga luha ko.bilang bakla, requirement ang pagiging feminist, pagiging pro-women dahil ang mga karanasan natin magkakarugtong. akala ko naintindihan ko na, hindi pa pala.sa dami ng kwento nabasa at mga anekdota na narinig ko na tungkol sa parehong problema, akala ko sapat na yon para malugar yung sarili ko sa posisyon nila. hindi pa pala.napakahalaga ng pelikula. kahit saglit lang, naparamdam niya sa akin yung dilim na dulot ng pagkakaroon ng sinapupunan pero lalo na yung makulong ka sa mga utos ng lipunan. in fact, kinailangan kong itigil saglit yung pelikula dahil nahilo at bumigat yung katawan ko sa eksena kung saan nasa kwarto siya. hindi lang dahil sa proseso na gagawin niya kundi pati sa desperasyon na nagawa niyang maipakita.sa pagbagsak ng pangarap niya, sa galit sa sumabog dahil sa sarili at sa mga misogonistasa kawalan niya ng pag-asa, sa pagkapit sa talimsa hirap na sarilinin yung problemabinigyan nito ng konteksto, binigyan nito ng pangalan, at binigyan nito ng buhay ang lahat ng sunshine na gusto lang makalaya at mabigyan ng karapatan na magdesisyon para sa sariling kapakanan.ka-eme ako pero kahit hindi, TANGINA ang galing ni direk tonet. ito ang pelikula, may mensahe, may puso, at may adbokasiya.tamang tama ang paglabas nito sa streaming platforms sa pagsisimula ng anti-vawc campaign. sana marami pang makapanood nito, lalo na ng hindi pa nakakaintindi sa pinaglalaban natin.sana magets niyo na.

choice is a right, not a privilege someone else gives you!nakakapagod na hanggang ngayon kailangan pang ipagpilitan ng kababaihan na may karapatan sila sa sarili nilang katawan. Sunshine shows exactly how cruel it is when a system decides for you‚Äîkung paano ka nito tinatanggalan ng pangarap, boses, at kontrol, habang lahat ng tao sa paligid mo ay may opinyon pero walang pakialam sa bigat na ikaw ang nagdadala.si Sunshine, hindi siya nagmamagaling, hindi siya nagpa-paawa‚Äîpinapakita lang niya kung gaano ka-unfair na ang isang babae kailangan pang dumaan sa sakit, hiya, at panghuhusga bago payagang magdesisyon para sa sarili. yung choice na dapat normal lang, pero ginagawa pang kasalanan.and ang nakakainis pa dito yang mga rapists at mga irresponsible na nagbuntis, madalas walang consequences, walang accountability, pero yung girl, siya pa ang pinipilit na magtiis at magdala ng pasaning hindi niya pinili.nakakainis din yung point na mas inuuna nila yung thought ng ‚Äúbaby‚Äù kesa sa babaeng mismong nagdadala nito ‚Äî kahit alam nilang pwedeng mentally unstable, financially unprepared, o walang tunay na support. laging religion at morality ang ginagamit nilang justification, pero wala namang konkretong tulong sa taong talagang naghihirap.Sunshine survives not because she‚Äôs fearless, but because she refuses to let the world define what she should do with her life. and yun yung ayaw tanggapin ng mga taong takot sa idea na may kontrol pa rin ang mga babae sa mga sarili nila.

such an amazing movie. the story and the acting were top notch. again, another topic that i wished was talked about more in the philippines, a very conservative country. this could help a lot of young girls.

‚ÄúPangarap ko rin ang mga pangarap mo, Sunshine.‚ÄùAng sakit panoorin si Sunshine habang kinakain siya ng mundo na may opinion sa katawan niya ‚Äî a world that tells her what to do, what to be, what to sacrifice. Pero the film reminds you: walang mas mali kaysa pilitin ang isang babae mabuhay sa buhay na hindi niya pinili.Ramdam na ramdam yung paninindigan. ‚ÄúPro-choice‚Äù; it lives inside the everyday moments that prove why choice matters. Yung pagod. Yung takot. Yung guilt na hindi naman dapat sa‚Äôyo ibinibigay. Yung simpleng hiling na kung ano ang sa akin, akin pa rin dapat ang huling salita.And when Sunshine finally chooses herself ‚Äî hindi bilang martyr, hindi bilang symbol ‚Äî kundi bilang isang babae na may karapatang mahalin ang sarili niyang buhay at ang kanyang pangarap na maging gymnast. Grabe. Para akong sinampal nang may lambing.This film isn‚Äôt about abortion alone.It‚Äôs about agency, dignity, and the quiet power of choosing herself and her aspirations.Antoinette Jadaone gave us a story that doesn‚Äôt just ask for empathy ‚Äî it demands respect for the lives women build, unbuild, and choose.

one word, powerfullakas ng mensahe ng pelikula nito. it was raw, authentic, and it was worth the wait. even as a man of this patriarchal society, the feeling that the movie left me with was like a scar. context palang, nakikita natin kung gaano kalubha ung sistema natin dito sa Pilipinas. kahit ilang bills pa yan ang naipasa, di parin mawawala ang traditional views natin dahil sa influence ng catholic church. at pati nga ba naman sa sarili natin komunidad, mahirap ito pag-usapan and that‚Äôs fucked up. sobrang gold ung acting dito ni Maris Racal, it felt like she was made for that role. i also like that small detail of her ribbon being called as baby. when she performs with it, she was free. away from the problems and away from reality. other actors such as si Annika Co was also great, left with that last scene of the line ‚ÄúGets mo ba?‚Äù. it was at that moment that her character knew why she had to do it. although the ending was for the viewers to interpret, we can already by that scene that she did aborted it.AND GOD THE CINEMATOGRAPHY! sobrang naappreciate ko kung paano ipinakita ang Manila. parang di ka makakahinga sa choice of compositions nila. especially the set designs of the Maternity Ward and Sunshine‚Äôs House, it speaks a lot on the character‚Äôs lifestyle and what could be the reality for the struggling women out there especially in the Philippines.to conclude my not so ‚Äúperformative‚Äù but appreciation on the film. Sunshine left me with lesson to pause, to reflect, and to understand. with this film, this could change how our people would see abortion to some deeper context :)

Gets ko na.Sobrang ganda ng pelikula mo, Direk :( To approach such a controversial topic this way and show the raw and lived experiences of women in the Philippines who are willing to put their lives on the line for something that the government is robbing us of. Sobrang mahal na mahal ko ang mga babae sa pelikula na ito, lalo na si Sunshine. Ang hirap maging babae sa sistema na walang pakielam sa'yo at sa kalagayan mo. Fuck men and fuck rapists, fuck the religious and conservative, far-right people who care more about the lives of unborn fetuses than the lives of women and children, fuck the government and the healthcare system, and fuck everyone who thinks they have a right to a woman's body and choices. Tangina niyong lahat.The movie was so powerful and was delivered and portrayed beautifully by Miss Ma'am Maris Racal, sobrang galing umarte, kuhang kuha niya ang puso ko bilang Sunshine. Sana sa palabas na 'to ay mamulat ang mata ng gobyerno at ng sistema to how much and to what extent a woman is willing to do, even at the risk of her own safety, for something she truly doesn't want. Sana sa palabas na 'to, magalit ang mga tao sa sistema na patuloy pinagtutulakan sa'tin mga babae. What if siya ang makakadiscover ng cure ng cancer? Well, fuck you. What if hampasin kita ng bote sa ulo? Sana patuloy tayong magalit at ipaglaban ang mga sarili natin sa mga idelohiya na dinidiin sa'tin, all while completely disregarding our opinions and beliefs. Sana magets niyo na rin.Sobrang galing, direk, and Miss Maris Racal. :( To have this film in this time and age shows na this is a movement and patuloy dapat nating nilalaban para maiwasan ang mga nangyari kila Sunshine. Also, shoutout sa'yo Dok Helena, I aspire to be a doctor like you in the future.Mahal ko 'tong pelikula na ito :(

an emotional, poignant, and a heavy watch.I have a lot of things to say yet I can't fathom it into words. Sobrang tagal na since umiyak ako sa isang local film (well, I don't really watch a lot, but I'll catch up, pramis üò≠) Maybe the reason why I got so emotional is that I think I already met a Sunshine in my exposure to hospital. Makikita mo yun sa mata nila, that aggravating emptiness that lingers. I am an empath for women like Sunshine and Menggay ‚Äî is it really justifiable that the corrupt system continues to villainize them despite the much bigger concerns like child neglect and abuse which were very well presented in the film? Tho I can't fully comprehend the root of this mindset, but that is something to ponder on. +++ Kudos to the director for tackling such sensitive and fragile topic, despite the imposed opposition of many people

ang hirap maging babae. ang hirap maging mahirap. ang hirap maging pilipino. taena filipino movie of the year. no f words. tbf in depth review sadyang balisa ako after the movie wtf‚Ä¶ ang galing ni maris. ang galing ng plot. ang galing ng build up. ang daming nangyari. ang galing mo direk antoinette. brb !!!!! wtfedit:ok here goes..i would say that the movie was so uncomfortable.. in the best way possible‚Ä¶ gets?sobrang raw ng pelikula. simula palang, hinagis na agad tayo sa gulo (kalye, quiapo, yung typical manila setting, the life in manila outside bgc) hindi nito sinubukan na maging malinis, aesthetic, or cinematic just for the sake of it. it might look so all over the place but the movie is alive. it was shaky .. and that‚Äôs why it feels so real. hindi kinailangan mag romanticize ng mga bagay. that honesty is what makes the film hit deeper.if you‚Äôre the type of person who lives in black and white, there‚Äôs like a hundred chance the movie won‚Äôt make sense to you. or it does, pero you would think that the movie is forcing you to pick sides. kung sino ba ang bida ?? at kontrabida?? or kung kanino ka ba dapat kumampi. instead, IT SITS IN THE GREY AREA. that tiny gap where life actually happens. it showed how people can be both good and bad at the same time and how our choices aren‚Äôt always noble. it showed how circumstances shape people in wags we don‚Äôt always understand. especially if hindi ka babae. hindi ka mahirap. or hindi ka pilipino (hehe) this movie is so fawking brave. knowing that we‚Äôre a religious country and literally one of the few places left na anti-abortion pa rin‚Ä¶ ANLAKAS MO, DIREK TONET!!!!! gets ko na bat nagkaron discourse sa intrepretation ni bini jho‚Ä¶ medyo alanganin nga thoughts nya sa movie xDd pero to be fair, hindi rin naman talaga to yung type ng movie na straightforward unlike any other contemporary films. like you actually have to sit with the discomfort and think about what the movie is trying to say.okkk detailsss‚Ä¶ sa character ni sunshine, taliwas sya sa karaniwan nating nakikita na representation ng isang babae. hindi sya mahinhin, marupok, or tatanga tanga sa pag ibig. hindi rin naman sya yung overly empowered, high functioning, girlboss woman. if there‚Äôs a third kind, sunshine is that girl. the type of woman who‚Äôs allowed to be messy. yung walang sinusunod na rules. which is i think, the most realistic representation of being a woman. she‚Äôs a flawed character, in a way that makes the movie more authentic. hindi nag eexist ang karakter nya para mag serve as inspiration or moral lesson. she exists as a person who is shaped by an unjust system that we have. to be continued LALA I HAVE SO MUCH TO SAY U GUYS

‚ÄéA woman is more than a mother and a wife. A woman can have a life, passion and dreams other than giving birth and creating a family. A woman can desire a life of her own without a child in the picture. She has a brain, a heart, and a soul that can yearn for a greater life; she is more than just her womb. And that is fine, if a woman decides to prioritize her own ambitions instead of being chained to traditional norms, then so be it‚Äî it's her life. ‚Äé‚ÄéWe should never push our own values and ideals to someone that is living their own life. If they're not ready for a child, they aren't. A living and breathing woman's choice should speak louder than an unborn, lifeless fetus. Even if their decision is against our principle, at the end of the day, it is healthier to have them choose than seeing them losing it all together. ‚Äé‚ÄéWomen are already suffering from a lot of judgement, abuse and maltreatment on the daily; the least we need is people dictating our choices and deciding our own lives for us‚ÄîLet alone having people that know nothing about a woman's body making the rules.‚Äé‚ÄéNapaka-imposible mabuhay nang madali bilang babae sa mundong ating ginagalawan ngayon. Ang natatanging tulong na p‚Äôwede nating gawin ay ang pagbuo ng ligtas at payapang komunidad para sa ating mga kababaihan.

THIS FILM NEEDS TO BE DISTRIBUTED INTERNATIONALLY!!! I don‚Äôt think a film has moved me this much in centuries‚Ä¶Words CANNOT encompass how I feel right now. This film is relevant, powerful, and painfully raw. Jadaone proves yet again what a tremendous director she is, showing clearly how religious culture and broken healthcare systems fail women in the Philippines. The absence of support for abortion is front and centre throughout. And Maris Racal BRUHHHHHHH just astounding asf. Her despair and desperation were palpable‚Ä¶such an impressive, intense performance, definitely a career milestone for her! Not to mention how beautifully shot this film was OMG, the colours were so lush. It captured Manila‚Äôs imperfections and rough edges so well, and Sunshine‚Äôs kindness and determination to find a solution became this quiet metaphor for sunlight breaking through the darkest of places. Women should always have the right to full autonomy over their bodies, and this film conveyed that with absolute clarity.
