i originally planned to watch this last july but sadly, i had no time to‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs why when i learned it‚Äôd be coming to netflix, i was so fucking happy! i‚Äôm glad it didn‚Äôt take too long for the film to be digitally streamed after its release here in the ph theaters, but now that i have finished watching it and learning how truly great this film was, i regret not being able to experience watching it in a theater with fellow friends and women‚Ä¶this is exactly how films should spark conversations, and i‚Äôm genuinely thankful this exists and will continue to reach a wider audience. this film is brave, raw, and honestly courageous in the way it speaks for women and directly to society. it rawly and flawlessly tackles teenage pregnancy, abortion, and religious guilt without sugarcoating anything. this is one of those films that women will understand on a deeper level, especially filipino women, because it reflects lived realities we rarely see shown this honestly. so huge respect and thanks to ms. antoinette jadaone for creating this masterpiece.the way society treats women here is so unfair, and the film doesn‚Äôt shy away from showing that; it was unapologetically real. it‚Äôs honestly exhausting how women are judged before they‚Äôre even heard, and this film finally pushes back against that! and at its core, it reminds everyone of something so simple but often ignored: women are people first. so it also hurt to watch how much empathy only came from fellow women‚Äîdoctors, mothers, strangers‚Äîwomen who just ‚Äòknew.‚Äô those scenes in the maternity ward especially, where women help and understand each other without needing explanations, were deeply emotional‚Ä¶ i also loved how realistically they showed manila; it‚Äôs always busy and full of (ordinary) people, it‚Äôs messy, and you would always see the traffic and the smoke and hear how loud the sounds of vehicles are. the cinematography and score were also beautiful, especially during sunshine‚Äôs performances, where you can feel her focus and desperation all at once. and maris racal, the actress i never once doubted, delivered a raw, natural, and phenomenal performance as sunshine; she did a very great job bringing this powerful story to life. i just hope more people watch it, talk about it, and sit with the discomfort it brings, because that‚Äôs where real understanding truly starts.

First of all, I know that this movie premiered at the 49th Toronto International Film Festival in 2024 and arrived in Philippine cinemas 4 months ago. And now that it finally dropped on Netflix‚Ä¶ I hope I‚Äôm not too late to say it finally: This movie is powerful üò≠üíØAntoinette Jadaone delivers one of her most fearless films yet with ‚Äòùó¶ùòÇùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóªùó≤‚Äô ‚Äî a coming-of-age sports drama that hits with quiet power and emotional honesty.Maris Racal plays the titular character, a young gymnast on the road to the Olympics. Her world revolves around discipline, repetition, and the dream of making it to the competition she‚Äôs trained her whole life for. But when she discovers she‚Äôs pregnant, her perfectly controlled world cracks open.What I loved about the film is how it never sensationalizes her situation. Sunshine‚Äôs fear is treated with quiet realism. The movie acknowledges how complicated teenage pregnancy is, especially in a society where abortion, reproductive rights, and bodily autonomy remain heavily stigmatized and often misunderstood.These themes are controversial. And yes, the movie will divide people. But ‚Äòùó¶ùòÇùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóªùó≤‚Äô refuses to look away from the truth: ùòîùò¢ùòØùò∫ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ùòØùò® ùòçùò™ùò≠ùò™ùò±ùò™ùòØùò¢ùò¥ ùòßùò¢ùò§ùò¶ ùò¥ùòµùò≥ùò∂ùò®ùò®ùò≠ùò¶ùò¥ ùò≠ùò™ùò¨ùò¶ ùòµùò©ùò™ùò¥ ùò™ùòØ ùò¥ùò™ùò≠ùò¶ùòØùò§ùò¶. ùòàùòØùò• ùòµùò©ùò¶ùò∫ ùò•ùò¶ùò¥ùò¶ùò≥ùò∑ùò¶ ùò¶ùòÆùò±ùò¢ùòµùò©ùò∫, ùòØùò∞ùòµ ùò´ùò∂ùò•ùò®ùòÆùò¶ùòØùòµ.Maris is phenomenal here. She carries the entire emotional weight of the story with a performance that feels painfully real. She rarely breaks down on screen, but you think her internal collapse in the smallest expressions ‚Äî the breath she holds, the way she avoids eye contact, the way she pushes her dream forward while everything else is falling apart.ùóßùóµùó∂ùòÄ ùó∂ùòÄ ùó≤ùóÆùòÄùó∂ùóπùòÜ ùóºùóªùó≤ ùóºùó≥ ùóµùó≤ùóø ùóØùó≤ùòÄùòÅ ùóΩùó≤ùóøùó≥ùóºùóøùó∫ùóÆùóªùó∞ùó≤ùòÄ ùòÅùóº ùó±ùóÆùòÅùó≤.The supporting cast ‚Äî particularly Jennica Garcia, Meryll Soriano, Rhed Bustamante, and Xyriel Manabat ‚Äî also elevate the film, each representing a different kind of pressure or support Sunshine faces. And yeah, some male characters in the movie definitely got what they deserved. üòÖJadaone‚Äôs direction is quiet, patient, and uncomfortably close ‚Äî exactly how it should be. The movie lets us follow Sunshine‚Äôs anxiety and feel the suffocating pressure she‚Äôs under.One of the film‚Äôs boldest artistic choices is the recurring appearance of a mysterious girl who seems to follow Sunshine. At first it‚Äôs confusing, then a bit eerie, then surprisingly emotional. I won‚Äôt spoil anything, but when the film finally reveals who she represents‚Ä¶ üò≠. It‚Äôs symbolic, heartbreaking, and adds a deeper emotional layer to Sunshine‚Äôs arc.Beyond the gymnastics, beyond the controversy, Sunshine is really about choice ‚Äî and how young women often aren‚Äôt given the space to empower themselves to make their own choices.The movie conveys important messages: your body is your own; silence can mask the deepest struggles; the pressure to be perfect is harmful; pursuing dreams matters, but so is ensuring one's survival; kindness fosters safety, while judgment breeds fear; and young women need safe spaces. The movie doesn‚Äôt push a specific viewpoint ‚Äî it drives for humanity.Overall, ‚Äòùó¶ùòÇùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóªùó≤‚Äô is brave, heartbreaking, and painfully relevant. It does not shout ‚Äî it whispers truths that hit even harder. Indeed, it‚Äôs a film that mirrors reality for many young women today, and one that our society needs to see, even if the conversations it starts are uncomfortable.With that being said, I‚Äôm going to give this movie‚Ä¶9/10! ‚≠êÔ∏è (Woooo!)

SOLIDDDD tangina everything about this film works. angas kung paano pinakita ng ‚Äúsunshine‚Äù kung gaano kabigat yung ganung klaseng desisyon. hindi siya simpleng ‚Äúayoko‚Äù or ‚Äúgusto ko,‚Äù hindi ganun kadali. may takot, may guilt, may pressure, may mga pangarap na hindi nagtutugma sa sitwasyon. parang bawat eksena may bigat na hindi mo alam saan ilalagay, tapos kahit ikaw viewer lang, ramdam mo yung pagod nila. and yung whole thing about facing the possibility of abortion, ang linaw pakita dito na hindi siya quick choice. hindi siya ‚Äúbahala na,‚Äù hindi siya impulsive. it‚Äôs this long, messy, emotional process na walang tama o maling sagot pero lahat may consequences. the most painful part is how quick people are to judge na parang may manual sila sa tamang buhay ng isang babae. konting taliwas mo lang, ikaw na agad yung mali. wala silang alam sa trauma, sa hirap, sa takot, sa pangarap na paulit-ulit na nababangga sa realidad.at puta, nung mga eksena na yung doktor kung makaasta akala mo siya yung may-ari ng katawan ng babae? tas babae din siya jusko. and miggy‚Ä¶ tangina mo pa english-english kapa di mo nga alam word na accountability amen tangina mo din bobot ikalma niyo titi niyo (pasarap gusto? responsabilidad ayaw?)! it‚Äôs so frustrating watching someone act like they know everything.these stories are real and filipino women continue to suffer kasi sobrang stigmatized pa rin ang ganitong conversations. ang hirap maging babae sa pilipinas (2).¬©Ô∏èzowi

Sobrang hirap maging babae. Lalo na, maging Pilipinong babae.Sunshine is by far my favorite Filipino movie. The casting is phenomenal‚ÄîMaris is an incredible actress‚Äîand the cinematography perfectly captures what it feels like to live in a third-world country where women‚Äôs health is treated as one of the least priorities.Growing up, I always knew how hard it was to bear a child. All three of us siblings were delivered through cesarean section, to the point that my mom was in critical condition. My father had to choose who to save between me and my mama. But even with that knowledge, I never fully understood the depth of how difficult it truly is to be a woman‚Äîespecially in a predominantly Catholic country where family and faith are held above everything else.Being a woman‚Äîa Filipina woman‚Äîmeans constantly choosing between survival and expectation. I think now we are so comfortable discussing how a modern Filipina should break molds and create her own path. There is so much manifestation that now, more than ever, these cages should be dismantled. I don't want to say this, pero hindi pwedeng dahan-dahan tibagin ang problemang kumakahon sa kababaihan, because women should not endure when all their lives they are expected to survive.We honor the Church, follow tradition, and protect the image of being a ‚Äúgood woman,‚Äù even when those expectations silently hurt us. Even though I am pro-choice, I still feel slightly uncomfortable talking about abortion (because of how I was raised). And this topic is so important. This topic is so necessary, especially since most of our laws are anchored sa Katolisismo. Maging ang moralidad ng buong bansa ay nakabatay sa kung ano ang turo sa Bibliya. The truth is, women are left with no choice. They have no privilege to say ‚Äúayaw ko maging nanay,‚Äù which leads them to do ‚Äúillegal procedures‚Äù because, again, women‚Äôs health care has long failed us. The very system that is supposed to prepare and free us is the one that is caging us. We shouldn‚Äôt just look at this problem from a biblical perspective (notice how Sunshine went to the church after knowing she‚Äôs pregnant at 19?), not when the Church itself has been one of the loudest forces shaping the silence around women‚Äôs bodies. The problem begins when morality is dictated without considering lived realities‚Äîwhen doctrine is treated as absolute while women bleed, struggle, and navigate dangers that society refuses to acknowledge.And that‚Äôs the heartbreaking truth: Judgment is more accessible than proper healthcare. We preach compassion from the pulpit yet withhold it from the very women who need it most. I may not be the most religious person in the room, but I know my God. And He will never let me or anyone suffer from a torture.This is why conversations about reproductive rights are not just political‚Äîthey‚Äôre personal, urgent, and life-changing. When a woman, like Sunshine says ‚Äúayaw ko maging nanay,‚Äù she‚Äôs not being irresponsible. She‚Äôs being honest. But in this country, that honesty is treated as immorality. Women are pushed into silence, into shame, and into dangerous choices because the system refuses to give them safe ones. Walang point ang socially established morality mo kung selective lang ang application nito.We owe it to women to dismantle these cages not gently, but urgently. Because for generations, they‚Äôve endured quietly. For generations, they‚Äôve survived what they should never have had to face alone.And maybe that‚Äôs why Sunshine hurts so deeply. Because it‚Äôs not just a story. It‚Äôs a mirror of what we still refuse to fix.

ANG PANGARAP NI SUNSHINE AY NAGING PANGARAP KO NA DIN.maris racal delivers an outstandingly complex performance as antoinette jadaone's titular sunshine. she gave grit, nuance, and humor in sunshine that no other actress from her generation could deliver as unconstrained as her. i am not shy to admit that i have always been a fan of maris and have always known that she could deliver such a performance, but she truly was operating on a different caliber in this film. sunshine, as a film, shows the raw and honest experiences of women in a society that constantly attempts to not just strip away their rights but also their chances to have a choice. the film is straightforward and courageous in portraying the characters and story it wants to tell about, without any restriction‚Äîbut with absolute care. it lays bare the raw experience of women shackled by outdated norms, patriarchal laws, and the belief that their bodies and their choices are not truly their own.

me and my love for films that capture the mundanity of city streets, the way a place can be loud and crowded yet still shelter thousands of small sacrifices and quiet complexities. so many filipinos carry the same city-shaped loneliness: being away from family, feeling small beside high-rise buildings, breathing in the same polluted air day after day.but what makes this film stand out from everything i‚Äôve seen?it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs centered around women. the story follows a gymnast, someone expected to be disciplined, much like how women in this country are expected to behave simply because being born a woman already places you on a pedestal you never asked for and forces you to fit into patriarchal norms that keep the country from ever progressing.the film never paints these women as symbols or archetypes. jadaone shows them as people, real and ordinary, who carry their own exhaustion and yet offer kindness to those in need. the coach, the doctor, the hotel cashier, the kid, her best friend, her ate, and sunshine herself each give a kind of support that only women seem to instinctively offer and without asking for anything in return. it shows how women still choose to carry one another despite the burden of existing in a world that asks too much from them.gets ko na. sana ma-gets na rin ng lahat.

Direk Tonet Jadaone, come get your Baddie chain!Having lived in the City of Manila during my university days has shown me the city after dark [winks]. Seeing the city through Jadaone's lens takes me back to watching the classics of the '70s and '80s where we see Manila as the place where people begin to reach their dreams. We can see that with Sunshine's rehearsals and training routines in Malate's Rizal Memorial Sports Complex. She has become an Asian Games champion here, and she has started dreaming of becoming an Olympian here. That's Manila, the City of Dreams.But, similar to Bernal's Manila By Night (1980) and Brocka's Maynila sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (1975), we get to explore the dreadful city in its raw, authentic form. We see this as we walk together with Sunshine through the hazy streets of Downtown Manila during the day and the grimy pillars in Morayta's streets where prostitutes wait for clients at night. The film doesn't tackle these aspects of the city and just shows them as they are through guerrilla-esque filmmaking. It's just enough for the viewers to see the situation Sunshine and other Manile√±os are in. It might also be that, after decades of instability in the Capital, people already know that Manila is no longer what it used to be, so there's no need to explicitly discredit Manila's reputation anymore.And of course, when a young, unmarried Filipina gets pregnant in a movie, it's obvious that the film will touch on Christianity in the Philippines. We see the Catholic guilt Sunshine faces, the hate-filled Christian love that out-of-touch Filipinos have, and the deeply-ingrained consequences of colonialism to the Philippine society. Unfortunately, this isn't something new. This has been going on for centuries already, and has been a topic in Philippine cinema for decades.However, this film offers a more modern take using a sports drama. Maris Racal delivers what is undoubtedly the best performance by a Filipino actor this year so far. We can feel her desperation to fulfill her lifelong dream as an athlete to reach the Olympics. Whether or not you're someone who is against abortion, you will be forced to empathize with her dilemma because of how compelling she is.What I also like about the movie is it's not just some liberal self-help nonsense that just "wants to raise awareness" about an important issue. This film also challenges the worldview of religious conservatives. It will force people to ask themselves questions like:To what extent do women have to be forced to give birth to a child they don't want to have?What if she's a victim of incest?What if she's a rape victim?What if a pregnancy puts her life at risk?What if she can't afford to give a decent life for her child?What if she's not yet ready to be a parent?What if she simply doesn't want to be a mother?And, in the end, the film stands firm on what it believes in. It's so rare to see a Filipino movie be so unapologetic in its message and still get this much traction. I hope this opens the door for more movies that will boldly discuss controversial issues head-on because that's what we need.This film is outstanding, a real body of work. This cements my view of Jadaone as a filmmaker you can always trust to make good movies, and of Racal as an actress who will lead the next generation of stars. They're the future of Philippine cinema.

really loved watching sunshine. everything felt so real the acting, the places, the whole atmosphere. it really showed manila the way people actually see it every day: crowded streets, smoky air, tight alleys, small stalls everywhere, messy and honest.in sunshine, you follow a young gymnast who dreams of joining the national team. but right before her big try-out, she finds out she‚Äôs pregnant, and her whole life suddenly shifts. all the things she was working for feel like they‚Äôre slipping away.the movie doesn‚Äôt hide the harsh parts of her situation. she ends up looking for illegal abortion pills from sketchy vendors near church stalls, which shows how desperate people can get when safe options aren‚Äôt available. you also see how people look at her, the judgment, the shaming, the assumptions.one thing that really stood out was the little girl in the film. she felt like a symbol, almost like a reflection of innocence or the childhood the main character is losing too quickly. the little girl also shows how young women are expected to handle things way beyond their age, carrying responsibilities and pain that should never have been theirs in the first place. she represents the younger version of so many girls who grow up in harsh realities, where choices are limited and voices are ignored. the little girl is a reminder of what could‚Äôve been and what gets taken away too soon.through all of this, sunshine makes you think about real issues. what happens to young girls who get pregnant and have no support? what if they‚Äôre too young, or not ready, or simply trying to survive? what if they‚Äôre judged instead of helped?overall, sunshine felt raw and honest. no sugarcoating, no pretending, just real life, and that‚Äôs what makes it hit so hard.

Naiintindihan mo na?Gets ko na.At first I thought Annika's role was to portray Sunshine's inner child but of course as the movie progressed I realized what actually Annika's character represented. I also noticed how since Mary Grace was carrying her unborn child longer than Sunshine, Ariana already had a name meaning Mary Grace probably already thought & pictured giving birth to him knowing she didn't really have a choice after being sexually harassed at 13 years old by her mom's lover. While Sunshine only called Annikas's character Bata, showing how most probably from the beginning she knew what her choice would be therefore why she never thought of a name.A woman is often judged automatically once she considers abortion, she is often called names, and is labeled. Sunshine represents all the women who has already made up their minds, yet is still conflicted. Throughout her experience, she was consumed with guilt & doubt as she knows the weight that comes with even only thinking of what she's about to do but it's either that or sacrificing her dream, her only dream. People often judge quickly and forget that even when a young woman seems to easily decide to get rid of her baby, it's hers. What I mean to say is that, once a woman has an abortion she's not merely getting rid of a clump of cells, she's sacrificing a part of herself; a possibility, a what could've been.Sunshine was haunted with the thought of her child being angry and dissapointed at her for what she's about to do but as time went on and when she rehearsed her routine as she gave it her all whilst preparing for the Olympics, she is reminded why & from there she knew, that her child would've understood and that she's made peace with herself.This film excellently portrayed the unfortunate reality many young women & even children, are experiencing in our country ‚Äî all around the globe even. As I continue to write this review, the messages in the film remain present & true as I write this with a bit of doubt & guilt because I'm supposed to agree with the doctor that judged Sunshine right? Because in the bible it is a sin? Is it wrong that if I was with Sunshine I would've supported her decision? Sure, I wouldn't have encouraged her but I would've supported her nonetheless. That alone is proof how behind we are, not only from healthcare services to proper maternity wards but how we, as a Catholic country, continue to enforce our beliefs to individuals who clearly don't share the same belief.It is unfair how men like miggy & that uncle get to continue to live normally after what they did. Sure, they'd be guilty but when the time comes it isn't them who'll be lying on a hospital bed as an attempt fails or as a child is birthed; it isn't them who'll be conflicted to sacrifice their dreams nor is it them who'll be scrutinized and judged by everybody.May Sunshine be a reminder that it isn't selfish to choose yourself. In fact, to birth a child with an irresponsible father whilst being unstable in all aspects of yourself is more selfish of an act than choosing not to give birth.

Sobrang gets lang talaga ng palabas na ‚Äòto, sana napanood ko siya on a bigger screen. Ang galing ni Maris Racal, totoo nga na the moment na alam niyang buntis siya, naka-autopilot na siya at alam niya na kung ano yung gusto niyang mangyari kahit na hindi niya alam kung paano. Sa totoo lang, isa sa scene na napatanong na lang talaga ako kung ano bang silbi talaga ng mga lalaki ay yung nasa hospital si Sunshine kasi dinala niya si Menggay doon, tapos ipinakita yung mga kama na kaunti lang ang espasyo sa isa‚Äôt isa, yung mga manganganak pa lang at nakapanganak ng mga babae na nag-uusap at nag-abutan ng gamit ng bata. Ewan ko, ang hirap manganak, ang hirap maging nanay, at ang hirap ng estado ng healthcare sa Pilipinas. Bukod pa roon, nandoon yung bigat tsaka ingay sa kabuuan ng palabas. Bigat nung dinadala ni Sunshine bilang babae na hindi suportado ng karamihan ang pagpapalaglag dahil tayo ay nasa isang relihiyosong bansa. Yung ingay sa paligid, yung mga dasal, yung desperasyon, yung konsensya habang paikot-ikot siya para lang makahanap ng solusyon. Ayun, sana naman mas mapag-usapan pa ang reproductive health ng mga kababaihan sa Pilipinas, and yes decriminalize abortion.

Nakalulungkot isipin na isa‚Äôt isa na nga lang ang mayroon tayong kababaihan ngunit hindi pa rin lahat ng uri natin ay maituturing nating kakampi. Pangarap ko rin na magkaroon ng ate na gaya ng kay Sunshine. Minsan talaga, kahit isang kakampi lang na maniniwala at magtitiwala sa atin ay higit na sa sapat. Ganoon ang naramdaman ko habang pinanonood ang pelikulang ito, na kahit gaano man kalupit ang mundong ito sa kababaihan ay mayroon tayong kakampi sa paglaban para sa ating mga karapatan.Hindi man kami pareho ng sitwasyon ni Sunshine ay nakahanap ako ng kakampi sa mga tauhan sa pelikula na tumulong sa kaniya at hindi siya hinusgahan. Nakahanap ako ng kakampi sa ‚ÄòSunshine‚Äô, maging kay Sunshine mismo na hindi sinukuan ang kaniyang pangarap kahit na pilit siyang ikinakahon ng mundo tungo sa isang bersyon ng sarili niyang malayo sa kaniyang kagustuhan.

Sunshine felt so familiar to me, not because her story is mine, but because it mirrors someone I love. And like Sunshine‚Äôs sister, I stayed. Sometimes loyalty is quiet, sometimes it‚Äôs all you can offer, and sometimes it‚Äôs the only thing that saves someone. I believe God forgives, and I believe He lifts people back up, but He often does it through the hands of those who refuse to leave.What unsettled me was the doctor turning a fragile moment into a moral lecture. A woman‚Äôs choice belongs to her ‚Äî her body, her future, her weight to carry. That‚Äôs why I never argue about abortion. I don‚Äôt push beliefs. I don‚Äôt corner anyone into a ‚Äúshould.‚Äù I only guide, gently, and let them choose their own path.In the end, I saw myself in Sunshine or maybe the version of myself who hopes fiercely for others. And I‚Äôm genuinely thankful that she reached her dreams, even after walking through so much darkness to get there.

I just watched Sunshine and honestly, no words can fully capture how exceptional the writing is. The film lays bare how brutally hard it is to be a woman‚Äîespecially when it comes to unwanted pregnancies. Men ruin everything and walk away untouched, while women are left with all the responsibility, all the judgment, and all the shame. We‚Äôre expected to endure, to forget, to move on, while they roam freely without consequence!!!And it makes me fucking furious‚Äîfurious at men and the religious institutions that still believe they have the right to dictate what a woman can do with her own body. Women deserve choice, autonomy, and proper healthcare. We deserve dignity. I hope that one day our country finds the courage and progressiveness to give that to us.Being a woman is painfully hard‚Ä¶but the solidarity we find in other women makes the burden a little lighter, and the fight a little more bearable.

Drown out the noise. You're Sunshine.Sobrang tapang at sobrang totoo ng Pelikulang ito. Ramdam mo yung bawat emosyon na gustong iparamdam nila Direk Tonet at ni Maris. Maraming salamat Direk sa bawat dayalogong nakakapagbukas ng usaping madalas ay hindi napag-uusapan sa bansa. ---Sobrang galing na na portray nila ang Maynila lalo na ang bawat sulok ng Quiapo na lugar na puno ng kwentong ayaw pag-usapan. Quiapo na kahit saan ay may mga gamot at langis na bawal sa "batas ng Dyos".Bawat karakter sa Pelikula ay may role para sa kabuuan ng gustong ipakita ng pelikula;Si Sunshine na gagawin ang lahat para sa kanyang pangarap, ang ate niya na mirror kung ano ang hahantungin niya sa magiging desisyon niya sa bata, ang Pastor na personipikasyon ng matinding pananalig ng mga Filipino sa Diyos, si Dr. Helena at ang tindera sa Quiapo na nagbibigay pag-asa, at si Thea sa kung ano ang stigma ng bansa sa isyung ito. Madalas, ang tingin natin sa abortion ay "kasalanan sa Diyos" at ang teenage pregnancy naman ay "kadiri" pero kung ito man ang tingin ng karamihan sa bansa, bakit wala pa rin tayong ginagawang aksyon para rito? Bakit wala pa ring maayos at komprehensibong sex education lalo na para sa kabataan? Bakit wala pa rin tayong accessible healthcare, lalo na ang mga kababaihan,? at bakit wala pa ring karapatang mamili ang mga kababaihan para sa kanilang katawan? Maaring ang mga bata sa istorya ay ang personipikasyon ng konsensya nila Sunshine at Menggay, pero ang interpretasyon ko, sila ang "what could have been", ang mga buhay na maaring umusbong kung hindi sila nagpa abort. Maaring kaya't may pangalan si Ariana dahil sumagi sa isip ni Menggay ang buhayin ang bata, pero kaya't walang pangalan ang batang kasama ni Sunshine ay dahil simula't sapul ay alam niyang hindi pa niya kaya o gugustuhing maging ina (kahit na may mga oras na nagdadalawang isip siya). Kaya't may sariling pangarap si Ariana dahil maari siyang mabuhay. At ang pangarap naman ng bata, ay ang pangarap ni Sunshine, dahil mas malakas ang sigaw ng kanyang puso para tuparin ang mga pangarap na ito kaysa sa pagdadalawang isip niyang ipalaglag ang bata. Sa Bansang konserbatibo katulad ng Pilipinas mahirap pag-usapan at madalas ay iniiwasan natin ang mga taboo topics tulad ng aborsyon, relihiyon, r4pe, at kahit idolism politicians, pero katulad ni Sunshine, kailangan natin itong harapin. At katulad ni Sunshine, tayo ay mangarap, na mabuksan ang isip ng bawat-isa at magkaroon ng maayos na solusyon sa mga ito. Sa mga isyu katulad ng aborsyon, tayo ay may sari-sariling opinyon at ang bawat opinyon na ito ay may mga rasong mula sa mga karanasan, sariling paniniwala, at maski sa takot natin. Si Sunshine, ipinakita niya na hindi natin kailangang hanapin ang kung ano nga ba ang "tama" at hindi natin kailangang baguhin ang ating paniniwala. Kundi, Kailangan lamang natin buksan ang mga mata, puso, at utak sa bawat isyung ito at sa mga sitwasyon ng mga taong nakararanas nito.Sa huli, alam nating mas pinili ni Sunshine ang kanyang pangarap. Bago man makamit ito, maraming pagsubok ang kanyang dinanas, at marami rin siyang nalamang kwento na katulad ng sakanya. Hindi lamang nag-iisa si Sunshine!Maaring isang karakter lamang sa isang piksyon na pelikula si Sunshine, ngunit ang bawat eksena rito ay maaring naranasan na rin ng isang tao, at ang istorya ni Sunshine ay istorya ng lahat ng kababaihan. Hindi lamang nag-iisa si Sunshine, maaring mayroon na tayong nakasalamuhang katulad ni Sunshine, maaring tayo rin ay si Sunshine na gagawin ang lahat para sa pangarap. Ngayon, Gets ko na, Gets na kita, Sunshine.---

first of all, i love the acting of Maris, she portrayed the character so well. Isang malaking sampal ang pelikulang 'to sa mga hipokritong taong nagtatago sa pagiging "relihiyoso" nila dahil lamang ayaw nila at hindi nila ma-respeto ang desisyon ng mga babaeng gaya ni Sunshine. Maraming babae ang gaya ni Sunshine‚Äî takot, naliligaw, at nabibingi sa ingay ng mga boses ng mga mapanghusgang tao. Sana maging way ang film na 'to para ma-legalize na ang abortion sa Pilipinas. Dahil habang ipinagkakait sa mga babae ang autonomy nila sa sarili nilang katawan, at ang karapatan nilang magdesisyon‚Äî dadami at dadami ang mga babaeng kagaya ni Sunshine at ng character ni Rhed Bustamante ang magre-resort sa delikadong pamamaraan. ps: putangina mo Miggy at putangina no'ng tito ni Rhed sa pelikula.

late review, but the tears that i have shed were an overwhelming amount ‚Äî tears for the women who felt so alone, with a cruel world that seems to surround them from all sides, forcing to navigate these hardships on their own while combating bigotry, misogyny, and prejudice in modern society. yung scene kung saan humingi ng tulong si rhed bustamante kay sunshine hanggang sa hospital, iyak ako nang iyak, na parang naghilamos ako. konting-konti lang yung nakakagets pero karamihan hindi, kasi nasa bansa tayo na traditionalist, maka-diyos (thus sunshine‚Äôs plea for forgiveness, that familiar catholic guilt), at mapili pa sa morality. kaya kahit anong galaw mo bilang isang babae, feeling mo ang daming mata nakatutok sayo, ang bilis nila manghusga at sila pa yung gumagawa ng mga desisyon mo, binubuo pa yung buhay mo kahit hindi mo pa nga naaabot o nakakabuo ng pangarap mo. mahirap maging babae sa pilipinas, and the film portrays the harsh reality so honestly. ‚Äúdrown out the noise‚Äù a line that rises above judgement, criticism, and societal pressure. sana mapaunlad ang sistema natin sa healthcare at para sa kababaihan, at sana mas marami sa atin ang maka-gets.

Oh my fucking god, Direk Tonet, you did it! YOU ACTUALLY DID IT!!!Drown out the noise.A film for all women out there. This is definitely an outstanding film that captures the reality of most women in the Philippine society. Sobrang ganda. The color grading? Kuhang kuha yung magulo, maingay at masulasok na lugar ng Maynila, at partikular nito ay sa Quiapo. Ang ironic rin, na yung nagbebenta ng pamparegla or pampalaglag is the same na ale who's selling religious statues and relics. I love how it contradicts the situation. Kitang kita mo yung gustong ipahiwatig ng film throughout that specific scene alone. Ang galing lang talaga. Ang daming nangyari sa Quiapo. I would love to point out na true, sobrang pinoy ng actions ni Sunshine there. Iba yung tama ng bawat hakbang niya papalapit sa simbahan para humingi ng tawad, sa ale na nagbebenta ng pampalaglag, lugar na puno ng relihiyoso ngunit mapanghusgang mga tao, sa pagsira kuno ng kotse ng putanginang ex niya na wala man lang reaksyon nung sinabi niyang buntis siya, sa pagcheck in niya sa avenida inn. Tagos na tagos at damang dama ko yung emosyon ni Sunshine from the screen. Hindi lahat gusto maging nanay at tumayong maging magulang sa mga anak nila. Totoo naman. Iba ang bigat at responsibilidad na dala ng isang pagiging nanay. Kahit ganun saludo pa rin ako sayo, Sunshine. Para sa mga babae at para lamang sa mga babae. I love being a woman. This film touched me to the core. Ang iyak ko sa last scenes, jusko. Gets ko na, GETS NA GETS KO NA TALAGA!!!

The hype is real ‚Äî it is that good.It starts at a pace that might feel overwhelming for some, reminding me of Anora and Uncut Gems: you think you know where it‚Äôs going, but it proves you wrong every time.Then it swirls into a cut-throat reality check on how brutally the healthcare system and religious beliefs fail young women‚Äôs reproductive health. At one point, I found myself teary, realising how f*cked up the system is ‚Äî how biases and beliefs can completely derail someone‚Äôs life.Sunshine isn‚Äôt a perfect film, but its message stings and leaves you gobsmacked. It‚Äôs definitely landing in my Top 10 of the year.A must-see.

Best Filipino movie I watched this year because it's the only Filipino movie I watched... Kidding aside, I've been in a huge movie slump for a long time and this was the only movie I wanted to watch in the cinema, and I wasn't able to do so. When I found out that it was coming on Netflix, it was the only thing that kept me going for the whole month. I'm so glad that I watched it. This just intensified my political rage because I've always wished that abortion was legal here in the Philippines. I hope for a future that no other woman may go through all the things that Sunshine went through. I hope that no one else would be forced to go through motherhood when they are far from ready. But we could only hope. I love you Antoinette Jaodone, and Maris Racal. Fuck you Miggy, and fuck the men who can't wear condoms. May the government rot for still not approving abortion in the Philippines, and shame on the Spaniards for planting the catholic mindset and catholic guilt to us.

This film is a fucking masterpiece. It is a protest‚Äîa massive slap in the face to those who deny women of the liberty to choose. That alone is one thing to talk about which this film DEMANDS and I am soooo here for it. I've said it before and I'll say it again, Direk Tonet's range is a blessing to philippine cinema. The way her mind works, and every detail that was put into this film was nothing short of perfection. Hangang-hanga ako sa'yo, Direk, as in. BWELO!!! Also, this is Maris Racal's best performance yet, gets ba? The way it looked as if she really owned the pain, the way it REALLY felt as if everything was against her. Ang galing, sobra. Bwelo part 2!In terms of the film's themes, I just want to say na sobrang timely at perfect niya. EVERYONE NEEDS TO SEE THIS. Abortion is healthcare, and to deny abortion means to disregard a person, more specifically, a woman's right to healthcare. Sana sa pamamagitan ng pagsusubaybay kung paano naging impyerno ang buhay ni Sunshine ng napakabilis, mamulat naman tayo kahit kakaunti. Speaking of women and healthcare, WE NEED MORE DOCTORS LIKE DOC HELENA!!!! Tangina imbyerna ako dun sa matandang biglang nag bible sharing, like of all places and of all situations, dun ka talaga?? Sa isang maternity ward?? Gets, Catholicism in the Philippines is widespread, pero that does not excuse the fact na there is a time and place for it jusko. Also, some might not get the little girl's (Annika Co) role sa film, pero the way I view it, She is the personification ng pinapasan nila. The inner saboteur that was born from immense societal pressure. The child they gave birth to, before actually giving birth. For me, sobrang important ng role niya dun, because Sunshine's body language can only tell so much, kaya they were a big help in terms of really navigating Sunshine's individuality. Then we have Miggy. Actually wala akong gustong sabihin sa kanya. Tangina niya. Let's leave it at that nalang. I have soooooo much to say about this film, but I'm going to leave it at that, because I want you and everyone else to watch it kasi sobrang relevant niya AS IN. Tangina napakaganda.

I really really wished i watched this at the cinema pero okay na rin ata na sa kwarto ko lang at mag-isa kong pinanuod ito dahil walang halong biro na iyak ko nang iyak, tsaka yung galit ko, walang mapagsidlan. Nakakagalit kasi sa tuwing napapag-usapan o napupunta sa ganitong topic iyong usapan, bakit kailangan pang ipaliwanag ang abortion nang maingat na para bang may matatapakan? Na sa tuwing pinipilit kong kumbinsihin sinumang kausap ko, palaging naiiyak ako sa sobrang frustration kasi di nila ma-gets iyong pinupunto ko. One time, habang naglalakad kami pa-Recto galing school, may baby na umiiyak sa sidewalk, may katabi siyang tulog na minor de edad na lalaki at babae (di ko alam kung kapatid ba ito nung baby o sila iyong parents). Then, there's also a time during a jeepney commute from Tondo to Quiapo, may nakasabay akong dalawang teenager rin na may dalang baby, one doing her best to hold the baby in her small arms while the other looked out for them. My concern goes out for the baby, but my greatest concern are for those kids, who were children as well. Madami pang beses na may na encounter ako na almost the same situation and even now, I could never know their real stories. At tuwing umuuwi ako sa bahay, isang malaking singhap at galit na naman sa gobyerno ang dala ko. Sabi nila, masyado akong sensitibo para maramdaman yung ganitong malalaking emosyon pero naisip ko, hindi nga ba dapat lang na magalit tayo? Hindi ba empathy ang pinakang kailangan sa mga ganitong pagkakataon at sitwasyon? Kaya gayon na lamang ang pasasalamat ko kay direk tonet sa paglikha ng karakter na kagaya ni Sunshine at pagsulat ng isang storya na totoong sumasalamin sa matagal nang suliranin ng mga kababaihan dito sa Pilipinas. Sobrang galing lamang na naipahayag nya iyong kwento nang may labis na pag-unawa, hindi lamang sa isang indibidwal, kundi sa maraming kababaihan na may parehas na kinatatayuan. Sobrang galing din ng cinematography, editing, at production design, lalo na nung napakinggan ko sa AWKP kung gaano ka meticulous iyong buong staff behind the camera para mai-portray ng pelikulang ito iyong mensahe na gusto nitong iparating. Sobrang galing at sobrang nakaka empower. Nawa'y maunawaan na nila, kung di man ng lahat pero sana ng nakararami lalong lalo na iyong may mga kapangyarihan (parehas sa gobyerno at religion) para maisaayos ang matagal nang kakulangan ng access sa maayos na healthcare dito sa bansa. You all preach for love and care for one another but when it's a girl or a woman just simply wanting ownership for her own body, you simply cannot give her that? Then, maybe your belief and love for God is too narrow-minded and shallow. It's high time we hear the pleas of all Sunshines out there! As for me, gets na gets kita Sunshine. Gustong gusto kitang yakapin.

‚ÄúGets ko na.‚ÄùThe film doesn‚Äôt preach, it just lays out the messy truth. Sunshine chooses herself, her future, and her dreams, and the film refuses to guilt-trip her for it. It‚Äôs a story that sits right in the tension between ‚Äúpro-life‚Äù in the traditional Filipino sense and the very real reality that a woman‚Äôs body is her call. My body, my choice. Hindi siya concept dito‚Äîpinapakita siya as lived experience.What makes the movie hit harder is how disruptive it is to the usual script. In our culture, teenage pregnancy is still treated like some moral test the girl has to pass, while the older generation automatically leans into religion, ‚Äúpro-baby,‚Äù and quiet suffering as the noble path. Meanwhile, the guy who should be held accountable often disappears into the background, untouched. Or worse, the film doesn‚Äôt shy away from showing how men can also be the source of the violence‚Äîrape, exploitation, dynamics twisted by class and power.But the film doesn‚Äôt drown in despair. Sunshine‚Äôs sister? She‚Äôs the heartbeat of the whole thing. The support, the admiration, the way she stands beside Sunshine without making her feel small. And honestly, it‚Äôs the kind of love that exposes how warped the traditional expectations are. Some women support women. Some people actually understand that choosing yourself is choosing life.Sunshine isn‚Äôt a comfortable watch‚Äîand that‚Äôs the point. It shakes the old narratives, calls out the hypocrisy, and makes space for a girl to choose her own damn direction without being sanctified or demonized for it. Brave film. Needed film.

Everything about this film is a masterpiece‚Äîthe storyline, the cinematography, the sfx (the murmurs got me!).It exposes the harsh reality of abortion in the ph, and it speaks a lot for women who have lived with their pain in silence. Misery. This is just exactly why abortion must be legalized. Women deserve proper healthcare, dignity, and choice.

This movie is begging you to consider the lives of these young girls, and not just the unborn child, when talking about abortion. Who should take precedence might be a judgment call, but the autonomy of the would-be (or not) mothers should always be respected. I love that the resolution scene is one of ultimate understanding. Everything in this film is so quintessentially Filipino. I felt like I have met a version of all these characters at least once in real life. I also appreciated how Manila is portrayed, and how it became a character of its own in the story. 10/10 storytelling

gets ko na.this film looks soft at first, but underneath it‚Äôs basically a reminder of how exhausting it actually is to be a woman in a world built by people who never had to fight for basic respect.it doesn‚Äôt go on some dramatic rant about misogyny. it just shows it‚Äîquiet, casual, constant. the kind of everyday sexism that everyone else seems numb to, the kind you‚Äôre expected to ignore unless it becomes too obvious to pretend it isn‚Äôt there. women always notice it long before anyone else does.being a woman now means moving through life with your guard halfway up all the time, because experience already taught you that someone is always ready to talk over you, question you, or blame you for something they‚Äôd excuse instantly if a man did it.that pressure‚Äîbe perfect but not intimidating, kind but not ‚Äúweak,‚Äù confident but not ‚Äútoo much‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs all over this film. not even in a dramatic way. just‚Ä¶ there. like background noise we‚Äôve gotten used to.what hit me the most is how the men in this movie move through the world with zero awareness. no fear. no second thoughts. they get space, leniency, the benefit of the doubt. women get judgment, expectations, consequences.and the crazy part is how normal it all feels. like yep, here we go again. this is just life.sunshine gets that quiet frustration‚Äîthe tiredness that doesn‚Äôt go away. the way women are still somehow the ones expected to bend, adjust, shrink, compromise. the ones apologizing for having boundaries or opinions or basic self-respect.it‚Äôs not a movie that tries to ‚Äúempower‚Äù or offer solutions. it doesn‚Äôt even try to soften the message. it just holds up a mirror and goes: ‚Äúsee? this is what we deal with.‚Äùand honestly‚Ä¶ yeah. it is.

I tried to avoid this movie for the longest time. Afraid that it might ignite a trauma I suppressed for so long. But now that it's available on Netflix, I felt that I could finally watch it alone. I'm so glad that I watched it. As a child from an unplanned pregnancy, it was so refreshing to see that Sunshine got to choose her future. There was no point in that movie I disagreed with her. It was a thought provoking film done beautifully by direk tonet. It tackled several topics of poverty, corruption, bad governance, and bad healthcare in the Philippines. Sunshine is a film that explained the saying "Ang hirap maging babae, pero mas mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas." I hate that even though we live in a progressive generation, the Philippines is still behind on so many levels. This is definitely one of my favorite movies.

SHET ANG GANDA WOW. unang-una sa lahat, totoo nga yung nababasa at napapanood ko sa internet tungkol sa sunshine. at hindi sila nagkakamali. wala nakong ibang masabi kundi ang ganda!! kuhang-kuha talaga yung hirap na pinagdaanan ni sunshine sa kasulok-sulukan ng maynila. hindi lamang ni sunshine ang nakararanas nito, pati na rin lahat ng kababaihan na pinagkaitan ng accesible at maayos na healthcare at suporta mula sa gobyerno. alam naman natin na mahirap talaga magpa-abort sa pilipinas dahil kalaban mo ang gobyerno, ang batas, at ang isang buong relihiyon (kaya mahirap pag-usapan ang aborsyon sa bansa natin eh kasi nga taliwas ito sa sampung utos ng diyos which makes most of the filipinos pro-life). pinapakita lang din nito kung gaano natin kailangan ang sex education. pataas nang pataas ang teenage pregnancy rate sa bansa natin at hindi pa rin ito inaaksyunan ng mga nasa puwesto. its better that we are aware than sorry (impromptu speech flashbacks) a lesson i can take from this is that everything is political. oo, isa lang itong pelikulang ginawa ni direk tonet, pero nakakabahala isipin na mataas ang chances na may MGA babaeng totoong nakakaranas nito. napaiyak ako doon sa part na tinanggap pa rin siya ng ate niya kahit ganoon yung sitwasyon niya. sinuportahan pa rin siya at inintindi. ramdam ko yung bigat na nararamdaman ni sunshine. syempre ba naman, ang pangarap mo na siyam na taon mong pinaghirapan ay mawawala lamang dahil sa isang unwanted na pregnancy. grabe din ung pressure sa kaniya since part siya ng national team and it would be a big scandal kung nalaman ng publiko ung situation niya. pero sunshine proved us wrong, even if she was under all those circumstances, she still pushed through with her dream. ang hirap maging babae, lalo na kung mahirap ka.grabe, you will realize throughout the film how hard it is to be a woman‚Äîlalo na if you live in the Philippines, where privilege is a hard earned thing. not just that, puno rin ng mga religious people. sa kanila, mas angat ang moral kesa sa empathy at understanding‚Äîgod is everything kamo, kahit yung may pakana ay rapist. hindi lang 'yon, when one gets pregnant early, the woman gets all the blame. palibhasa, men are mostly trash. alam kung paano magpalabas ng tite, pero kapag nakabuntis na, biglaang nawalan ng pag-iisip. nakakadiri ang mindset na kapag nabuntis ang babae nang maaga, malandi agad sa paningin ng mga tao‚Äîthe woman gets all the dirty looks, the shit talks, as if the male's semen has nothing to do with it. i love this film so much‚Äîdinig na dinig ang boses ng mga babae, kung gaano kahirap humingi ng tulong, at ang konsensiya sa desisyon na hindi naman dapat masama. the cinematography is chef's kiss. and yung inner child ni sunshine, god, it made me cry.hindi murder ang abortion, lalo na kung hindi pa naman ito buo sa tiyan mo. a fetus is not yet a human, it is still a cell. hindi masama ang abortion lalo na kung hindi pa handa ang nagdadala, at mas lalo na kung dahil sa üçá. abortion should be legal, because it is healthcare. and a woman's body is hers to decide, hindi dapat ito taboo to begin with.

Sunshine is the kind of film that quietly earns for your attention. It pulls you into a world that feels overwhelmingly familiar yet rarely portrayed with this level of honesty. At the heart of it is Maris Racal, delivering what may be her most nuanced performance to date.The film‚Äôs backdrop, quiapo, is equally compelling. Masikip, Mainit, Maingay, Mabaho ‚Äî pero buhay. This is a story of sacrifice, particularly the kind expected from women. That they are often asked to endure more than they should. They are expected to adjust, to stay, to carry, to choose responsibility over desire. Sunshine goes deeper, challenging the everyday hypocrisy we tend to overlook. This film will leave you with a question that lingers long after the credits fade: Do we truly have the right to decide what‚Äôs ‚Äúright‚Äù for someone else?Sunshine reminds us that empathy begins where judgment ends. And at the core of all this realism and heaviness is a message that lands softly: choose kindness. because behind every decision is a story we do not fully know. behind every face is a storm we did not witness.Sunshine isn‚Äôt just the best filipino film i‚Äôve watched this year ‚Äî it is a brave, intimate, and necessary piece of storytelling. In the end it leaves us with a simple truth: after every storm, we wait for Sunshine to come. ‚õÖÔ∏è

At sana, lahat ng nakakaranas nito kagaya ni Sunshine, ay mayroong isang tao na handang umintindi at ipaliwanag ang mga bagay na hindi kayang maintindihan ng isang babaeng ayaw at hindi pa handang maging ina.Direk Tonet, salamat sa sining at sa pelikulang unti-unting nagpapamulat sa realidad na hinaharap ng mga kababaihan, lalo na dito sa Pilipinas.

‚ÄúDrown out the noise.‚Äù The words from her coach keep echoing in Sunshine‚Äôs mind whenever she loses focus during her routine. But in the middle of Manila‚Äîthe blaring jeepney horns, the chaotic streets of Quiapo, the rumbling trains‚Äîthere seems to be no escape from sound. Yet the real noise is inside her: voices in her head questioning, doubting, demanding answers. What is right? What should she choose? Should she continue pursuing the dream she started, or embrace the new life quietly growing inside her? Amid the chaos, Sunshine‚Äôs heart struggles, searching for peace, for direction, for the courage to decide.This is arguably one of the bravest Pinoy films released in Philippine cinema, even if it didn‚Äôt get wide distribution. It tackles women‚Äôs autonomy‚Äîraising a child, reproductive rights, and the right to choose what‚Äôs best for themselves. So bold, it challenges the comfort zone and questions the stereotypical mindset toward women who experience teenage pregnancy.The film is also a stark reminder of how broken our healthcare system is for women, especially in maternal care. Sunshine‚Äôs story is just the tip of the iceberg among thousands of women who struggle to keep their children alive or risk their bodies simply because their physiology or age cannot sustain a pregnancy.This is NOT about ABORTION. This film is about how women are crucified for past choices, how society lets one moment define a lifetime. It shows how young girls are often weaponized by circumstances beyond their control‚Äîpregnancy, abuse, or rape‚Äîwithout understanding that some are victims of forces they didn‚Äôt choose.‚ÄúGets ko na.‚Äù That line in the third act cemented this as one of the best films I‚Äôve seen this year. It‚Äôs not just about understanding‚Äîit‚Äôs about Sunshine finally realizing what‚Äôs best for her. Her missteps never stopped her from becoming an Olympian.This film is powerful, necessary, and unforgettable. A definite must-watch.Lesson learned: Fuck men! hahaha
